Slammed from a bottle, aroma is strong coffee, taste is smooth roast and coffee, love this guy
Delicious beer! Pours black with a small tan head, smells of coffee lots of it and a bit of chocolate, tastes the same as it smells.
Had this poured on draft at Bells tap room.   Black pour with tan head. Coffee aroma. Coffee taste. Very smooth. Standard IPA

Bottle. Poured black with a medium-sized tan head that left some lacing.  Aroma and flavor were rich coffee, quite a lot of dark roasted malt, a bit of milk chocolate. I usually dont like coffee stouts -- usually taste like acrid, stale grounds to me. But this one was quite good.
In a bottle good coffee flavor. .. burnt with hops and malt. .. great beer!!!!!!!
Really a nice burnt coffee taste. Not heavy on the palate but certainly not a light least. Very burnt roasted favors. Stellar for coffee stout lovers!

Bottle thanks to Jstax ! Pours a rich burnt umber color with a finger or two of khaki foam... Aromas are roasty chocolate, deep espresso, licorice and some earthy boozy fruit. The palate follows the nose with a rich creamy mouthfeel with a aggressive bubble. Sweet milk chocolate, deep burnt coffee, dark fruits... long roast on the finish even a touch of peat. Burly.

Pours opaque black with slight brown highlights, a nice tan head with good lacing.  The nose imparts aroma of roasted malt and a deep coffee that smells a bit acrid and vegetal.  Small amount of bakers chocolate and caramel.  Taste is mostly coffee grounds and dark roasted malt with an ashy  flavor.  The barest amount of sweetness from the malt and a moderate but sharp bitter.  Mouthfeel is smooth with a medium/full body and moderate carbonation.  Similar to Founders Breakfast Stout with the slightly vegetal coffee ground taste that I dont really like.  I prefer more of a rich coffee bean flavor, but this isnt a bad beer by any means.

Deep brown color with a little light showing through around the rim, no head. Smells of coffee dominate as expected, also some vegetal like smells, grass, a little roast. Tastes of roast coffee, booze, some bitterness and a little bit of sweetness in the form of maybe a chocolate or cocoa. Needs a little more sweetness to balance it. And I don't care much for the grass/vegetal smells. Decent overall but doesn't quite hit the mark.

Dark stout with cream head. Prefect amount of coffee flavor. Very smooth for a stout.

2013 bottle to a snifter.  Dark brown color with a little tan head and good lacing.  Aroma is chili pepper and vegetal with some tobacco ash, coffee grounds and chocolate.  Taste is the same.  Medium mouthfeel.

Rich color. Has a lightly sweet flavor, but very strong coffee taste. I did not like this one that much since it had a brutal bitter finish.

Very dark in color with a nice carmel colored head that holds for quite a while.
Smells like chocolate. Awesome taste of caramel, chocolate and  coffee.
This is one of the best beers I have had from Bells and as far as that goes any other brand. Nice job!   Truly magnificent.

On tap in a imperial pint glass at Papago Brewing Co. Strong espresso nose with toasted biscuit and a pungent bark-like bite. Pours a jet black with a smooth tan head, interspersed with several huge bubbles, and sticky lacing. Very sharp earthy, dark-roast espresso taste with bitter chocolate and cinnamon  The bitterness and cocoa taste lingers for a long, almost woody finish. Medium, easily quaffable body. The rich Sumatran roast sets this apart from most coffee stouts.

Black pour with beautiful fluffy large tan head. Aroma of roasted malt and coffee. Taste of roasted malt, chocolate, coffee, a slight hint of tartness and faint hint of powdery cocoa. Full bodied and creamy, very good.
Bells Java Stout has a strong coffee taste and aroma. It is dark brown in color. It has a light chocolate flavor. Bittersweet taste
Aroma is roasted coffee.  Apperarnce is dark with a dark cream head about a finger width. taste is roasted coffee that lingers a bit. this is a good coffee flavor stout
12oz bottle. Pours jet black with a thin mocha colored head. Aroma of roasted coffee, dark chocolate, and some hoppy bitterness. Taste is bitter coffee, espresso, dark chocolate, and burnt toast.
Bottle - Pours black with a nice thick coffee head. Huge aroma of coffee and a creamy mouthfeel. Im not a huge coffee fan but I liked this one.

The Java Stout pours nice and dark with a tan brown head that leaves pleasant lacing. The aroma is mostly coffee with some chocolate and caramel mixed in. The flavor mostly follows suit but there is a hint of floral hops. Overall this is delicious and I recommend you have one or two.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

The color of this beer is a very dark brown with a small off-white head, and the aroma is purely of coffee beans. The taste is mildly sweet, mildly bitter, and slightly umami, which is like a not-too-strong cup of coffee; furthermore, the palate combines a slick texture, full body, soft carbonation, and a long bitter finish that is reminiscent of slightly old and room temperature coffee, but this isnt necessarily a bad thing because the body of the beer counteracts the negative connotations of old coffee due to the robustness of the mothfeel.

Draft at Proof. Black pour with a creamy tan head. Rich aroma of chocolate chip cookies, roasted malts and fresh ground coffee beans. Thick, rich chocolate flavor, espresso with roasted malts and a earthy finish. Creamy mouthfeel and smooth carbonation. Damn tasty.

UPDATED: FEB 5, 2014 Pours a beautiful jet black, with caramel colored head. Head dissipates quickly, and has aromas of caramels and coffee. great lacing that stays for the entire beer. hints of caramel and vanilla upon first taste. So delicious

12 oz bottle pours a very dark brown, almost black color with small tan head and good lacing.  Smells of coffee and roasted malts.  Aroma is dominated by coffee, but with enough roasted malts and a touch of chocolate for balance.  Body is thinner than I expect for a stout.  Mouthfeel is creamy without too much carbonation.  Taste is bitter coffee with a short dry finish.  An excellent coffee stout, which I avoided for a couple of years because of the price of a 6-pack of these.
Lovely bitter coffee flavor with notes of roasted malts and chocolate.  Black in color with khaki head that leaves lacing.  One of the best stouts Ive had featuring the taste of "java".

coffee coffee and more coffee.  Roasted espresso.  This is a coffee stout.  Body is a tad thin for my taste but about where a 7.5% usually is.  My only complaint is that this is pretty expensive for a 6 pack.

Bottle to pint, pours thick oily black with a tan head, great looking brew.  Aroma is great as well, good amount of coffee on the nose.  Taste is spectacular...roasted coffee to the max.  Very well done, one of the best stouts out there.

Appearance: Oh boy does this beer look nice. Pitch black with a very nice and creamy tan head. Lacing is patchy but very nice as well.

Smell: Actually the lowest point of this beer ... I figured itd smell awesome, but its basically average. It has a very faint coffee aroma, but malts are the primary smell here.

Taste/feel: I can say this is one of the best "feeling" beers ever. So smooth, and the slickness left at the end of each sip that not even Founders Breakfast Stout can replicate. Is this a better stout than that one? I dont think so, though its VERY close, in my opinion. FBS seems to have more layers of flavor, but Java Stout isnt too shabby, and like I said, the feel is phenomenal. 

Like any other stout, I personally wouldnt drink this one too often, but its a great every-now-and-then beer.

Holy cow. This is a tasty tasty beer. Its kind of like taking espresso, melt in a chocolate bar, pour in a bada$$ stout. Then take it, boil it down, put it through a strainer. Then take it and throw in some carb tablets or force carbonate it. THEN you pour it in my glass and then I drink it! Thats a nice nice nice beer. Yah, its a big beer but I love that i can find it in a 6 pack.
Bottle. Pours rich dark. Dark tan head. Smokey coffee aromas. Smooth palate, real simple to drink. Complex roasty toasty coffee flavor.

Pours thinner than my taste for stouts. Finger-width head, light in color. Very distinct coffee smell, love it. Very, very distinct coffee taste, meh. Usually a fan of coffee stouts, but this coffee is overpowering. Thin and goes down smooth. Overall, pretty good. Had better, had far worse.

Pours near black with a nice tan head. Smells like a fresh pot of coffee, and a Hershey bar. Tastes almost entirely of dark coffee, fills the mouth for just a few seconds and then its gone. Overall very solid.

Pours dark brown with an impressive khaki head. Aroma is dominated by strong black coffee. The taste is also dominated by bitter black coffee, but has a pepper element as well. Creamy mouth feel and a bitter finish. Improves greatly as it warms.

Pours black with a 2 finger, tan head.  Had aromas of black coffee, dark chocolate, and a bit of roastiness.  Really strong going down, and had a bit of bitterness to it.  The taste of black coffee lingers.  Medium bodied, but not too thick.  Definitely a digable beer.

12oz. bottle poured into a pint glass. Pours a very dark brown with minimal cream colored head and light carbonation. Moderate amount of lacing. The aroma is heavy. I can smell it perfectly, a foot away from the glass. STRONG coffee/espresso smell with a slight booziness and hint of vanilla. Taste is all coffee and roast up front followed by a wonderful, bitter/chocolate flavor. The coffee comes back and sits on your tongue for a bit. The best coffee/cappuccino stout by far. Definitely 1 for the aging cellar.

12oz bottle pours a dark black/brown with a medium tan head. Aroma of peppery roasted coffee, some smoke, and chocolate. Taste has a dry coffee roasted bitterness that rides until the end with undertones of hops and chocolate. Good stuff!
Pours oil black with a thin chocolate head. Smells of espresso, coffee, chocolate, and a slight chili pepper note. Tastes of espresso beans, cream, coffee, and cocoa nibs. Really really nice stout.

extra in trade with wchesser.. thanks a bunch buddy..Pour is dark brownish black with a cream tan head..Nose is coffee beans, light roast, chocolate..Taste is roast, boldness, chocolate,coffee, oily..Palate is coffee and oily.

Pours coffee black with a minimal tan head. Aromas of coffee beans and cocoa. Flavor is straight up black coffee bitterness with a slight chocolate balance and some slight earthy hops coming through also but the coffee aspect takes the reigns in this one. Bells has yet to disappoint me and this one is no exception.

Pours a nice black. Smell is roasted malt and fresh coffee. Taste is crazy fresh coffee and toast. Reasonably thick with a long toasty finish.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Strong coffee infusion here. Lots of roast, dark chocolate. Pours with decent head and lacing, pitch black. Coffee bitter aftertaste with residual bitterness. Average carbonation, consistency a bit syrupy. Bottle from Smoke it Here.

Black with brown head.  Smells like...cofee, surpising huh?  Taste - Rich coffee beans...very fresh, authentic taste...if youre a coffee lover this is fantastic for you.  Notes of dark chocolate and even a bit nutty, but certainly cofee dominates.
From tap. Pours black with little head. Aroma is all coffee and dark roasted malts. Slight jalapeno aroma. Taste follows. All coffee with a slight jalapeno aftertaste. Not hot, just taste.

One of the better coffee beers, I think. Although, Ive never met a Bells beer that I didnt like! Big dark, espresso flavor & aroma. Dark chocolate, slight roast and a touch of hop bitterness for balance. A great breakfast beer!

UPDATED: FEB 26, 2013 Aroma of clay and coffee. Bitter black coffee bite. Great oily mouth feel. Carbonation almost hovers, waiting to be drank. Good yearly brew. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Love everything about this beer! Poured pitch black. Freshly brewed coffee aroma. Deep dark coffee & dark chololate flavor. Great mouthfeel. Bitter finish. Well done!

Great coffe stout, but like everything Bells, too expensive.  Very good body, aroma, taste, and pallet.  Love this beer.  For me, this winter, this coffee stout falls to third behind Mothers Winter Grind and Great Divides Cappuccino Stout.
Bottle.  Perfect balance of roasted malts and roasted beans.  This is the perfect Sunday brunch beer.
Pours a dark black from the bottle with foamy tan head and moderate lacing. Aroma of roasted malt and heavy coffee. Taste is serious dark roast coffee, thats about it. Really good if you like coffee.

Not too bad of a beer. There wasn't enough body for me in this, and mine was super carbonated. However, the aroma of coffee and chocolate were very prevalent, and on the plate you get the same. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Got 12 oz. bottle in a trade with Queenholly. Thanks so much! As soon as I poured this stout into an English pint, I could smell rich organic coffee grinds. The aroma makes me think I could drink this for breakfast. Flavor has light sweetness, coffee, roasted grain and cocoa powder. Ends on the bitter side with some strong coffee notes. The body is slightly thin but it doesnt matter. The coffee lingers on well after the sip. Mildy smooth texture with light carbonation.This is a nicely executed coffee stout. You got to be a coffee lover to really appreciate this stout.

S: Coffee notes, brings an acidity with it. Smells smooth....
A: Nice tan head. black body.
T: Hits with a coffee note that is something like a medium roast. A bit of acidity, bit of hops in there as well.
P: CO2 is a little aggressive but overall its pretty smooth. Good flavor development. Acidity cuts though a bit much.

Overall a solid beer. Easy to drink yet full of flavor. Better on tap than from a bottle (which is what this review is from... a bottle).

I shouldnt have had this beer this late in the evening, I might be up all night.  Coffee pervades this beer, obviously, but it doesnt completely over power the beer or the drinker.  Pours opaque black with a thin mocha head and a burst of sweet latte scent.  The coffee grounds hit immediately upon the first sip but mellow out quickly to a roasty, creamy, chocolatey back end that blends fantastically in the mouth.  Its not a heavy mouthfeel either so drinking it is very easy.  For a coffee specific beer, this one is at the top of the list.

Pours deep brown/black. Nice big kahki head on this one. Spicey coffee wafts off the top like my morning stop for caffeine. Hints of bitter cocoa. Lacing present as the head recedes. Very nice all coffee flavor. Wow this is great. Almost like a cold cup of Joe here. Light to medium mouthfeel with low to medium carbonation. Right on what it should be. Very nice. Could drink this all night. Must pair this with food sometime.
Deep brown with a medium, caramel colored head. Earthy, caramel, coffee and a little smokiness. Flavor is balanced with moderate sweetness and bitterness. Body is heavier, with a foamy carbonation.

Pours dark black with a big brown head that looks good and has good lacing.  Aroma is coffee, coffee, coffee, and a little malt.  Taste is almost entirely coffee, with some malty sweetness.  I dont like coffee, and while I can appreciate the taste in a balanced beer, this one was too far down the coffee spectrum for me to seek out more.  However, I had no trouble getting through the bottle, the aftertaste was much more pleasant, and its a 7.5% beer with absolutely zero hint of alcohol... so thats always a plus.

Pours nearly black with a dark tan head.
Nice strong coffee roast, malt aroma....smoke.
Taste is creamy, dark bitter chocolate and good coffee.
Wonderfully heavy body, big flavours...
Excellent.

Nice coffee notes. Not overly bitter or sweet. Nice head as well. Roasty aroma with a caramel finish. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Appearance: silky black pour with a giant, rich, creamy dark tan head slowly shrinking to a thin cap/fat collar.   Aroma: strong notes of roast, with coffee and bitter chocolate most prominent.   Taste: blast of acidic coffee up front, then bitter melted bakers chocolate.   Finish: dry, bittersweet, with fading notes of burnt toast, espresso, dark chocolate, and licorice.   Notes: 	I really wanted to love this, but the coffees acidity was too strong, and detracted from the delicious stout undertones.  Would have loved this had the coffee been dialed back even 20 percent.
This is a great stout! There is a great coffee flavor with a malty bitterness. If you are a coffee drinker you will love this beer!
Bottle. Pours dark black with a ring of tan head. Aroma is coffee, malts and chocolate. Flavor is a blast of coffee followed by malts, chocolate and vanilla. Overall a nice beer.

Roasted malt smell. Looks amazing - big tan foam atop a dark brown to black brew. The taste is not terribly complex, with burnt coffee flavours the biggies. A decent stout, but probably not up to the Bells double cream stout.

Bottle pour, and the bottle isnt particularly young either - black with a very thin tan head that dissipates very fast.  Aroma - sweet malt, sweet chocolate, roasted coffee - altogether good!  Flavor is almost chocolate first, then coffee, roasted, sweet malt, and an underlying milk presence - this is a good coffee stout.  Palate is medium and appropriate for the beer.  Not surprised, but this is a nice effort for an everyday coffee stout.

Draft to taster at Bells. Looks good; cola black with light beige lacing. Smells solid; bitter coffee and malt. Tastes like it smells with an average mouthfeel. A little more bitter than I prefer, but good nonetheless.
Pours a dark black with light brown head, strong aromas of coffee with great coffee flavor with hints of sweet chocolate, very good stout

Great aroma of, what else, coffee! Nice thick head on this one. Beautiful black body too. Taste is nothing more than amazing. Great coffee bean flavor with a hint of alcohol. Palate is long and smooth. The lacing on the glass lets you know where your last drink was. One of the best javas out there.
Great coffee beer, look foward to this every winter, awesome aroma, thick frothy head, good retention but has become pricey.

Great coffee stout. Good dark, dark pour with a espresso looking head.  Good lacing.  Good coffee aroma and taste.  Good smooth feel in the mouth and not a long lasting chocolate/ coffee note. Great brew by Bells brewery. Always impressed!

Pours pure black with a small light brown head.  Aroma is of malts, some big time roastiness, coffee, and dark chocolate.  Full bodied.  Flavors in this bad boy are: malts, coffee, big roasty/toasty flavor, nuttyness, and chocolate.  Leaves a roasty coffee finish.  Similar to Founders Breakfast Stout.  Superb.

Pours almost black with a thick tan head. The aroma of coffee and dark roasted malts smack you in the face even before you pour this stout.  The taste is exactly as the aroma would suggest, lots of coffee, along with plenty of chocolate and dark roasted malts. One of my favorite beers but if you are not fond of beers with plenty of coffee stay away from this one. This is the double espresso of coffee stouts.
poured black with a smaller head than expected. aroma was chocolate and e coffee. it just got better and better as I sipped on it and it warmed a bit. just a very, very good stout
Pours black with brown head. Nose of coffee, java. Pleasant and mild aroma, coffee, some chocolate. Wish it was a bit sweeter, but otherwise stellar.

Really good, better to sip slowly. Stout appearance: deep brown to black, classic stout head. Aroma is strong, bitter coffee/espresso, roasted. Flavor is the same but stronger, almost burnt. Not for everyone but I like it. More flavor as it warms.

Drank in a bottle. Intense dark coffee aroma. The flavor definitely has hint of jalapeño and a bit smokey. This one is unique. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Poured into signature glass. Dark Brown in appearance, abrupt coffee aroma and appearance. Great beer and highly recommended!!

12oz bottle from Kentucky. Dark brown almost black with a light tan head. Aroma of rich mocha, chocolate and some sweet caramel. Flavor is lots of coffee with a light acidity, a healthy dose of chocolate with bitter roast. Medium body with a smooth mouth feel. Really nice coffee stout.

Superb coffee stout. Malty, thick, and dark, with a strong coffee note throughout. No hops to speak of -- clearly not West Coast inspired. Recommended!

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Great tasting coffee stout. Well balanced and a nice finish. Better on tap at Bells. 


---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

12 ounce bottle into signature pint glass, bottled on 9/10/2012.  Pours lightly hazy extremely dark brown color with a nice 1-2 finger dense tan head with great retention, that reduces to a nice cap that lingers.  Nice spotty soapy lacing clings down the glass.  Aromas of big roasted coffee beans, espresso, dark chocolate, roasted malt, light char, caramel, and light herbal.  Damn nice aromas with big coffee presence and nice background malt balance.  Taste of big roasted coffee, dark chocolate, espresso, roasted malt, light char, toffee, caramel, and light herbal hops.  Light coffee bitterness on the finish; with lingering notes of coffee, dark chocolate, roasted malt, light char, caramel, and herbal on the finish for a good bit.  Nice flavor balance and complexity with plenty of coffee flavor; very nice malt/bitterness balance; zero cloying flavors noticed after the finish.  Medium carbonation and body; with a creamy and slick mouthfeel that is very nice.  Alcohol is very well hidden with only a slight warming noticed after the finish.  Overall this is an excellent coffee stout!  Plenty of coffee flavor with nice malt flavor balance; very smooth to drink.  Really enjoyable offering.

Bottle. Pours near black with a puffy tan head. Aroma is coffee, but with a definite green pepper tinge. Taste is the same but with some chocolately sweetness. But yeah, definite green pepper coffee taste that kind of overshadows the actual coffee taste.

Bottle at Kaseys Tavern, Chicago - 03/11/12.
Pitch black with a thin dirty coffee coloured head that soon clears to the edge.
Big Java coffee nose, roast malts, touch of bitter dark chocolate, mineral tones.
Big Java coffee kick hits you straight away in the taste, this is followed up by bitter roast malt, very dark chocolate and molasses.
Fuller end of medium bodied with fine carbonation leading to a roasty coffee finish.
Great coffee stout!
user_location: Hazlemere, the lower Xhitlerns, Buckinghamshire, ENGLAND

text: [email protected]/* <![CDATA[ */!function(t,e,r,n,c,a,p){try{t=document.currentScript||function(){for(t=document.getElementsByTagName('script'),e=t.length;e--;)if(t[e].getAttribute('data-cfhash'))return t[e]}();if(t&&(c=t.previousSibling)){p=t.parentNode;if(a=c.getAttribute('data-cfemail')){for(e='',r='0x'+a.substr(0,2)|0,n=2;a.length-n;n+=2)e+='%'+('0'+('0x'+a.substr(n,2)^r).toString(16)).slice(-2);p.replaceChild(document.createTextNode(decodeURIComponent(e)),c)}p.removeChild(t)}}catch(u){}}()/* ]]> */ Twist, Stockholm. Deep reddish brown colour with a mediumsized beige head, that leaves some lace. Aroma is mild roasted malts, coffee, some slight nutty notes as well as chocolate and mild ripe fruits. Flavour is chocolate, roasted malts, some coffee and toffee with quite a big bitterness kicking in in the finish.

From tap. Black liquid, small mocha head. Aroma is roasted coffee, ashy, burnt, roasted. Taste is very coffee forward, roasted malts, ashy, burnt, smooth.Too much carbonation in this beer for my liking though.

Bottle. Slightly bitter and herbal coffee aroma, gets more harmonic later. Black, brown head. Big coffee roast and dark chocolate notes, demerra sugar. Light herbal in the back. Fullbodied, dry on the palate. Nice bitter chocolate aftertaste.

Bottle. Poured straight black with a nice tan head. Coffee flavor is strong and right out front, followed by a more traditional stout flavor with some chocolate. Great roasted malt flavor to balance everything out.

12 ounce bottle, pours black, aromas of coffee, light roast, and some earth.  Flavors follow suit, lots of coffee in the flavor, some light tabacco in the aftertaste, a solid stout that I can enjoy any day of the week.

UPDATED: JAN 31, 2013 Black as night with one finger tan head Aroma of black coffee, tobacco and roasted grains. Taste is all coffee with a great heavy mouthfeel. Just enough carbonation to tease you!

Poured from a 12 oz bottle shared at home.  Pours a very dark brown, almost black with a thin tan head.  Strong coffee nose.  Coffee, tobacco and bitter hops.  Not sure it all works well together, but still a nice stout.
Quickly disappearing head. Deep Black. Wonderful aroma , coffee and chocolate, roasty. Full creamy body. Tastes just like it smells.  Delicious

The great beer was courtesy of Strykzone.  Poured a dark garnet when held up to the light but looks otherwise black. Tan head with good lacing rings. Nose is roasted malts with chocolate coffee, and dark fruit. Bold body, and smooth creamy mouthfeel. Flavor is rich and chocolate and coffee mix well and in good balance. The finish is bittersweet. Very tasty beer. Thanks Dave for this winner. .

Aroma: massive dose of coffee, also some chocolate and roast malt.  Pours pitch black, tan head with decent retention, thin streaks of lacing.  Big coffee flavor, roasty and somewhat bitter, lots of chocolate, some caramel.  Medium body and carbonation.  Perfect balance, excellent coffee flavor, killer brew.

UPDATED: NOV 6, 2012 Dark appearance with decent head and absolutely splendid lacing sticking everywhere on the glass.  Aroma - pure, roasty, complex coffee.  What a scent.  Flavor - rich, bitter, strong, yet not over-bodied.  What a presence!  Lingering flavors!  This isnt an impy?  Holy moly!  One to savor for sure.  Nearly on par with Founders Breakfast Stout overall, but not quite as memorable on each note.  NOVEMBER 6 RERATE: Compared next to Kalamazoo.  Kalamazoo had a better head and better lacing.  Aroma - Java Stout wins.  Great coffee aromatics.  Kalamazoo has some licorice, roast malts, and dark chocolate, but I am biased toward coffee aromas, so there.  Taste - Java Stout is just so coffee-licious.  The ABV is wonderfully hidden - Kalamazoo actually tastes boozier to me.  Also, the body in Java Stout is preferable - it feels less heavy than Kalamazoo.  Ill downrate a little on appearance/overall, but that is it.  Still prefer it to the Kalamazoo.
Pours jet black. Bitter, chocolate, vanilla coffee flavor. Finishes nicely with burnt dark chocolate and espresso. Light for a stout but doesnt lack in flavor.

Year old bottle. Dark brown, tan head that fades away. Nose is coffee that has been in the pot all day, chocolate, roasted malts. Taste is slightly stale coffee, coffee beans, and mellow roasted malts. Drinks very smooth. Will probably be adjusting my rating once I try this fresh--the coffee character was definitely diminished. At any rate I could tell that this is a pretty special brew when fresh.

UPDATED: JAN 30, 2017 The aroma is fantastic. Nice mix of chocolate, vanilla, and coffee. Appearance is jet black, two-finger light brown head. The taste is very coffee-forward, light flavors of chocolate and vanilla. The mouthfeel is also very good, a well-balanced creaminess and velvety mouthfeel. Overall, this is exactly what I look for when I drink not only a stout, but a beer itself. This is wonderful.
12oz bottle->tulip.  Deep brown with dark tan head.  Very pleasant chocolate and coffee aroma.  Full flavor of burnt coffee. Decent stout.

Poured from a slightly chilled 12 ounce bottle into a tulip glass. Pours a very dark brown with a large head of dark grey to brown foam erupting steadily through the life of the beer. The aroma is over the top coffee with heavy notes of espresso richness and bittering. Taste is the rich espresso again making the beer come across as a nice cup of coffee that has been chilled wich some extra carbonation. I really enjoyed this beer and will definitely be working on my six pack pretty hard over the coming cool months.

12oz bottle - pours opaque dark brown with two fingers of tan head and decent lacing. Nose is roasted dark chocolate and coffee. Flavor adds little more. Taste is somewhat sweet and bitter on the dry finish. Creamy mouthfeel. Solid.

Bottle brought back from Chicago. Nice simple coffee stout, extremely well balanced. Love that bells makes such a good non-imperial coffee stout.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

UPDATED: NOV 10, 2012 Tap at eccentric.

S: Like sniffing a chilled cup of heavily dark roasted coffee, slight chocolate bitterness
A: Just like Kalamazoo with a slightly darker head
T: Cold carbonated coffee.. this is just too much for me, and I am a heavy coffee drinker
P: Medium bodied, lingers too long considering the taste
O: I respect this beer, but it is not for me

Bottle courtesy of Andy at the apt. Thanks. Poured into tulip; black body, light brown/tan head, nothing shocking. Aroma is rich with cocoa/dark chocolate. Flavor is very light with somen notes of chocolate and coffee but the standout characteristic was a bitter fruity flavor that I did not expect. Possibly cherry. Definitely more than decent, but was expecting more java.
Draft. Black pour with brown head. Aroma is of roasted coffee and sweet malt. Ive had most that are coffee and roasted flavored, a few have had some off pepper.

Bottle from trade with StFun. Pours black with a moderate head. Aroma is not noteworthy, surprisingly. Flavor is full, with balance of roasted and sweet malt and an underlying hint of coffee. Keeps the coffee under control, which I like. Finishes with lingering roasted bitterness. Pretty nice stout.

No light gets through it.  Its pitch black, yet not extraordinarily heavy in body.  Theres excellent foam retention and a lot of coffee aroma.  Cherries, roasted malts, and coffee are in the taste, and the coffee side doesnt overwhelm the other components.  I enjoyed the coffee presence thats balanced with complementary cherry/malt tastes.

Bottle shared by matt9875. Thanks Matt!

This coffee stout appears dark brown in color, with a thin, eighth inch layer of beige head. The aroma is primarily of coffee, with a bit of roasted malt lingering behind. This is a decent brew, but not as full-flavored as I would prefer. The coffee and roasted malt are certainly there, but could be fresher, zestier, more aromatic, flavorful. The feel is medium bodied with adequate carbonation. This was an OK beer, but not among the elite coffee stouts.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 12-31-2010

12 ounce bottle, poured into tulip glass.  Smells like coffee and chocolate.  Pours deep black with a small creamy head. Flavor is coffee, maybe some tobacco, and chocolate.  Very good if you like coffee flavors in beer.

UPDATED: OCT 14, 2012 If you like coffee this ones for you.  This is a coffee bomb bigger than any other java stout Ive had.  Not for me, but I am sure some love this.  Massive coffee nose and flavor.  Not sweet but no coffee bitterness.  Well balanced but just too much.

Rerate-bottle with about 6 more months on it.  Coffee is a bit more balanced.   Coffee smells older like a pot left on the burner too long thats gone cold.
On tap pours dark tan to black. Rich coffee and dark chocolate taste. Fairly creamy texture.

@ Akkurat: doften ganska stor av kall kaffesump. Smaken ungefär den samma. Fina rostade toner men kanske något enformig. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle. Pours deep black with a medium brown creamy head with good lacing. Aroma is strong coffee, bitter chocolate and tobacco. Flavor is tobacco and coffee dominated, with notes of grass in the quite bitter finish. An interesting brew, but too much tobacco for my taste

Bottled on 9/14/11, so....its basically a ten month old coffee stout. 12 Oz bottle poured into a clear plastic hotel cup. Dark black body with an ugly greyish mocha head. Solid lacing and retention. Smell is roasted malt and black coffee. Taste is roasted malts, light salty smoke and smooth coffee. Its not a dark roast, or an espresso. Its just a basic, run of the mill black coffee. Very light bitterness, finishes cleanly with lingering coffee notes. Its simplistic, but very effective. Mouthfeel is silky and smooth. Even aged, this beer has a solid coffee presence. Damn tasty!
Bottle at craft ale house. Pours black with a small tan head. Aroma is full of coffee obviously but stronger than expected. Taste is full of coffee And a little bitter on the finish. A fav.

Bottle 12 oz. Pours pitch black with a small bubbly brown head leaving lace. Aroma is nice coffee roasted malts chocolate bready and a bit ashy soy. Flavor is lean pleasant coffee some vanilla tones lots of dark chocolate roasted malts and sweet as well. At the end bitterness comes out with a nice pungent touch. Finishes bitter coffee chocolate and some vanilla tones.

On tap at the brewery.  Pours black with a thin tan head that rings the glass.  Toasty malt and coffee aromas.  Big coffee flavor with roasted gain and chocolate notes.  Creamy mouthfeel with a dry finish.

Pours a pitch black with a small tan head.  Aroma is of strong black coffee, roasted malts, some bakers coco, some licorice, and some dark fruits.  Taste is of earthy-acidic Sumatra coffee, roasted malts, bakers, coco, and licorice.  Has a medium-full body with a creamy, oily mouthfeel and a bitter, semi dry finish.  overall, a good, unique stout that makes good use of coffee.

UPDATED: OCT 6, 2014 Pure black pour into tulip glass. Brown head, eighth inch tall. Acidic and deep coffee aroma. Taste is sweet initially with a lot of coffee flavor. This tastes like cold coffee, in the best possible way. Sweet coffee bean after taste.

UPDATED: AUG 27, 2015 35,5 cl bottle @ home. Rated on 30.09.2011
Aroma has some roasted malt and coffee. Flavour is fulfilled with coffee, but also some dark chocolate and hints of licorice pops up. A bit different coffee beer, maybe because I am not used to Java? Good stuff anyway and almost a 4.0 from me.
A real kick in the teeth!  Nice upfront crisp palate.  Long finish.  Sweet, and with deep rich cocoa and coffee tones.  Light carbonation.

12oz bottle. deep brown in color, appearance is black. thick tan head sits up top. aroma is roasted coffee beans all the way along with some roasted malt and faint chocolate. medium to full bodied. flavor is roasted coffee, toasted malt with some bitter hops on the finish. i do not like coffee 1 bit but i do like this beer..
Black with a brown head. Aroma is sweet, roasted malty, chocolate and heavy coffee. Flavor is quite sweet, light acidic and rather bitter. Dry and roasted moderate bitter finish. 010512
Bottle. Medium head with medium duration. Color is black. Aroma and taste are rich coffee, roast malt, some acidity, chocolate and hops.

Bottle 33cl. very dark brown beer with a nice white head. Smell is coffe many coffee. Taste nice stout but not very heavy blend.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Originally reviewed: 12/14/09. Bottle poured into my pint glass. Pours a very dark brown with some light ruby on the edges. No head at all with an aggressive pour. No lace, obviously. Scents of ground coffee, roasted malts, and slight leather. 

Full-bodied beer here. Slight chewy feel. Moderate amount of carbonation. Flavors of coffee, cocoa, coffee, roasted flavors, and more coffee. This is the most coffee-forward beer Ive ever had. If you are into that sorta thing, this is the beer for you. I liked it.

Bottle, from trade with SecretSanta. It pours a very dark reddish brown body and a dense, finger-thick tan head. The aroma sure is java-ish, with roasted malts and something reminiscent of Islay peat. Loads of coffee in the flavor, with a smoked peat hint in the back. Full-bodied and smooth, finishing with java and roasted malts lasting for a long time. Although not a coffee drinker, this was a beer I really loved. 110930

Pours a black in appearance with a thinner dark beige head.  Aroma is very heavy coffee and roasty.  Creamy and smooth upon drinking, with a bit of carbonation.  Taste is smoky and roasted.  Extremely strong flavor of coffee both immediate and in the aftertaste.  I can find a bit of chocolate as well.  This has everything that I enjoy in a beer.  Given the opportunity, I wont pass this up.

UPDATED: APR 11, 2012 Pitch black in color with a small beige head.  Strong coffee aroma along with chocolate and cream.  Very pleasant. Very smooth coffee and chocolate taste.  Very little bitterness which is nice.  Sweet vanilla finish at the end.  Great coffee stout.
For something named after coffee, this one delivers. The coffee really comes through in both the taste and smell. Its a little heavy for a while, but a great tasting beer.
Bottle. Black colour with a tan head. Aroma is vanilla, smoked, heather, coffee. Flavour is vanilla, smoked, burned, heather, coffee. Full body. Nice beer.

Appearance:  Pours a dark brown with tan head that subsides to a ring.

Aroma:  Medium roast coffee grinds, dark chocolate, sugar.

Taste: Bitter coffee, burnt roasted malt, dark chocolate.

Mouthfeel:  Full bodied , very active spicy bubbles.

Overall:  Pretty solid, and the coffee worked well with the base beer.

Huge coffee aroma leads to a smooth flavor of mocha.  Crisp appearance and great mouthfeel.  Very enjoyable.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

12 ounce bottle from Sicilianos in Grand Rapids, MI.  Clear dark brown with a thin light brown head.  I usually like coffee in the aroma, but this one smells like cheap instant coffee to me.  Taste is mostly just coffee.  May be better than a "6" but hard to tell with that distracting aroma.  Im disappointed with this one.  If you like cold black  coffee this might be the beer for you.

On tap @ the Beer Seller in Indy.
Near black pour with some tan head.  Tons of coffee aroma with some roasted malt.  Big time coffee flavor as well but I expect nothing less from a beer with java in the name.

UPDATED: AUG 27, 2015 355 ml bottle.
Rated on 20101114.
Pitch black color. Aroma of heavenly coffee, roasted malts, chocolate and liquorice. Flavor of roasted malts, coffee and chocolate. Smooth palate, feels quite complex for a lower abv stout. Brilliant.
4426

Date: March 2, 2012 Mode: Bottle Source: TheGuy Description: Opaque black pour with some head.  Aroma was coffee and roasted malt.  Taste is as advertised roasted coffee with a little bit of a dry alcohol finish.  Some carbonation which was not a good thing.  Thanks Chuck!

Pours very dark, almost black with a rich chocolaty head.  Gives off a great coffee/chocolate aroma.  Taste is strong dark coffee and roasted malt notes with slight chocolate at the end.  Medium body with a creamy texture, very carbonated at first with a smooth finish.  Excellent coffee stout, not my favorite but certainly near the top of the list.  Ill be back for more.

From notes.  First reviewed 1/3/2011.  Poured from a 12 oz. bottle into a pint glass.

A very dark mahogany color with bits of ruby appearing where some light can sneak through. A creamy, bubbly coffee color head forms on the pour and demonstrates nice retention. Gobs of lace stick on the glass.

Tons of espresso comes through in the aroma, just an incredibly robust and full aroma. Some sweet molasses, roasted malts, and a bit of chocolate are present as well. 

The beginning of the sip has a soft molasses sweetness to go along with chocolate and roasted malt flavor. Strong espresso opens the eyes and really dominates through the rest of the sip. A light earthy hop presence at the end, but the finish is slightly sweet, mostly bitter, and all coffee. Simple, but enjoyable.

This has a big body and very viscous, and it drinks a bit larger than the 7.5% ABV. Very creamy, with a moderate level of carbonation. A little bit sticky on the lips. 

As a coffee lover, this has a strong appeal for me, and I find it very easy to drink. People who do not enjoy coffee as much will not like this stout.

Bottle poured pint glass.  Aroma is mocha and sweet chocolate.  Taste is immediately coffee.  Black coffee with a hint of chocolate.   Amazing coffee beer wow. Tennessee members sorry you will never have the opportunity to drink.this.amazing craft beer.  But you can always dream.
i get a bit of the coffee notes, but overall its a solid stout. easily one of the best ive had.

Bottle/12oz - Pours a very dark black/brown in color with almost no head and very little carbonation. The small tan head that did appear did produce some minor lacing, however.  Aroma is strong of coffee and a bit of chocolate.  There is also a strong aroma of dark, almost burnt, malts that covers some of the more subtle aromas that might (or not) be present.  Flavor is huge of the coffee with a much smaller amount of chocolate.  The "burnt" flavors also come through quite strongly and I feel that this is a major distraction from what, otherwise, would be a really good coffee stout.  I am a bit disappointed...
12oz bottle.  Pours almost black with a medium tan head.  Roasty aroma with coffee and chocolate.  Strong coffee flavor with a hint of chocolate and roasted malts.

A black beer with a medium tan head that leaves decent lacing.  The aroma and flavor both exhibit coffee but also a strange spiciness, like hot peppers.  I dont know if its just my batch or what, but this is no good, and I generally love Bells.

UPDATED: MAR 2, 2012 Look no further if you are on the hunt for the right coffee/java related stout. Bells is almost always reliable and with this one (along with their Expedition) they have hit a home run in the stout field. I have yet to taste a coffee stout (and there are lots of them) that compare in potent taste to this one. The aroma of java is strong and the drink and aftertaste matches it tenfold, which is not true among most other of this kind. If you like stouts and you like coffee, then this is the one to try.

Pours a dark black color with a tiny brown head. Aroma is pure coffee beans. The taste is coffee but not overly bitter. Its very well balanced, I thought it was going to overwhelm me after smelling it but its just right. Slightly sweet, slightly bitter, all coffee. Really good.

Bottle. Pours an opaque black color with a tan head. Aroma is coffee all the way, I also get some dark chocolate, burnt notes, roasted and toasted malt. Flavor follows the nose with lots of coffee, some roasted and toasted malt, burnt notes, some almost soy sauce flavors from the bitterness, along with dark chocolate and dark caramel. The body is medium with a creamy mouth feel. Overall a really good coffee Stout!

Looks delicious in a big bells tulip. Smells roasty and suggests a fairly dry beer. Mouthfeel is luscious and creamy, pretty much ideal for a coffee stout. Tasting confirms that this beer is pretty dry, flavors of bakers chocolate, dark roasted coffee, finishes satisfyingly dry and bitter. Overall a pretty austere coffee stout worthy of the Bells mantle.

Pours black with a brown head and strong aroma of coffee beans. A lot of flavor in this brew, heavy on coffee, mocha, and chocolate while sweet with a slightly bitter finish. Loads of coffee flavor in this brew, very nice.

Pours dark black with a nice coffee colored head. Aroma smells like a double shot of espresso. Taste is nothing but flavor. Strong coffee and chocolate flavors. Finish is sweet and lastings. If you do not like " joe " stay away otherwise do not miss this stout. Quaff Score ( drinkability with hearty enjoyment ) 8 / 10

This roasty beast pours black with a nice head.  Rich aromas of whole roasted coffee beans and a little chocolate malt greet the nose.  Medium body smooth roasty malt tastes like dark chocolate and finishes with a lovely lingering of fresh coffee.  This is one of the best coffee stouts Ive had.
TAP. Coffee, chocolate, and banana on the nose. It tastes like good, strong, black coffee.
pours a viscous black. Smells like coffee beans. A bit of a roasty tone with a medi thick body. Lots of coffee all the way. Almost an espresso after taste. Great brew.
From a bottle poured a dark brown color with a fair amount of head.  Strong toasted malty flavor with a lingering aftertaste.

UPDATED: NOV 30, 2014 12oz bottle, bottled 9/22/11. Pitch black color, thin medium-brown head that fades to minimal. Super-awesome coffee aroma. I love it. I had this and the Troegs Javahead back-to-back last night, and I definitely prefer this (albeit by a small margin). Theyre both totally different animals, however, and both great brews. Taylor tasted it, and she described it as a "punch in the face" (she preferred the Javahead). Yeah, its a punch in the face, but thats what I want from a java stout. This delivers, call me enchanted. Taste is nice and roasty, light bitter. Body really stands out from the Javahead, this is much heavier and thicker with a less pronounced light and crisp carbonation, definitely very big and chewy. A great brew. 8/4/7/4/16Update rate, 11/30/14: 12oz bottle. Holy crap, I forgot how good this was. I always saw FBS as the king of coffee stouts, but this a very strong competitor to that title. Unbelievably nice coffee flavor, more coffee than what you find in FBS from what I remember. Medium plus body, with a smooth, crisp, lighter carbonation, good chewiness, very light slick finish. Moderate to bigger bitter taste, moderate sweet. Just wonderful. I love coffee flavor, and this delivers it. Scores unchanged.
Wow.  Nutty coffee combined with Bells delicious stout, this beer will awaken all your senses.

Pours dark as night with a decent tan head.  Nose is coffee, nutty, coffee, dry leaves and coffee.  The coffee isnt your run of the mill coffee smell though, it is strong has characteristics Ive noted in some Kopi coffees.  Flavor is great balance of sweet, salt and bitter although the coffee and hops packs a pretty bitter aftertaste.  Sits on the palate quite a while, very sharp with a medium to full body.  This beer is one of the better coffee stouts Ive had!
UPDATED: FEB 13, 2012 12 oz bottle pours black with a tan head.  Aroma is basically coffee and a hint of sweet chocolate.  Coffee is a major component of the taste.  Great beer
This stout actually tastes like strong black coffee. Id rather have one of these in the morning instead. Awesome beer!

A - pours dark brown with two finger tan head. No  lacing.  

S - burned malts, dark and milk chocolate and smoke. 

M - medium body. Very creamy feel. Lightly syrupy. 

T - burned malts and toasted nuts on the nose. Strong notes of coffee and coffee grounds with lightly metallic smoke on the palate. Notes of blackened malts ending with hints of smoke and bitters. 

O - good drinkable coffee stout.  The coffee is great 

7-

Sweet malty caramel aroma. Pours a dark black with little to no head.  Very malty, coffee taste with a choclaty caramel hint.  Not overpoweringly strong.   One of the top coffee stouts i have encountered.
Great beer. Have not tried anything by Bells brewery but I will try more now. So malty and delicious, kinda wish I had another.

Pours jet black. Aroma and flavor both full of chocolate and coffee
 Lovely.

Super dark, espresso head.  Heavy mouth feel.  Thick and creamy.  Lots of coffee aroma and flavor.  Slight hint of milk that mellows out the bitterness of the coffee.  Some chocolate in there too.  Very sweet with a nice bitter finish.  Super drinkable.  This stuff is really good.

12 oz. bottle at Lunar Brewing Co., viscously poured to a Czech-pils glass with a black/brown color, creamy, brownish tan froth to the head, and curtainy/wavey cling to the lacing. The nose was strong roast, expressive bakers chocolate & espresso, and some burnt qualities. The flavor was similar, with hefty malt, just a hint of sweetness, medium+, lingering hop bitterness, lightly syrupy texture, medium to full body, subtle but mostly hidden alcohol, and a dry & bitter finish. Bold and flavorful, with the wintery day appeal to duplicate the experience.

Bottle. 3 months old. black with mahogany edges good initial tan head and lacing with heavy sugar beading. Smells strongly of fresh brewed dark and sweetended coffee. Also of malts.  Taste is moderately sweet with dark chocolate and coffee. Feels soft and smooth. Ends very coffee and chocolate nib bitter.  Not balanced or nuanced but the flavors are so distinct.  Top notch!

Pours a nice black with a fair cocoa head.  Aroma is of coffee and coffee (and some roasted malts).  An awesome coffee stout.  Doesnt have too much else going on, some roasted malts, maybe a little hops at the end, but most of the bitterness if from the coffee.  Great finish and after taste.

Now thats a freakin coffee stout.  Eh, pretty much tastes like strong dark coffee.  Hops dont come through that different than bitter coffee, so Im not sure which is which, but it works well.  If you like a coffee stout, go get it!
Very dark. Mmm.... Smells good. coffee really comes out. Bitter too! Yay!  A new find.

This was selected at the Caboose in Ashland for tasting.  I am not a coffee drinker so this stout was too much coffee for me.  I like some coffee in the stout but this product from Bells is too strong.  The coffee aroma is quickly noticed  The stout poured an ink black with no head retention.  Very soft  carbonation and a smooth finish.

12 bottle from a Binnys sixer.  Pours black with tan head; nice lacing for a stout.  Heavy coffee nose and taste....excellent.  Strong chocolate / malty taste.  This is a really tasty brew...glad I have more stored away.
On tap at Luce. Pours almost black with reddish highlights. Head dissolved rapidly. Strong coffee aroma, toasted... Medium carbonation, full body. Long bitter aftertaste. A very good stout!
Very dark brown in the glass with a tan head. Nice roasted coffee aroma. Good balance. Really great stout.
Expensive but very smooth. Just the right amount of coffee blended within.  Medium to heavy beer with creamy texture.  I highly recommend this beer.

Bottle courtesy Jason - thanks!  Nice light brown head that laces its way down the glass.  Aroma is clean and light coffee over roasted malt/oat.  Taste is coffee bitterness up front, soft chocolate, some roasted malt character, bitter hops, and a touch of malt sweetness on the end.  Easy drinking and enjoyable stout.
UPDATED: FEB 23, 2013 Pours black. Strong coffee. A little thin for my liking. Very little carbonation. Solid, but not my favorite coffee stout.
Tap @ Bells. Black appearance with a brown head. Roasty coffee, Very roasty, dark coffee grounds, rich chocolate malty, espresso flavor. Pretty nice brew.

Refrigerated bottle poured into a glass.  Pours coal black with very small light brown head.  Little lacing, heavy body, and medium carbonation, and coffee aroma.  Taste is roasted malt, lots of coffee, some espresso, and a hint of hops in the finish.  A little hard to drink.
Ok beer.  Dark black with little head retention.  Smell is coffee and burnt.  Taste is bitter and burnt.

Video review at: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=jdsdWkfPR4U

Appearance: Jet black + red transparencies skimming bottom, 1-finger head, above average lacing

Smell: Used coffee grounds, toasted marshmallow, raw cinnamon, dirt, limestone, spruce, tiny hint of mint

Taste: Full body, used coffee grounds,, toasted marshmallow, roasted carmel malts, black licorice, raisin, toothpaste mint layers, hint of espresso + milk chocolate + spruce, brownie fudge residual, smooth finish, balanced, mild carbonation

Pairings: Digestive w/ tiramisu

Definitely tastes like a stout had sex with a coffee. Very dark coffee is present midway in and at the finish. Start of the sip is sweet and chocolaty. Very interesting. Could pair with anything you would normally pair coffee with...like breakfast (still not better than Founders Breakfast Stout IMHO).

12oz bottle from John Browns poured into a shaker. Pours black with a small bit of dark tan head. Aroma of coffee and coffee with a little bit of caramel. Taste is medium bitter with strong coffee notes. Full bodied with a thick texture. Lively carbonation and a very long, very bitter finish. Overall, very good. I would drink this again any day.

Strong coffee aroma, definitely shows up in the taste, but not overpowering.  Pours black with a dark creamy head.  Nice, thick mouth feel with a smooth finish.  Usually not a huge fan of the coffee beers, but this one is balanced very well

UPDATED: SEP 4, 2012 Great stout. If you like coffee, you will like this! Powerful espresso smell and no hops. A touch of raisin, maybe. It is dark.... Really Dark! appetizing brown head tho it lasted far too short. The taste is a bitter espresso, and bakers chocolate - I sense a hint of dark dried fruit in there as well that is more present on the palate than the initial taste. Maybe a touch thin. Bitter going down in a great way. Carbonated subtley. I prefer a dry stout to stout; this however is an exception. Has some characteristics of Guinness FES but far less sweet. The taste sticks with you

Deep dark black/brown with a good sized tan head.  Big wallop of dark coffee on the nose.  The taste may biggest punch of roasted dark coffee/expresso Ive had to date.  There is a subtle burnt quality that is actually appealing.  Certainly some chocolate as well.  There is a good bit of bitterness, but it still is a smooth sipper.  Very nice.

Dark brown with tan head.  Big time coffee.  Green, earthy coffee aroma, some ash, light malt sweetness.  Nutty/earthy coffee with mildest of acidity, roasted malt, toffee.  Trailing coffee, light acidity.  Pretty tasty.

Pours a lovely dark colour,  but not quite the oily blackness I have come to expect. The taste comes across with coffe, and a touch of toffee, with just the right amount of bitterness to justify itself. A bit thin on he palate, but a truly great beer. I hope to have many more of these

This is the best coffee stout I have ever tasted in my life. So good. The roasted coffee flavor in this one is very present. Also has flavors of vanilla and roasted barley in the background. This is another Bells beer that I wish was available year round. Its a bit pricey (around $16 for a 6 pack) but trust me it is so worth it. If you enjoy coffee stouts at all, definitely give this one a try, you wont regret it.

Big Hunt, DC pint ($8): Pours a black color with a brownish head. Aroma is of coffee, coffee, and then some more coffee. Taste is pretty much the same. Body is super nice. Rich and velvety. Coffee flavours are in great proportion to the beer flavors. Some hop bitterness is evinced by the end. Balance was great. Not brutal like Beer Geek, but easy and mellow, yet still complex and flavorful.

12 oz bottle
A: spicy coffee, roasted malts, hint of lactose
T; mocha up front, followed by coffee with cream, nice roasted malt finish
This is a great beer with breakfast or for breakfast. I enjoyed it from start to finish.

Tap at Eccentric Cafe. coffee, smoke, and chocolate aroma. Black with a minimal creamy brown head. Dark roasted coffee, smoked meat, cream, chocolate, ash flavor. Smooth, creamy full body. Really great stout.

On tap at Bells Eccentric Cafe. Poured dark black with brownish head. Aroma is a huge coffee front with roasted malts under. Taste is coffee, coffee and lactose sugar. Some roasted caramel malts. Solid body. Finished medium length with some sweetness, some roast and some dry coffee. Sucker for the coffee perhaps but this was really tasty.

12 oz. bottle. Black pour with a nougaty beige, super thick head. Gigantic mocha coffee, lactic sugars, bakers chocolate, cacao, and a touch of date on the nose. The flavor brings less coffee but a beautiful creamy component with milk and sweeter chocolate notes. However, the coffee returns at the finish. Creamy palate, perfect soft carbonation. Very very nice.
One year old draft. Black, brown head, great lacing. Aroma of mellow dark cocoa, cinnamon, vanilla. Taste is rich coffee, vanilla, chocolate. Medium body. Very nice stuff.

Haha silly label.  Pours a dark black color.  Like nightime.  Not really any head to this beer at all!  Crazyness.  Strong coffee aroma.  Huge burnt aromas.  Roasty roasty.  Taste is pretty roasty as well.  Not as burnt smelling as I thought it might be.  Pretty well balanced actually.  Chocolatey sweetness.

Rich dark brown/black color; Heavy slightly creamy body; Aroma of toasted smoky malt, rich coffee beans, & some chocolate; Flavor of roasted malt, espresso, bittersweet chocolate, hops, and some vanilla; Finish is slightly bitter; Nicely balanced; Overall, one dimensional of course - but a great stout.

Bottle. Pours black with a beige. Aroma of coffee, roasted malt, burnt and vanilla. Flavor is sweet and malty with some caramel, vanilla and coffee. Medium body, average carbonation.  Really nice coffee stout.
pours a deep brown to black with a beige head that fades fast. Nose and taste is of chocolate and coffee. A very solid coffee stout. Worth seeking out.

Serving glass: Poured from bottle into Nonic Imperial Pint.

Appearance: Opaque black with thin tan head and slight lacing.

Aroma: Chocolate covered espresso beans and somewhat sweet roasted malts.

Taste: Starts off more sweet like a creamy coffee liquor before the drier roasted malts kick in with coffee, dark chocolate and a slightly sour mash. Ends somewhat bitter.

Palate: Low to moderate carbonation, somewhat full creamy and smooth body, dry finish.

Overall: Not as quite as good as Founders Breakfast Stout but damn close. Java Stout is maybe a little sweeter and not quite as smooth.

UPDATED: AUG 19, 2011 A great coffee stout. Its really all about the coffee... Pours black with a small tan head. Aroma is coffee - obviously - with a slight touch of vanilla and caramel, maybe a hint of licorice there as well. Taste is pretty much the same, a lot of coffee but with strong hints of cocoa bitterness and a well-balanced sweetness from caramel malts and brown sugar. Body is a bit lighter and not as creamy as your average american imperial stout but far richer than most beers, including most Belgians. A great beer, no doubt about it.

Bottle. @Akkurat. Pours opaque and nearly black with a lasting, beige head. Excellent lacings. Nose of roasted malts, coffee and chocolte notes. Sweet flavour is roasted malts, dark fruits, coffee and chocolate among hoppy notes. Full bodied, soft carbonation and oily texture. An excellent brew.

Bottle at Akkurat.
Rather straight forward coffe stout. Semi heavy taste.
Bottle. This beer is all about coffee. It tastes and smells coffee basically... Its pretty intense. Small notes of vanilla and licorice.

It poured a clear dark brown color with a brown foam. The aroma was of coffee, dark chocolate, roasted malt and light vanilla. The flavor was of coffee, roasted malt and dark chocolate with a smooth lingering coffee finish.

Amazing beer. Pours jet black, with a tan head. Strong aromas of Cuban coffee, and some dark chocolate malts. Taste is extremely heavy on the coffee, brutal, black coffee. Bittersweet malts mixed with dark chocolate, all ending on a very bitter dark coffee note. Very filling, but also extremely interesting. A rich, delicious stout.

Finally tried this one out recently. I held on to it a little two long, as it was a couple months past its prime. However, it didnt seem terribly diminished, as the coffee came right out and got me. Nice thin head on a chocolate brown color, all kinds of coffee with some chocolate. Another good after-dinner beer, and might not be bad with brunch either ;). Smooth and enjoyable.

Couleur noire légèrement brun rouge sur les côtés avec une tête qui se disperse rapidement. Difficile de capter autre chose que le café noir en arôme et difficile de croire quon a affaire à une bière. En entrée de bouche je décèle le chocolat qui se transforme doucement en espresso en fin de bouche. Moins amer quun café mais plus onctueux, leffervescence est très active et ne laisse pas autant darrière gout que je laurais souhaité. Pas damertume ni darôme reliés au houblon. Agréable mais un peu inoffensif.

12oz bottle from Timbo 
Appearance: Pours black with a small tan head and good lacing 
Aroma: Roasted malts and coffee,  dry cocoa and coffee 
Taste: Rich roasted malts, dark fruits, roasted coffee and coffee  
Nice and rich
Aroma is HEAVY coffee grounds and not much else.  Palate is rich and creamy.  Taste is coffee with some roasted character and sweetness.  Too much coffee for my liking, it overtakes the beer.
Great Genuine coffee flavors, roasted coffee, malts, the coffee Is the dominant flavor

Bottle from trade with Savvy1982. Thanks Kyle!! Pours out black with a slight mocha colored head. Aromas of viscous dark chocolate and creamy chocolate milk. Lots of strong coffee and espresso as well. Some toasted oats found in there late. Taste is full on assault of coffee and chocolate. Bakers chocolate and milk chocolate. Some roastyness deep under the coffee and chocolate. Smooth silky body with a great bitter finish.

12 oz bottle from Horrocks Farm Market in Lansing, batch #9992. Served in an English pint. Pours dense black with a small tan head. The head fades quickly to a small remnant and leaves a small amount of fine lace. The nose has a huge whack of coffee, along with smoke, roasted malts and a hint of chocolate. The flavour is intensely coffee bitter throughout; it begins slightly sweet but dries out towards the end. The finish is long and roasty coffee bitter. On the palate, it is full in body with a dry texture and soft carbonation. Overall, this is a nice coffee stout. The coffee is a major part of the flavour, not just an accent. Nice, and well worth a try. 2011-05-20

Bottled poured into snifter.  Dark, nearly opaque, black.  Thin tan head that falls away quickly, but resurfaces big-time when swirling for aroma.  Nose is excellent with heavy coffee profile, slight chocolate, slight leather, mild earthy hops.  Oily on the palate, more carbonated than I anticipated.  Coffee lingers throughout the taste with a touch of bittersweet chocolate late.  Quick finish.  Medium bodied, very nice beer.  7.5% booze is hidden nicely.  Not amazing, but solid.

12oz bottle split with mcberko. Pours a thick, black colour with a fine caramel head. Aroma of very dark chocolate, dark roasted coffee, hidden booze. Flavour the same but with a hint of black cherry. Becomes sweeter the more you drink. Medium bodied. Leave a warm sensation on the tongue. Decent.

12 oz. bottle, split with Matts_Property, pours black with a small tan head. Aroma of potent espresso beans with little else. Flavour of slightly burnt / roasted espresso beans, with some roasted malt. Slightly bitter finish. Could use a more dynamic body, but this is solid.

Pours black with a bit of tan head. Strong coffee aroma along with some pepper, chocolate, roasted malt. Also a bit of an herbal aroma that confused me. Full bodied, dry with bitter coffee, espresso. Very solid.

Pours jet black with a milk chocolate head. Strong aroma of coffee with a hint of roasted malt. Tastes strongly of coffee and roasted malt. Has a silky medium body with a good amount of carbonation. Very enjoyable coffee stout.

This was a nice catch. Happily poured into a highball glass, this one isnt as thick as it might look. The head was dark brown, and not much for lacing. Carbonation was light, with a rather full body. The scent was nothing other than pure brewed coffee, more so like espresso with a hint of sweetness too. The malty sweetness keeps this beer very balance against the wave of coffee and dark chocolate notes. The light but generous ABV keeps the palate in check too, with a nice syrupy warm finish. I wouldnt recommend this particular brew for those who hate coffee, but if you do... you have to try this. It may be a little strange at first, but it will grow on you until you love it!

A: The pour is just about black in color with a finger of light brown head.

S: Like you might hope for from a coffee beer, the nose is dominated by coffee aromas.  Quite a strong coffee note with some roasted mlat and a mild toffee malt sweetness underneath.

T: Much the same on the palate.  Lots of great, intense coffee flavors.  A fair amount of roasted malt flavor which gives a mild bitterness.  Not too much of the sweetness from toffee or caramel.

M: Medium in body with a moderate level of carbonation.

O: A solid coffee beer.  Like many beers of this nature, you do have to enjoy the coffee flavor, but if you do, this is a winner.
Had a very strong coffee scent like walking into a coffee shop. Poured black with tall brown head. Had a very strong spicy coffee flavor, seemed stronger than 7.5%.

not sure im a fan of this one. there just somethig about coffee in a beer that i just dont like. aroma was strong. good solid head. Dark as a stout should be. and smooth, but coffee and beer is not for me.
On draft at Union Jacks pours black with average light brown head.  Aroma of roasted malts.  Flavors of coffee (espresso), toffee, and brown sugar.

12 oz bottle. Huge coffee nose-smells delicious.  Taste is full of bitter coffee, with a moderate malty roastiness. This is truly a coffee beer. Body is just a bit thinner than I would like for this style but this is a sumptuous beer.
user_location: Seattle still not near Beersel., Washington, USA

text: 12 oz Bottle.  Appearance is black with beige head that quickly dissipates.  Aroma is heavily coffee with some of the roasted grains coming through.  Taste is also heavy on the coffee, espresso with some chocolate and nuttiness.  Beer is creamy on the palate with a very thick body.  This is a very pleasant stout.

Aroma coffee, espresso, ash, dark chocolate, roasty. Pour black with a beige/tan head. Taste bakers chocolate, coffee, espresso, very bitter, slight creaminess, hazelnut. MF creamy silk full body with very faint carb. Very nice creamy tasting beer and as a coffee and beer lover this strikes a very good balance. Well done.

12oz bottle in a shaker. Pours black with a head that is so dark its almost red.  Aroma strong of coffee, chocolate, roasted malts, and some light hops.  Flavor very strong of the coffee and chocolate.  Thick texture.  A really good stout.

Poured into a snifter, Java Stout gives a rich dark black color with some ruby hints towards the top. Nice rich tan head with a good retention rate. Great lacing. Sweet malty aroma, from which I get cherries. Some slight coffee hints but not overpowering, with a dash of licorice in here as well. Wow! This could be perhaps the best coffee beer I have had yet. The coffee flavors are subtle at first, and then all of a sudden they just take control of the palate. Mouthfeel is very smooth and flavorful. The palate is very complex, yet subtle. The carbonation level is dead on for what this beer needs. Would I drink it again? I just bought a case.

(bottle) dark brown with negligible brown head; aroma of coffee; balanced flavour with strong coffee tone; I dont care for coffee but overall this is one of the better coffee flavoured beers I have tried

Amazingly vibrant aroma of whole cappuccino beans. It smells like a Starbucks. Pours black and viscous with almost no head.  Taste of dark chocolate, coffee, and malty goodness. The taste lunges for hours afterwards. Favorite bells beer so far.

Pours dark black with tan head that remained a trace throughout.  Great lacing.  Aroma is fresh coffee beans, roastyness, earthyness and dark chocolate.  Taste is bittersweet with the sweetness lingering on the finish.  Nice warming on the finish as well.  This is about as solid a stout Ive ever had.

12 oz bottle. Batch 9462.

It pours a dark brown/black with a large creamy/foamy tan head. The head sticks for a good while and leaves a thick layer of lacing.

The smell is coffee with some caramel and a slight hint of chocolate thrown in, not complex but still enjoyable.

The flavor is coffee with a hint of tanginess. I dont really like it, i seem to be getting a lot of misses with coffee beers lately.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 11-14-2010 02:48:56
Deep dark pour. All coffee on the nose, taste is nutty, coffee... surprisingly not overwhelming to the palate though. Finishes nice and balanced with pleasing aftertaste. 12 oz pint glass.
I really like this one!  Nutty coffee nose.  Great taste, perfect balance of roasted coffee, sweetness.  Full palate.  Easy to drink. want more.

2009 12 oz bottle from the brick store cellar.  Pours a dark black color with a tan head.  Aromas of heavy coffee.  Coffee overpowers the beer, with some chocolate and caramel underneath.  Very interesting.

Bottle, from Happy Harrys in Grand Forks, ND. Pours clear black, thin tan head, spotty lacing. Nose is black coffee, big roast, light vanilla. Flavours of hazelnut, black chocolate, reminiscent of DDC Peche Mortel, only lighter. Great stuff!
Pours a very dark brown with a small beige head. Strong coffee notes - very reminiscent of espresso. Also some licorice notes. Bitter and complex, with a strong aroma.

Pours black Sorry with a beige head. Super strong roasted coffee aroma. Smells like my morning. Nice mouth feel . Nice coffee and rasted malt flavour. Chocolate is strong. It is a very nice stout. I like it a lot.
Pours dark brown with a small tan head. The aroma has a tun of coffee. This is like Pèche Mortel light. Fantastic.

Nearly opaque black pour with a thick mocha head. Big coffee aroma with notes of chocolate and coffee. Taste has some coffee and bitter dark roasted malts, but the predominant flavor seems to be a strange fruity ester. Its the first thing I taste and the last thing in the finish. The coffee flavor seems very subtle for something named "Java Stout." Not sure if this is supposed to taste the way it did, but I did not enjoy it at all. Definite drain pour.

Tasted on 2/23/11 on draft at Clark Street Ale House.  Pours deep black with a thick tan head that slowly recedes to thick rocky lace.  The most prominent aroma is very strongly roasted coffee, along with some darkly roasted malt, and some dark berry fruit.  The flavor is berry fruit up front, moving to freshly roasted coffee, and dark malt.  The body is medium with average carbonation and a long coffee finish.

Bottle purchased from Tiffanys in Kalamazoo, Mich., and poured into a pint glass.  Coffee notes are very subtle, much to my disappointment. Also, it tastes metallic.... like tinfoil on my cavity.  All in all, I will probably pass next time.
This is a unique beer havent had to many coffee beers but this seems to be a good example. Reminds me of drinking really good coffee with alcohol in it.

Reviewed from notes.

Pours a vet dark brown with a tan mocha head and a faint bit of lace. Nose consists mostly of coffee and roasted malt with a bit of chocolate. Coffee takes over the flavor win some dy roast. Between the coffee flavor and bitterness, I really like the feel. Not one of the best coffee beers, but a solid offering.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 10-13-2010

This brew pours black with a thin coffee-colored head. Aroma is pretty earthly and smoky with some coffee and brown sugar notes thrown in. Taste is sweet at first (cream and sugar) and then transitions into a bitter stout finish. Light to medium bodied and great for those who like coffee.
Almost too dark to distinguish color, bit mahogany seems about right. Average head, smells of GOOD coffee! Tastes of GOOD coffee! Absolutely delicious.

[12oz bottle courtesy of Bullit @ cgarvieuk tasting] As youd expect from a coffee stout, pours black with a tan head. Quite a smoky aroma, mingling with the coffee reminded me a big of cigarettes. On the palate lots of coffee, a touch of dark chocolate and more cigs. Despite this, it was actually really good and very drinkable. Good warming finish, too [28012010]

Bottle. Pours a dark mahogany, thinner tan head.  Loads of coffee in the aroma with espresso coming through, but with some slight roastedness and sweetness.  Caramel is light, but coffee comes on strong in the flavor with bitter roasted malt that carries it all really well.  Thinner to medium body with subtler carbonation.  Great drinking, and a coffee bomb but not over the top.

Bottled @ tasting cgarvieuk. Great looking black colour, medium dark tan head. Aroma is deep roasted malts, coffee and little ash. Flavour is roasted malts, coffee, coffee cream and ash. Slightly sweet and bitter finish. Very drinkable.

Pours black with a medium tan head. Aroma is lots of coffee with some sweet notes. Flavor is rich black coffee with some sweet, roasted malt. Medium to full bodied with decent carbonation. Definitely a lot of coffee in this brew. Very tasty.

UPDATED: JUN 14, 2015 14 June 2015, bottle. black. nose is light coffee and dark malt. med body and mildly fizzy. coffee, some chili, burnt malt. nice. coffee isnt very prominent. could do with at least a tad more on the nose and in the taste. 

(Original rating - 747315 = 3.6) Jan 29, 2011. Dark black w/ thick dark tan head
nose is cold, wet espresso grounds and cold, wet, stubbed out cigarettes
med/full body
faintly sweet but mostly dry, dark chocolate malt
really good!

bottle at home ... at Home tasting ... 280111 ... deep black ... thin tan head ... light ash ... woody dark roast nose ... deep dark malts ... light vanilla ... big toffee roast ... again hint of ash ... but very nice

Bottle pours medium-thick almost black with one finger tan head.  Very nice coffee aroma.  Taste strongly coffee, everything else secondary but also with some roast and chocolate.  medium finish of roast.  Thick palate without being syrupy.  Alcohol disguised.

I like coffee stouts but this one doesnt have much except the coffee.  Would be helped by a better balance.

Bottle. 12 oz. Pours a deep, dark, insidious black with a bold, amber head, which recedes into a slight lace across the surface. Aroma of pure, fresh coffee beans, dark chocolate, bitter hops, dry malts, wheat, roast and hints of marshmallow. Full, but not overwhelming, body. Sturdy, insanely tart and bitter palate. Finishes with a slow, meandering, mellow warming in the throat and through the belly. Outstanding, excellent stout.
Very strong coffee taste to it, almost couldnt tell that it was a stout.  Very good choice for someone who likes coffee, but I dont, but it was still good anyway.

Review from notes, sampled 1/11/2008
Received this in a trade with Jay23, thanks for the opportunity.

Pours a solid black that no light gets through. Average pour almost overflowed my glass with head. Weve got some carbonation in suspension here. Aroma is overwhelming with coffee. I also pick up some dried fruits and a bit of chocolate. If there was steam coming out of my glass I would think it was a flavored coffee. Taste is more roasted coffee bitterness with some creamy chocolate mixed into the fold. Creamy mouthfeel with a coffee bitterness in the finish. Solid double stout with coffee added. Another great beer from Bells.
Mild coffee aroma with a small head. Flavor is a mild coffee and a mild dark chocolate that are well blended. Full-bodied and very smooth.
Pour is black with a nice tan head, and apparent decent carbonation. Nose is of sweet coffee. Taste is very much the same with a nice roasty taste as well.

12oz bottle poured into pint, great frothy head, aroma of burnt coffee, a bit sweet, taste is nice sweet coffee, not a lot of malty complexity but Im loving the coffee. One of the nicest session stouts Ive tried. Another great brew from Bells.

Deep brown, mahogany, moving to black.  Two finger tan head.  Light but irregular lace.  

Aroma is all coffee.  It smells like a cup of strong, black coffee and only that.  I like strong, black coffee, so Im excited, but the scent alone could turn some people away.

Taste is the same.  This beer is as advertised--coffee all the way.  Rich, strong coffee flavor.  Balanced well on the back end with sweet malts, which keep the coffee flavor from being overwhelmingly dry.  This is a coffee beer in a major way, though.  Bit of a dry finish, especially as it warms.  But overall, there is a balance of faint caramel and toast flavor to tone down the coffee roast.

I love coffee and thats what this beer is.  But it stays safely within drinkable bounds.  But for those who sugar up their coffee in the morning, this stout will be too offensive.

Opaque black, thick bubbly tan head, velvety full body, medium-high carbonation.

Aroma: stale coffee and chocolate malt, with hints of silage and alcohol emerging as it warms.

Taste: bitter cocoa, stale coffee, roast malt, and just a hint of leafy hops.

This is great, except for the coffee. While this is maybe the best coffee beer ive had, i really dont like any of them.
Picked up at the brewpub. Pours dark brown, tan head. Nose is roasted coffee. Taste is pure espresso, dark chocolate, thick body, bitter finish. Nice beer.

Appearance- Pours thick and rich with minimal head. Its color is dark, dark brown, verging on a light black color.

Aroma of coffee, lots and lots of coffee. That really seemed to be the only aroma I could pull out of this. The coffee was just in your face.

The taste was a little to straight-forward for me. Coffee. The typical stout roasted malts and chocolate were very faint. I liked the idea of a coffee stout, but it seems that the coffee is too overpowering.

Great thick mouthfeel with very low carbonation.

Average at best. The coffee just seems to be to overwhelming and after the first one, I had had enough.

12 oz. bottle

Ar:  Huge shot of fresh ground coffee up front.  A bit of 
Ap: Beautiful pour in a 12 oz. snifter at 50F.  Nice light cinnamon head rises to about 1", pillowing just above the top of the glass.  The head has decent retention.  Decent lace.
T: The flavor is much more bitter chocolate than coffee, which is a nice change of pace.  The finish is straight mocha, and the aftertaste is coffee.
P: Nice, creamy body is a bit sticky.

O: Awesome dessert beer.

Pours jet black with a thin brown head. Smells like coffee grounds, leather, dark roasted malt, chocolate cake and the slightest hint of hop. Taste is bitter-sweet chocolate, coffee, roasted malt, a touch of hop and sweet, hot black strap rum. Medium bodied with a fine carbonation and a mid-length bitter-sweet chocolate finish.

A fairly straightforward coffee stout, although its slightly unique in that the coffee isnt really overwhelming and it doesnt just taste like a cold cup of joe.  Distinctly chocolate dominant in the early and mid-palate, the finish is a good strong mocha with appropriate bitterness.  Lacks mostly visually; very dull looking, no head, no lacing.  Its good beer.

Pours dark black with thin caramel colored head.  Aroma has a little resin, heavy coffee and bitter chocolate.  Flavor is malty and bitter sweet.  Palate is thick with an oily texture and flat carbonation.

UPDATED: DEC 16, 2010 On the First Day of Christmas 2010 the Beer Gods gave to me...  this decent stout.  Pours a dark brown color with a caramel colored head.  Has a heavy aroma of coffee with some hints of chocolate and caramel.  Has a sour taste with lots of coffee bitter and malt in the middle and chocolate notes on the finish.
