Not sure if the sour is from the heavy coffee bitters or if this brew has been infected.  I have seen a few other comments about the bitter/sourness of this brew so it may just be the beer.  I think if I was expecting the sour I would really like this, but it has caught me off guard.

Batch 9959 thanks to Secret Santa. Pours with a black pour and a large brown head. Very pretty in the glass. Big fresh, roasty, tropical spicy coffee roast aroma. Pretty awesome. Nutty, minerally, flint, creamer. All these descriptors are on the coffee aspect of the beer (which is everything!). A bit of leather. Big, leathery, roasty, nearly acidic, earthy coffee flavors. Rich roast. Very different than a Kopi roast, but equally pungent and very nice. Medium to low hop bitterness (added bitterness from the roast). Light chocolate and vanilla flavors in the finish. Lingering coffee. Pure coffee beer and very nice, different profile than some of the other pure coffee beers that I have had recently. Very rich with coffee decadence. Full bodied. Not overly sweet (perfect actually). Medium bubbles. Dry and good. I need to brew a coffee stout soon.

Bottle.  Black pour, short tan head.  Rich espresso aroma with a layer of char.  Loads of dry roastiness and espresso on the flavor with rich dark chocolate behind it.  You cant do much better for a coffee stout that comes in a six pack.

Pours black with a light tan head.  A small amount of lace, head dissipates quickly.  Aroma is of roasted malt.  Taste is malty with coffee and dark roasted notes, and a slight hoppiness.  Slightly sweet, roasted malt on the finish.  A wonderful beer that would finish a spicy meal perfectly.

Bottle. home, bought from Cracked Kettle. Celebrating Duffs birthday.

Wow. Great appearance, slightly let down by the lacing but bold, big and opaque jet black. 

Aroma is mind-blowing. One of the best.Surprisingly hoppy; bitter espresso, chocolate and chillies. This is how I want my beers to smell. Damn it. 

Taste is bitter-espresso, some wood, bells keep on giving me wood, chocolate, roasted malts, vanilla, chillies and hot mama source kick back you just want more of.

Damn fine stout with awesome balancing and fine bitterness. Drinkability is shit hot and one to get warm to. I would like to have more of this so I can do some blending with a Mikkeller Black Hole. Just a shame I dont have enough to be able to do this.

Stunning stuff Bells. Kick Out The Jams! 

Thanks to Angelo for turning me to this brewery.

12oz - Had a nice roasted nose, but the small head and watery (rather than oily) appearance wasnt appealing.  The palate was fine, but it seemed flaccid compared to other stouts, even their own Kalamazoo.

Bottle: Pours a nice dark brown/black, as youd expect. Very light beige head on this one - nice lacing, if nothing else. Aromas are of cocoa nibs, coffee beans, and a roasted character as well. Heavy coffee feel on this one - which gives you that bitterness but there is a nice chocolate sweetness at times as well - I say at times because it seems to get lost in the coffee element most often. Roasted coffee beans come through with the cocoa - Its one of the best java brews Ive had, to be certain.

Pours jet black, with no head.  Robust aroma of coffee and chocolate.  Taste is same as aroma but the chocolate is very dark/bitter and coffee is more earthy than expected.  Recommend a higher alcohol content.

Pours dark with small oily brown head.  Aroma of coffee and malt.  Taste was straight forward like aroma.  Everything was good, however there was a spicy taste akin to ginger in the mix that I wasnt a fan of.  (just a hint).  Anyways, aside from that, I enjoyed it.

Pours dark as night, medium mocha head with good retention.  Tons of black coffee on the nose, along with some light chocolate and roast notes.  This is an unabashed coffee stout, and a well-made one, even if Im not a huge fan of purely coffee beers.  Bittersweet coffee starts off and is followed by more bitter and zero sweet, the latter bitter notes definitely more from hopping than from the coffee.  Very slight pepperiness on the finish.  Good beer but I dont like black coffee a whole ton so its not something Id really care to try again.

Had this beer many times and finally getting around to rating it. Has great fresh coffee aroma and black coffee appearance. Probably sweeter than most coffee stouts and my all time 2nd or 3rd favorite coffee beer. Palate is kinda thick and somewhat syrupy and finish more sweet than bitter.
If you like coffee with sugar than try this beer!!

12oz btl thanks to FunkyBrewster. Pours deep and dark with a frothy tan head. A huge coffee aroma. Like taking a whiff of cold coffee. Pretty much all Im getting in the taste as well. Big smooth roasted coffee notes with a bit of bitterness. Overwhelmingly coffe-like but not in a bad way. Nice full bodied mouthfeel to boot.

Very dark pour. One finger brown head with little retention but decent lacing.  Smells like coffee, but like watered down, old coffee. I find it strange that i want to take a sip.  Coffee Coffee Coffee. I really dont taste much more than coffee and alcohol. Not getting any chocolate or maltiness here.  I hope you like coffee if you bought this. If you didnt...abort!
This is the finest chocolate-coffee stout that I have had.  Pours jet black with a big tan head.  Taste is dark chocolate malt and coffee.  Quite a nice beer.

Bottle 12fl.oz. @ home.Clear dark brown black color with a average, frothy, good lacing, mostly lasting, off-white to beige head. Aroma is moderate to heavy malty, strong coffee, dusty coffee, dark roasted malt. Flavor is heavy sweet and bitter with a long duration, coffee, dark chocolate, chocolate bean. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is soft and smooth. [20101018]

pours a deep black with a thick tan head.  Aroma of you guessed it coffee!  Great blend of coffee taste with a hint of nutty chocolate.  Really a great stout blending two of my favorite things.

12 oz. bottle
A nice robust coffee flavor with a smooth finish. This is quiet possibly the best coffee stout on the market.

Wow, this is helping me become more and more of a stout fan.  Pours very, very dark brown/black with a tan head.   Aroma is roasted malt and coffee.  Taste is (I cant believe I can finally pick this up) a bit of dark chocolate followed by a pretty strong coffee taste.  Body is medium-to-heavy and very smooth.  Coffee and a bit of hop bitter aftertaste.  Very tasty and easy to drink.  One of the best stouts Ive had (though I havent had a lot of them yet...more stout reviews to come from the stock in the fridge!).
Thick black beer with an ample tan foamy head.  Strong aroma of coffee and roasty.    Looks like a good stout.  Full bodied and smooth.  Coffee is strong but not overpowering. All around good beer.

UPDATED: DEC 18, 2010 Bottle.

A - Dark mahogany color with a little above average sized, frothy, sticky, creamy, light tan head. Good retention leaving a thin, creamy layer of lace.

S - Very strong roasted coffee/espresso aroma. Some smokey and tobacco aromas as well. Roasted malt and dark, spicy and earthy aroma as well.

T - Also contains a lot of coffee flavors. Both used coffee grounds and strong espresso flavors dominate the flavor. Pick up some strong smoky, tobacco flavors toward the finish of the sip. Some roasted barley provides a background, but for a stout, it is not strong. Burnt flavors show up mid-sip as well. Maybe just a little sweetness, but this is overwhelmed by roasted, bitter, and coffee flavors.

M - Fuller side of medium body with a nice level of carbonation. Incredibly smooth and creamy feel with a nice slickness. Great body and mouthfeel.

D - Decent drinkability, but the strong charred coffee and bitterness gets to be a bit much.

Notes: Definitely a coffee stout. Coffee dominates with not a lot else coming out too strong as it just gets overwhelmed. Went back and forth about how I feel about the taste, deciding that in small doses, its nice, but I dont really want too much. The smokey tobacco flavors are probably what really probably brings this down. The mouthfeel is excellent though. Worth a try, especially if youre a coffee lover.

Bottle poured a clear dark brown with a lingering ring of brown foam. Aromas of coffee, dark chocolate, roasted malt and light vanilla. Palate was medium bodied and smooth. Flavors of coffee, roasted malt and dark chocolate with a smooth lingering coffee finish.
has a nice creamy coffee aroma.  A nice silky body, has a bit of a sweet chocolate taste followed by a bit of a bitter coffee taste, a nice combination.

Bottle  Pours a good black with a decent tan head.  The head is creamy and lasting, and laces very well.  Aroma is sweet and bitter plenty of coffee and hints of chocolate.  Carbonation is good.  the taste is sweet at first then the coffee hits you.  Has a medium body.  Alcohol is hidden well.  Has a thick texture.  Has a decent finish and I like the aftertaste.  Really like coffee beer.

Looks great, smells great, taste like someone dumped their ashtray into the beer!, as well as the morning coffee grounds.

PS
buy the expedition stout, it rocks
Pours a dark, opaque brown/black with moderate brown head.  As expected a coffee elements, roasty, rich aroma with a clean, but mild lingering finish.  I really like this beer.

Bottle. Beautiful black pour, very opaque. Aroma is mostly fresh espresso coffee and brown chocolate, subtle bready notes too. Rich coffee flavors but not too intense. Alcohol is very well hidden too. Soft and creamy palate. Im not a big fan of coffee stouts but this one is really enjoyable without being too light.

Batch 9462. Poured a deep dark black. Nice tan head. Smells good, coffee with hints of chocolate. Thats where the good traits end. This tasted awful! I usually love stouts. I drink cold espresso and coffee. Ive had other Coffee Stouts. This was bitter and putrid. The only beer I ever poured away because I couldnt choke it down. I would be curious to know if this was a bad batch. I did notice one other review which mentioned this batch number and they had the same experience. If so shame on Bells for letting this out of the brewery.

Pours  black with khaki head.  Aroma of roasted malt, coffee, hint of chocolate and hops.  Similar taste, coffee dominates throughout.  Wish I could start off everyday with an expresso shot infused with this brew.

Looks like coffee, smells like coffee, tastes like coffee. Must be coffee or at least Bells Java Stout. Pretty good. Its nice to find a coffee flavored stout that isnt 10 percent plus of alcohol. Flavors are spot on for the catagory. Not too thick or heavy. Just right.
Pours a jet black with a tan head. Aroma is coffee, java, and nuts. Taste is lighter coffee, java, a bit watery. Palate is decent. Light mouthfeel, clamy overall a pretty decent brew

UPDATED: AUG 22, 2011 Trying again, with a bit more of an open mind, not to mention an idea of what to expect. Pours, of course, jet-black with billowy tan head. Nose is hugely roasted coffee, overripe fruit, a bit of sea salt. Taste is still bracingly bitter, but Im really taking my time here...evens out eventually, and the palate gets calmer with a black coffee bitterness bordering on pleasant. A bit salty and pungent. Still not a go-to for me, but better than I initially thought.
Black-brown, thin tan cover.  Burnt coffee aroma, chocolate.  Taste is burnt, roast, coffee, chocolate, bitter roast finish.

On draft at The Eccentric Cafe, pours a very dark brown with a thick tan head, aroma is full of malt, coffee and a nice hint of chocolate.  The flavor is very sweet with a strong kick of coffee to it.  This is one great beer.

Bottle pours deep brown/black with a dense beige head that leaves some lace around the glass.  Aroma is primarily coffee with some underlying chocolate and roasted malt.  Flavor shows the same with sweet molasses to balance the dry bitter roasted finish.

Pours a deep dark brown/black.  Aroma of rich dark chocolate, molasses and coffee.  Flavor is coffee with a dark chocolate to follow and a touch of sweet roasted grain and molasses to finish.  Wow!  This is good.

UPDATED: JAN 25, 2013 Location/Date:Re-rate: Bottle on January 17th, 2013.
Appearance: Pours a dark black opqaue.  
Aroma: Aroma of roast, and coffee of the french roast variety. 
Taste: Light bitterness, tons of coffee.   
Palate:Medium-medium light body.
Summary: A straight coffee stout, which I appreciate instead of the constant imperials that mix in chocolate. Tasty.
Old Summary:A perfect wake up beer!..loved the coffee aroma, nice chocolaty taste.  I want to get this again..along with Expedition stout.

I might have gotten an old bottle or something, (no bottling date listed on the bottle), but this one was just a mess. Pretty much straight coffee ground aroma and flavor with nothing to back it up. It did look pretty though.

UPDATED: AUG 17, 2010 (12oz. bottle).  Pours black with tan head.  Powerful coffee aroma and vegetal (also very dry).  Taste is bitter from the coffee-not much else going on.  Medium bodied with astingent finish.  Ok beer.  This is a coffee stout that has been around for a long time and its hard to compete against the coffee stouts today-it lacks finesse.  Its better than I remember about 10 years ago, but not something I would seek out, especially when I have Kalamazoo stout available.

On tap at HopCat while in town for RBSG.  Pours a ruby tinged brown black with a medium sized beige head.  Spicy jalapeno, coffee, roast, and old grain.  Medium bodied, but a bit empty, light chocolate.  Hints of coffee and a long slow bitterness on the finish.

This octopus ink oozed jet black out of the bottle.  The nose was loaded with expresso and chocolate.  The taste followed suit with big expresso, chocolate, and roasted malt flavors.  Not the best Ive had, but still a good beer.

Pours black, with a relatively thin, moderate brown head.  Head is a bit frothy, but with little in the way of retention--dissipates quickly.  Aroma is absolutely dominated by coffee, with a somewhat sour character.  Some chocolate malts are detectable, but theyre definitely in the background.  Taste is of coffee with a mainly tart, sweet-and-sour character.  Some fruitiness, too--like cherries.  Not much in the way of burnt malts, almost porter-like.  Mouthfeel is a bit on the thin-side, but I wouldnt say watery.  Lively carbonation, but the effervescence is not overpowering.  In sum, this beer is somewhat uncharacteristic of many coffee stouts because of its almost porter-like presentation, but a very fine beer nonetheless.  If youre a coffee lover who is disappointed with that coffee stouts that privilege burnt malts, then give this one a try.  A grower, but I like it a lot.  Bears a lot in common with the Bells Cherry Stout (which I love), but with a coffee kick.  Another fine showing for Bells.

Dark pour with black appearance and a small tan head that leaves lots of lacing. The aroma is loaded with coffee, has some roast, and a hint of coca. The flavor is similar, with a good bitter to sweet balance. Very roasty. Great coffee stout.
Bottle from De Gekraakte Ketel. Completely black with a beige head. Rich roasted coffee aroma. Good coffee and chocolate flavours. Bitter on the balance. Satisfying is the word.

very black. when they say java they mean it.  evident aroma of fresh coffee.  drinkable and bitter.  some cara and roasted malt. just a huge flavor in general. If you see a single or sixer, pick it up.  You will like it.
Caramel ans coffee scents. Completely opaque darkness. Lots of depth with firm coffee flavor with chocolate overtones. Remains light on the tongue.
Bottle. Pours a black color with a small tan head. Has a roasted malty strong coffee aroma. Roasted malty coffee flavor with hints of chocolate. Has a roasted malty coffee and chocolate finish.

Bottle from Cavie in a box from Sprinkle.  Dark pour with a nice tan head.  Aroma is dirty dark coffee, earth, alcohol, and a little chocolate.  Taste is bakers cocoa, dark chocolate, coffee, and yum.
Courtesy of Cavie.  Pours a nice dark color and smells amazing.  Tastes of coffee and heaven.  Definitely worth trying.

Bottle from Sprinkle! Very dark brown color with a lovely tan head. Aroma is a LOVELY warm coffee.  Roasted grounds, some toasted notes, tobacco ash, and happy thoughts. Taste is equally as impressive.  Great coffee, roast and smoke flavor.  Well done and very drinkable.
On Tap.  Pours black with brown notes.  Small tan head, too.  Aroma is mainly coffee.  Taste is a bit coffee.  Very acidic and ashy.  Damn thats a downer.

UPDATED: APR 15, 2011 Bottle thanks to drfabulous. Pours black with tan head. Little retention. Nose is freshly made coffee, hazlenuts, chocolate and toasted malts. Taste is very fresh coffee, coffee beans, chocolate, toasted malts and vanilla. One of the better regular stouts Ive ever had.

Pours opaque black, no question on the color.  No light passes through.  

Nose has a good mixture of chocolate, roasted malt, and espresso aromas.  Espresso quality comes through nicely on the palate as well, even with some of the typical off-flavors that one finds when ordering espressos at places that dont exactly give a perfect pull.

Medium to almost full body and good coffee flavors on the finish.  This is a contemplative beer, one to enjoy, but not necessarily a beer to have 2 or 3 in one sitting.

A: Pours pitch black with a tan head that leaves lacing along the sides of the glass.
S: Espresso and dark chocolate waft from this brew with a malty finish.
T: The taste mimicks the smell, but is more dominated 
P: Well carbonated with a slightly sticky finish.

Pours near-black with almost no head (duh...its a stout). Nose is coffee, coffee, coffee....smells EXACTLY like a cup of good joe. Flavor is pretty spot on for a slightly burned cup of java with a touch of hoppiness. I happen to love coffee so this stuff is right down my alley. The finish is a little on the short side and you could make an argument that this is a one dimensional beer...but screw it....I like it a lot.

The best stout I have ever had. Aroma is overpoweringly coffee, smells almost exactly like a bag of freshly ground french roast beans. Tastes like a thick, creamy coffee with a substantial mouthfeel. You have to try this one.

Batch 9462.  Aggressive and spicy coffee nose, burnt and wet.  Jet black viscous body, creamy tan head, sticky and loiters.  Burnt coffee coupled with simple syrup.  I dont dig this.  The coffee note is scorched into a piercing sweetness with no balance.  Coats the mouth.  Coffee stouts are hit and miss for me and this is quite the miss.

2009 vintage. The beer pours dark brown to black with a tan head. The aroma is a mix of coffee and chocolate. You also get some bitter notes, either from the coffee or the roasted malts. The flavor is heavy on the coffee with some chocolate mixed in. There is some low bitterness in the beer and the coffee lingers in the aftertaste. Medium-thick mouthfeel and medium carbonation.

Still more stout from Bells and more beer from the trip to the Great Midwest...

It pours blacker than black with a thin tan head. Powerful coffee aromas, big mocha and bitter chocolate. Roasty but still lots o sweet chocolate.
The flavor is dominated by coffee. Lots of mocha and bitter chocolate. Unfortunately, the coffee taste builds and overwhelms the beer in time. Its too much coffee for me. A lingering bitterness in the finish.

Outside of the heavy handed coffee, it would be an outstanding beer. Even so, its still pretty good. In the interest of equal time, K (my wife) loves this brew.
Sample. Black with small tan head. Flavour is roasted malt, dry and lots of coffee.

UPDATED: MAY 29, 2010 Poured from the bottle into a to-go cup at the Distillery in Savannah, GA.  Aroma was equivalent to a cup of strong joe.  Delicious.  Taste was dominated by coffee as well as some creaminess and a subtle bitterness.  Bells does no wrong when it comes to stouts.

Black as night pour with a thick luscious tan head that shows no signs of dissipating.  Aroma penetrates my nostrils from a distance, introducing freshly ground coffee beans, cream, bitter belgian chocolate.  Creamy, smooth mouthfeel slips down my gullet easily.  Extremely roasty but not overly bitter, like strong black coffee with a hint of cream added.

UPDATED: OCT 4, 2011 Utterly black pour with a frothy tan head. Aromas of freshly brewed coffee waft through the air. Upon going in for the first sniff I am met with massive mocha, espresso, lactic sugar, cream, bakers chocolate, and roasted barley. Literally everything I could ever desire in a coffee beer. The flavor is epic- tons of lactic creamy milk chocolate with huge components of roast, cocoa nib, and espresso. The palate is thick, velvety, creamy, and savory. A certain winner from Bells.

Bottle. 12 oz. Split with James and Tony. Pours a deep, dark, insidious black with a bold, amber head, which recedes into a slight lace across the surface. Aroma of pure, fresh coffee beans, dark chocolate, bitter hops, dry malts, wheat, roast and hints of marshmallow. Full, but not overwhelming, body. Sturdy, insanely tart and bitter palate. Finishes with a slow, meandering, mellow warming in the throat and through the belly. Outstanding, excellent stout. One of the best beers I have ever tasted.

Tap. Nice dark brown to black pour with a thin tan head. Aroma is roasted coffee. Semi carbonated mouthfeel, yet a bit creamy . Big taste of burnt/toasted coffee grounds. Maybe some herb element poking through. Good stuff.

Nearly black with a quickly diminishing tan head. Roasty coffee aroma with notes of milk chocolate. Lactose-like sweetness, roasted coffee, a slight peppery bite. Hints of black licorice linger on the tongue.

Nice beer. The aroma is huge coffee grounds. The taste is very well balanced, lots of coffee in the finish and a well temoered bitterness, but up front I got a lot of chocolate. Loved it. Definitely would pick this up again. Go Bells,
pours black with very little head, smells very sweet, chocolatey and coffee. taste is much the same, thick roasty coffee and chocolate with some alcohol burn on the back. good stuff.

12 oz bottle from the Four Firkins.  Pitch black puor with a big tan head.  Intense roasted coffee aroma and the flavor is more of the same.  Finish is a nice coffee bite that lingers on your tongue.  If you like an intense coffee experience mixed with a big stout, this is your beer.

solid...  I actually didnt smell much coffee aroma.
taste is malts, roasted, coffee  - not overpowering to me...  strength in very back end...

beer ends with a good alcohol burn.

solid beer;  good for cold winter night.
Black pour with a brown head. Woody aroma. Smokey flavor. Spicy alcoholic finish.
Mild barley aRoma.  Oily brown pour.  Nolt much java present here, just a slightly bitter herbal taste.

UPDATED: JUL 30, 2010 Bottle pours a thick brown body with some off-white lacing. Aroma is strong espresso shot - coffee, roast, and chocolate malts. Mouthfeel is medium and almost stinging with notes of roasted barley, chocolate malt, and coffee dominating with a strong underlying tart backbone.

Black pour with a small light brown head which gathers around the edges. Theres chocolate and roasted malt, dark roasted coffee, and lactose in the nose. The palate is oily, medium in body, initially lively carbonated, but settles after a few minutes. Astringent in the finish.  The flavor is pretty sweet upfront and finishes with a roasted coffee bitterness and funky tartness. I find this beer too sweet for my taste and the coffee is overpowering; its not subtle at all. Disappointing.

A- The body is jet black and is unforgiving even when held up to the light. An aggressive pour results in a very scanty head (less then 1/2 finger) that soon disappears. A very thin, dark tan collar is all that remains. No lacing is left behind in the glass.

S- Roasted malt is the first to hit the nose along with a ton off coffee. The nose basically says that I should be drinking this in the morning rather than past 11 PM.

T-The taste is much as the nose suggests. Initial flavor is medium strength and consists of rich roasted chocolate malt and coffee-with hints of a caramel sweetness. These flavors intensify for the finish and a sharp coffee bitterness is added. The bitterness soon subsides and what lingers is the taste of toasted malt, caramel,coffee, and the slightest hint of alcohol warmth.

P- Medium carbonation and mouthfeel is just a hair heavier than medium. The mouthfeel is not as thick as most from this style.

O- This is a nice, drinkable stout that I will have again. I was surprised that this wasnt a lower ABV stout-because it hides the alcohol well without being too rich. Job well done by Bells

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 02-07-2008 04:32:31
12oz bottle.  Of course the obvious, coffee and more coffee.  Tatse was very much of dark chocolate and coffee.,  Nice roasted malt flavor.  medium mouthfeel

Wow, for me, this is the bomb for big coffee stouts.  Pours dark as motor oil with a short but thick head.  The aroma and palate are robust with malt and java, but smooth and very satisfying .  The Kalamazoo Stout is a favorite and this Java Stout is an ideal follow-up for the palate.  Excellent!

Love the label in a big way. Coffee ground aroma is upfront and foremost and so it is in the flavor. Nice dark brown color. Thin enough to make it a session beer when its cold out. Just not my style may be a good bee but I could not drink it.

Thanks again, Adrian!  Coffee and esters in the aroma.  A medium weight coffee brew that seemed more like a porter than a stout.  Coffee, roasted malts, a touch of herbal hops, a bit of chocolate, and a little fruity sweetness.  A very enjoyable and drinkable brew.

Big coffee nose and dry, dry, dry finish. This is my least favorite of the Bells stouts, although that is a bit like being my least favorite denomination of currency: some is still better than none. Thank you. Ill be here all week.

Bottle thanks to ericandersnavy. Pours a black with tan head. Aroma of milk chocolate, coffee and dark roasted grain. Flavor is very much the same with a touch of cream. Mouth feel is heavy body, some creaminess, low carbonation. Overall, Damned this was good!

Black color; medium sized head, beige. The aroma is actually suspiciously dusty; there is roasted malt too, coffee grounds, very light phenol, not very nice. The flavor is much better; smooth mouthfeel, roasted malt in front, light coffee, actually with some residual sweetness; later, there is some light liquorice and phenol. Correct bitterness; the final is a bit drier. Very good.

i think my buddy kiefdog sent this to me as an extra.  pour was dark brown with a beige head.  aroma was chocolate covered coffee beans.  flavor was coffee grinds and baking chocolate.  body was light with high carbonation.

12oz bottle.  Jet black color.  Dark brown creamy head.  Aroma is big coffee.  Deep dark roast, some green coffee bean.  Flavor is of sweet vanilla beans, sweet espresso.  Finishes with rich espresso bean bitterness.  Its an 7% Iced Coffee!  ABV is well hidden, could be the caffeine.  Very smooth, creamy texture.  Heavy bodied.  Perfect Breakfast Beer!

UPDATED: OCT 5, 2010 *Expense Alert* $16 / sixer!  Sometimes you got to put down the money to try a good stout.  Burnt coffee nose, which is not offensive, yields to roasted coffee and malt.  Everything about this stout is bold--and a bit dry.  This is not a sweet stout.  Very well executed brew here.

from a trade with Smith4498. The aroma is roasted coffee.  The appearance is deep brown, oily, dark tan head.  The flavor is very roasty, almost burnt, coffee, some milk chocolate.    The finish is unexpectedly sweet, light bittering from the roasted malt, light hops, sweet cream.  The body is thick, the mouthfeel oily.  Very good...a little overdone with the roasted coffee.  Thanks again, Jason.  This is the last of the Bells.

Pours a nice, thick, dark, oily-black with small creamy head. Aroma of coffee is strong. Flavor is a nice coffee, with some chocolate and some caramel, along with the roasted malt. This is a very well-done coffee stout.

Bottle. Dark brown hue with a thick lasting tan head. Nose is huge coffee grounds and espresso with roast and cocoa in the background. Flavor follows suit with subtler coffee and roast (than expected from the nose), slight dairy and cocoa and grassy-earthy hops or balance, finishes with light sweetness. Full body, creamy thick texture, and light carbonation. A solid coffee-forward stout with enough depth and complexity to rise above the standard offerings but falling short of the richer aged versions...

Bottle courtesy of HowardF from TBS.  Thanks!  I dunno if its just because I drank a Dark Horse Tres Blueberry Stout or what, but this kinda has an offputting smell to it.....and I LOVE coffee stouts.  Ill have to give this one the benefit of the doubt and give it a fair shake some other time.

UPDATED: APR 4, 2010 Decent understated hops aroma, but dominated by coffee / dark chocolate scent.  Nearly black w/ decent tan head.  Medium-heavy bodied and very dry.  Slippery mouthfeel.  I thought I would try to re-rate this seeing how my own opinion of this beer seems to be out of line with the general consensus, but just way too much acidic coffee bitterness for my taste.  And I LOVE coffee.  And espresso.  And chocolate.   And stouts.  I really tried to like this.  Twice.

12 fl oz bottle, courtesy of fiulijn. Pours dark brown to black with a creamy tan and chocolate brown head. Aroma is spiced and dark chocolate malt aroma. Smooth roasted and chocolate, coffee herbal. Smooth and roasted chocolate vanilla and coffee roasted flavoured into a smooth malty and chocolate finish.
Dark pour with a creamy head.  Roasted malt and coffee come through big in the aroma and flavor.  Very good stuff!

Pours near black with a little red around the edges, and a nice dark tan head.  Aroma is roasted malts, coffee, cocoa, and a little toffee.  Flavor is very roasty, with a lot of coffee bean and bitter coffee finish.  Pretty good.

Serving: 12 oz. bottle from Total Wine Sterling.
It pours an inky black with a large, creamy, tan head.  Excellent head retention and lacing.  The nose is filled with coffee as you might expect.  There are also notes of earth, well roasted malt, and a bit of mineral.  The taste is loaded with black coffee (think french roast).  Its certainly not one dimensional though.  Nice notes of roasted malt, earth, mineral, and a nice malt sweetness help to provide balance.  It reminds me of lightly sweetened coffee.  The mouthfeel is medium-rich with medium-low carbonation and a long, coffee laden finish.  Overall I thought this brew was very well done and I highly recommend it.  Beware if you arent a fan of coffee though!
bottle, via trade with sprinkle, chocolate brown with medium tan foam,  aromas of coffee, almond, burnt toast, flavors are heavy on the coffee with some toast and roasted nuts, nice lingering finish
12 ounce bottle black pour brown head .One of the biggest coffee mocha flavors i ever had it sticks with you on the back end
Bottle.  Pours black with a mocha colored head.  Rich coffee with hints of chocolate and roasted malts in the aroma and flavor.  Dry, slightly bitter finish.
smells of fresh coffe grounds... on the palate it is bitter & dry with massive amounts of coffe influx... if you like coffee... this will give you a boner!!!
Pours nice and dark with a nose full of aromas. Roasted malt smell with strong coffee taste. This is one of the best coffee stouts Ive ever had rates up there with KBS and southern tier Javha.

Bottle. Pours pitch black with a small beigje foamy head. Yep the nose is intense coffee and Anton of roasted malts. Flavor follows the nose. Big coffee flavor, ad internee roasted malts. But it feels like something is missing, at least to me. Either a sweet note, or cho plate or vanilla. Something to break up the intense and extreme bitterness. I typically love coffee stouts but only like this one.
Has an incredible aroma of coffee grind, chocolate, and roasted nuts. The color is a smooth silky black with a dark brown foam head. The flavor is very smooth with a nice bitter sweet after taste.

12 oz. bottle; batch 9363; pours thin cola brown with eggy chocolate colored head settling slowly; chaulky aromas of choco powder, coffee beans, nuts, mild roast and creamy milk; thin texture that has an almost velvety mouthfeel; creamy coffee, chocolate; sign of the times that even at 7.5%, this comes off on the light side for a stout; drinks creamy with espresso, dry chocolate; not over the top with the coffee but rather a well rounded brew with plenty of sweetness to cover up any bitterness from the roast and/or coffee; very well done and a beer I was glad to revisit

Pours a 2 finger mocha colored head which resembles the creme from cappuccino. Body is pitch black. Head retention and lacing are pretty good

Aroma is of rich roasted coffee beans. Smoky burnt malts are also present but really take a backseat to coffee. Hops are faint and alcohol isnt detected. 

Taste is similar to smell, big on coffee which I love. Rich, roasted, burnt malts are also present. This beer definitely went all out to produce the coffee flavors. Hops and alcohol are on the low side. 

Mouthfeel is good. Head stayed through most of glass and added a nice froth. Just wish beer was a bit more full bodied. Carbonation was also slightly on the aggressive side. 

Overall this was a semi sessionable beer. Very rich and full of coffee goodness. I guess the only downside to this beer was that there was nothing to balance out the strong coffee flavors. My favorite beers in the world Peche Mortel and Espresso Yeti both have some sweetness to round out the beer and make them more complex. Java stout was just slightly rough around the edges but still extremely good, wish it was available in my state

Pours black with a 1 finger, creamy mocha had that has great retention. Aroma is huge on dark roast coffee and espress, nice roast follows that up, then some dusty dried grass and some salt and mineral notes. Flavor is on rich espresso, hints of dark roast coffee, rich bittersweet chocolate, dark toasted grain, planty and grassy hops, dark caramel and maybe a hint of lacto sweetness. Palate is on the heavy side of medium bodied with a fairly light carbonation, creamy entry, slightly slick finish and a fairly sticky feel on the lips. This is really a fantastic stout all around.
pitch black with small white head. aroma is tons of deep roasted coffee, bitter chocolate, burnt malts. drinks smooth with lots of bitter coffee, burnt malts, and a touch of sweetness at the finish.

Pours dark brown with a very large, fine, silky tan head. The aroma is thick with roasted coffee and a bit of lactose and salted raisins. The flavor is sweet with dark chocolate and roasted coffee beans. A bit of a cola taste as well in the middle. A very nice medium bodied stout.

UPDATED: DEC 8, 2011 Bottle. Amazing. As a beer/coffee lover, this is basically the most perfect marriage I have found. Incredibly potent expresso aroma, with slight hints of dark chocolate. Flavor is rich and layered, creamy chocolate and coffee with some sweet, burnt malt character. Very smooth and huge in body. Lovely, lingering mocha aftertaste. An experience.

12oz bottle. Pours dark brown black with a medium-thin tan head. Aroma is strong with espresso and dark chocolate. There is some earthy character - hops probably, but almost like chicory. Flavor follows aroma - coffee, some dark chocolate, mild malt sweetness. Finish is full and rich with espresso and light earthiness. Mouthfeel is quite full-bodied and brightly bubbled - almost like carbonated chocolate milk (okay, maybe not that full in body). Overall, tasty.

12 oz. bottle to my favorite tasting snifter. Aroma is straight coffee with hints of creamy chocolate. Appearance is medium body which is dark dark brown with a nice kahki colored head that dissipates with chunky lacing. Taste is quick coffee and creamy chocolate  that is malty with chaulky texture. Plate is medium bodied with chaulky dry swallow. This is a fine stout I love the true coffee flavor my only thing I would like is it to be thicker.

Bottle.  The beer is a a perfect java stout.  there is nothing but malts and coffee to this aroma and appearance.  everything about this beer is coffee. the taste is a full bodied, wonderfully aromatic, and bitter coffee flavor.  the best part of this beer is that the aftertaste is not too sweet like most other bigger stouts. a great taste

12 ounce bottle of yumminess.  Great black pour with tiny brown head that left the lightes tan galaxy spiraling across the inky void.  I know, I know.  Nose is coffee, coffee, and dark chocolate.  Roasted malt definitely there too.  Taste is wonderfully sharp, with lingering maltiness.  Is it also yeast Im tasting?   Tiniest hint of sweetness up front is assaulted by the malt.  Dusty ass dry finish.  Seriously, Im gonna have to drink a beer after this cus my mouth is totally dry.  Interesting.  Great beer.  I think this came from MrChopin, but Im not totally sure cus I didnt write down who sent what.  Thank you BIG TIME for this tasty goodness.

12 oz. bottle pours a pleasant dark chocolate brown color with a foamy tan head. Aroma is overwhelmingly of coffee - almost like old coffee grounds. Body is thin to medium and the taste is also overwhelmingly of coffee and dirt. A hint of what could be toast - if it were burnt - but I was unable to taste any of the maltiness or mellow roast that I love in so many stouts. Although it could easily be my uneducated palate, this is the first Bells beer that has disappointed, and not one Ill try again anytime soon.
Very drk black pour, scent of malts and coffee. Very good malt/coffee balanced taste. Cheers!

12 oz. bottle poured into english pint glass.  Aroma:  Satisfying amounts of both coffee and roasted malt hit the nose in succession.  Appearance is a solid dark brown with a medium mocha head.  Initial taste is is of dry, muted coffee beans.  Palate quickly fills with carbonation and it finishes with notes of chocolate and coffee.  Good mouth feel with a bit too much carbonation.  Overall its a top tier coffee stout.

Good color with a timid head reducing to nothing. Strong espresso on the nose. Full nectar with ample effers. Gives a chewy texture. Huge esspresso roast and only mildly sweet. Alcohol is appearant on the finish. Pretty straightforward with mild complexity.

Talk about coffee. Pour was dark black with a brownish/reddish head. Nose is fresh bean coffee and chocolate with banana. Taste was like drinking  straight coffee. A severe blend of espresso, americano, fresh ground bean and colombian, black...yet smooth and chocolate all the same. After taste remains dry with a slight bite. I would not have been surprised to have been up for 12 hours straight on this..Sometimes a brewer fuses two passions (coffee and beer) and gets it all wrong. Bells got it all right. The two have been blended well to go hand and hand and though its not something you could drink all night without getting sick, its definitely something Id turn to on any given cold afternoon

Bottle, This beer blew me away.  It pours a jet black body with a much taller and darker brown head than some other Bells stouts.  The aroma is of freshly ground coffee, roasted barley and a little peat.  The flavors are mostly rich aromatic coffee, and some playfully dark malts.  Nothing overpowering, and the bitterness in the dry finish was awesome.  Really brought out the tannin quality in the coffee and shored up the malts from getting chewy.  Very nicely done, and I am very happy to have finally had this beer.

Pours black into the glass with a beige head.  Aroma is straight up coffee grounds.  Flavor similarly tastes like day old coffee.  This beer was just not for me.  Ended up pouring half of it down the drain.  GASP!
Deep black with coffee head.  Aroma of coffee and roasted malt.  Flavor much of the same.  A real good balance of the two.  finish is kind of clean in that the flavor dissapates quickly.  Nice beer.

#200! 12 oz bottle.  Pours near-black with a thin tan head. Aroma is dominated by coffee, but roasted malt makes its presence known as well. Roasted malt and light chocolate in the front end of the flavor, but the finish is lingering, creamy coffee. Rich, satisfying mouth feel and low carbonation.

APPEARANCE: Poured into a tulip. Black with no sign of any highlights. Head is big and creamy and a roasted hazelnut color. About three fingers worth. It coats the sides of the glass like no other.

SMELL: If you like the smell of coffee then youll love the smell of this. Fresh ground coffee with some light chocolate notes as well and roasted malts.

TASTE: Not surprisingly this one tastes like coffee. Coffee up front and coffee on the finish. Not overpowering but just right. In the middle theres some light chocolate as well.

MOUTHFEEL: Smooth and easy to drink. Light carbonation. A somewhat dry finish.

DRINKABILITY: I love coffee and stouts so its obvious that im a fan of coffee stouts. This is very tasty and definitely i could drink a couple of these. I recommend this if youre into this style of beer.

12 oz bottle.  Pours black with a tan head.  Has a strong aroma that is completely dominated by roasted coffee.  Flavor is mostly coffee as well, with a significant bitterness from it, but lacks the richness of the aroma.  Creamy, roasty finish.

Enjoyed from a 12oz bottle in a pub glass.  The beer pours an opaque black color, with a moderate tan head that lasts in some form throughout the entire beers consumption.  The nose gives strong hints of coffee grounds, with some underlying roasted malt notes, and perhaps just a touch of alcohol.  The palate carries the marks of dark roasted coffee up front.  Roasted malt character follows, more aggressively than similar offerings from Founders and Terrapin, but not to the point that it destroys the palate.  Moderate bitterness follows, but again not to the extent that hop-derived bitterness or flavor detracts from the beers other qualities.  The finish is clean and neutral.  Overall, an excellent interpretation.
Good balance between the flavor of a stout and the coffee.  The coffee is not to overwheleming, would prefer a better tasting coffee though.
pours a deep brown to black with a brown head. aroma is espresso and chocolate. flavor is fresh espresso chocolate and burnt barley. lots of roastiness and a bitter finish.
UPDATED: JUL 17, 2010 had this from an awesome bartender in manyunk. pour dark choc. aroma is roasted malts. flavor is coffee and barley. nice brew. So tart and bitter.

Can you say heaven is a glass?  This beer is now my all time favorite.  Rich and roasty like a stout should be but with an incredible coffee taste.  Pours a black opaque color with a thick tan head.  Good lacing on the glass. Thank you Bells for coming to Arizona. Buy this beer if you can find it.

Coffee lovers rejoice! This is your beer! This one pours a black with a small brown head. An assault of burnt/roasted coffee beans hits the nostrils with this one. Full body, tastes like chocolate, roasted coffee, and has a light bitter finish. A VERY tasty stout indeed.

Bottle. Pours deep brown (basically black) with a nice 1+ inch of head that disipates to a film. Beautiful lacing going on. Aroma is of almost burnt coffee. Very long, complex finish on this guy. Very satisfying and tastes feels very warm, regardless of the temperature served.

UPDATED: JUN 26, 2010 The buzz and licking beneath the area of the tongue comes to a great functional matter as this dives into a whole sweet place to be with the fact of having tastebuds!

Updated from a 3 year aged bottle: Damn!  This retains its goodness, but mellowed out beautifully.  Blended flavors, velvety smooth, and still bitterly coffeed the F out!  Yum!

Most coffee stouts tend to have some of a coffee smell then a coffee taste this one does not follow that norm. On first smell I had to check to make sure I was not sitting in Starbucks. Smell is unreal of coffee kind of like a moca blend. Now on to the taste OMG unreal what a blend off coffee and roasted malt. The coffee is by far the leading favor in this beer. I would suggest you be a coffee drinker to take on this one.  By far the best coffee stout I have had in years. 

12 oz bottle 16 oz pint glass

Batch 9462. So glad to see this in the Illinois Valley. Dark pour with a brown head. Aroma of roasted coffee. Taste was wonderful. A perfect marriage of two of my favorite things- stout and coffee. Coffee added some bitterness to the end, but it worked out nice overall.

Id offer a formal review on this batch 9562 bottle of beer, but this is now the 3rd time Ive had type how black it poured with light brown foam that exhibits decent retention and fantastic lacing.  The first time I tried to express how the coffee was pretty much the sole aroma, the Bells website crashed my browser a couple hundred time while I tried to figure out when this beer with some serious malt that nicely complements the somewhat acrid coffee flavors was bottled.  Once I gave up on that endeavor, Steve Jobs decided that I had simultaneously hit some magically sequence of keys that deleted the entire rating where I gushed about how glad I was to see this beer back in rotation.

Appearance is black with a tan head. Aroma is strong coffee, almost, but not quite burnt. Flavor is also overwhelming coffee taste, also a little burnt in the finish. Slight chocolate flavor as well, a little bittersweet. Overall, this beer can be a little overpowering, but if you like strong coffee taste definitely check it out.

12oz bottle. dark pour with a fluffy tan, lasting head, nice lacing. great aroma of coffee and roast. the coffee isnt as out front as i thought it might be from the aroma, just a nice solid taste of black coffee, roast, bit of chocolate. not overpowering at all. mmmm coffee and beer....

Bottle pours a near black with a thin tan head.  Strong aromas of roasted malts, chocolate, and coffee.  Heavy bodied with coffee flavor dominating but not overpowering in taste, with chocolate, roasted malt, and caramel flavors present as well.  Very enjoyable Stout with coffee notes dominating but not overpowering this complex beer.

Bottle via trade.  Pours black like coffee with a small creamy tan head that lasts quite awhile.  Aroma is lots of coffee, roasted malt, and chocolate.  Pretty intense.  Flavor is really good and coffee-dominated.  Intense mocha with some nice sweet caramel malts and sharp roastiness.  Medium bodied with coffee bitterness on the palate and somewhat low carbonation.  Im a sucker for coffee beers, and this is a very good one.

Coffee. More overwhelming notes of espresso than founders breakfast stout. This is pure roast, malt, and sumatra. Tan, caramel head that pours a very dark, thick-bodied brew. Great beer to taste, but not the most pleasurable beer to the palate, a bit too intense.

Bottle thanks to Dakine.  Pour is an oily almost-black with a thin brown head.  Aroma is vanilla, roasted malt, light ash, and coffee.  Flavor is also roasted malt and coffee with a long ashy and espresso finish.  It is what you would expect.  Its done well as one would expect from Bells.

Black coffee black with a light tan head.  Aroma is sweetened coffee, and the taste is nice and even, but more of carbonated coffee than beer, with alcohol well hidden. Carbonation is as perfect as it could be.

12 oz. bottle from Ludlow Wines.  Pours very dark brown with a small brown head that leaves some brown around the edges.  Big roast coffee aroma, with notes of burnt toast, smoke, and ash.  Flavor is also a lot of roast coffee, with notes of dark chocolate, brown sugar, smoke, and burnt toast.  Smoky finish and aftertaste.  Bitter, but mostly roasty and smoky- a little sweetness helps make this more palatable.  Light-medium bodied, with a gritty roast coffee mouthfeel.  Im not much of a coffee drinker, but regular coffee drinkers- especially those that like it black- should like this a lot.

I shared a bottle of this with beerbaron617 today.  Its the first time Ive tried this beer and I feel like it has a lot of good things going on, and yet at the same time its not amazing.  It has an awesome aroma, lots of coffee, I mean, its all coffee, tiny bit of hops, but really its all coffee.  Its super dark and opaque, and its seemingly thick in the glass.  This coffee tastes only OK, its not a show stopper by any means.  If you enjoy coffee this beer would be the best thing for you.  Its flavor is predominantly coffee, but has a weird taste of licorice also.  I think this beer would go great with a brunch.

First beer review since joining the US Army!!! I shared this with my beer buddy MereLikesBeer. It poured an opaque black-brown with tan head. The aroma was nice, with lots of roasty coffee notes. Unfortunately the taste was like the smell, only a lot stronger, and not quite balanced. I expected a lot more from this brewery ,and this beer, and it just didnt deliver. Oh well.
thanks stfun! nice stout, smells of black coffee tastes off black coffee, almost looks like black coffee, but its not! great stuff, really tasty!

UPDATED: AUG 16, 2014 
Location: 12 oz bottle from Kramer(?), 8/16/14


Aroma: The nose is full of coffee (as you might expect), with some underlying chocolate notes

Appearance: It pours a dark brown-black color with a thin head and some spottydrippy lace

Flavor: The flavor is heavy coffee and roasted/burnt malts, lightly sweet, and medium bitter

Palate: The body is medium-full, smooth coffee feel, clean, with a dry, roasty finish

Overall Impression: 
I cant say this one didnt need a re-rate, as it has been 4+ years.  I do think I rated this beer too low the first time.  It is a fairly one-dimensional coffee beer, but that one dimension is done fairly nicely.  Theres too much burnt coffee though.  To me, that still feels like a flaw.  
Score: 3.5: 7/4/7/3/14

Location: 12 oz bottle from Wine and Beer Westpark, 12/17/09 


Aroma: The aroma is all about burnt/roasted coffee

Appearance: Dark brown color with a thin, light brown head with spotty lace

Flavor: Taste is lightly sweet up-front, with a big, long bitter coffee finish

Palate: Relatively full body, decent mouthfeel, pretty dry

Overall Impression: 
This is not a bad beer, but it might not be my style.  This one tastes a lot like black coffee, but since I like my coffee with a little cream and sugar, I guess its not made for me.  Its a little too burnt in feeling for my tastes as well.  Anyway, its alright, but a bit one dimensional, as the coffee completely dominates this brew.
Score: 3.0: 6/4/5/3/12

Deep black pour with a thin string of tan/light brown head that sheets laces slowly as it disappears.  Potent black coffee aroma, with extra-robust, nearly-burnt Sumatran coffee dominating all other smells.  Even for a non-coffee-lover, the flavor is tasty.  Make no mistake, this isnt a chugging brew...the black coffee and loads of dark chocolate on top of chocolate malt flavors are way too strong for that!

ABV is just right here, which proves you dont need 9+% to make a nice stout!

Bottle, thanks tarheels86. Pours thick black with a light brown head and tons of lacing. Flavor is coffee, dark chocolate, roasted malt. Big coffee flavor, I could slam these if they werent so expensive

12oz bottle (2009) into a pint glass.  Pours pretty solid black with some light showing through the edges with a half-finger milk chocolate head floating above.  The aroma is light chocolate and coffee mixed with sweet stout and a hint (jusssst a hint) of alcohol coming through.  The flavor is absolutely smooth and complex with milk chocolates, sweet roasted malt, a touch of sour American stout, and just the right amount of fresh coffee blended beautifully into the end of the flavor.  This is good stuff!

A: Black as night, with a small espresso colored head. Picture Perfect. 

S: This one has a wonderful malt smell about it. Of course there are hints of coffee, but you can also smell chocolate and a hint of spice, nutmeg maybe? 

T: Bells never ceases to amaze. This is another solid beer from their ever impressive lineup. The taste is wonderful. It is so simple yet complex. This beer has a taste of a perfectly crafted cafe mocha. The malt gives it a wonderful backbone and enhances the taste of fresh brewed dark coffee and chocolate. 

M: It is very smooth, creamy, with very little bitterness despite the taste of dark coffee and chocolate.

UPDATED: DEC 9, 2009 12 oz bottle courtesy of the Binnys singles rack (Orland Park, IL). A beer Ive been anticipating for awhile. Pours a near pitch black pour, a touch of very dark brown around the edges, opaque, a moderate dark brown head, that bubbles, stays decent sized, laces ok. Aromas are coffee, roasted malts, chocolatey mocha, with more coffee, and a bit of ashy smoke on the palate. Not bad. Initial is heavier bodied, a decent thickness, heavier coffee, roasted malts, dark chocolate, mocha on the palate, a touch of sweetness really sticks, but bitterness and roasty feel is very potent, but goes down nicely. A nice balance, largely roasty, but still  enough sweetness to make the beer quite quaffable. Finish is sweet and bitter, roasty with a solid ash and coffee dominance. Good flavors, not an overly complex stout, but certainly done very well, balanced, and tasty. Very nice!

Aroma is just like fine coffee with a smoky overtone - hardly like beer at all, but most inviting! It pours a deep opaque sable, nearly black, with a very thick, fine-bubbled tan head. Flavor is rich and very smoky, maybe a wee bit too smoky. It has a tasty chocolate undertone and hints of toffee and molasses. Texture is thick, smooth, fairly tingly, and quite satisfying. Overall, an immensely pleasing stout.

Bottle. Pitch black with a longlasting tan head. Hard roasted malt, roasted coffee beans, espresso and light vanilla aroma notes. Lovely roasted flavour with lots of coffee, light milky and chocolate. Creamy and soft texture. It ends up sweet coffeeish and light hoppy.

UPDATED: JAN 9, 2011 12oz bottle, batch 9992, bottled October 13, 2010.  I MUCH prefer this to the 2009 batch.  The 09 was rather burnt, soy sauce, mediocre coffee but this here features premium espresso, very rich, tons of chocolate, rich mouthfeel, complex aroma, great appearance, everything I want in a coffee stout.  Fantastic

12 oz. bottle batch 9436, bottled Nov 10, 2009.  Pours dark brown with a good-sized rocky brown head.  Leaves rings of lacing on the glass.  Aroma is a big punch o coffee.  Strongest coffee aroma & flavor Ive encountered in a beer...a little too much perhaps.  Some licorice, slight chocolate, and a bit of sourness round out the nose.Flavor is of course big on coffee, some chocolate, caramel, licorice, roasted malts, soy sauce.  Bitter coffee finish.Mouthfeel is pleasant, medium to full with low to medium carbonation.  Alcohol is well-hidden.I like coffee stouts a lot and had high hopes for this one, but it isnt as good as others Ive had.  The coffee is very overpowering which hurts the balance, and doesnt smell or taste like the highest quality coffee either.   More like day-old Folgers rather than gourmet beans.  Granted my bottles are extremely fresh, so Im hoping a few months of age may help mellow it out a bit.   This review is based on my second bottle, about a week after the first one and it is better than initial impressions.  The high price doesnt help either...
Aroma 6, Appearance 4, Taste 7, Palate 3, Overall 14, Score 3.4

First tasted on tap at the Brew Kettle in Strongsville, but purchased from one of the best beer stores in Cleveland if not all of America, Rozis in Lakewood.    You get the coffee hint right away, but the caramel & chocolate seem to lessen the coffee hit you get from dinking coffee.  Stays on the palate nicely and finishes very well.  Definitely use a snifter if you have one, keeps the flavor and aroma in the glass as yoy enjoy it.  As usual, with the darker beers, let it warm up a bit.  Youll taste buds will appreciate it!!!

UPDATED: JUL 23, 2011 first off, the pour is NOT black, its darkish brown. settles in the glass much darker looking, but this thing is not black. the smell is sweet and STRANGE. the taste is very sour, bitter, ashy, coffee..there is just a strange acidic sourness that is not pleasant. to me, the off smell really takes away from the beer...

Bottle (thanks to guyinchicago for this one)...  Poured black with a thick, brown head.  Aroma of dark sugars, roasted coffee beans  Nice, soft and subtle palate.  Grainy brew with a warming kick to it and a strong coffee and chocolate presence.  Smokey oak characters created a sweet base to the beer.  Malty and big body to the brews finish.

Bottle from andrew. Nice black color, small head. Good coffee aroma, Taste is roasted malts, coffee and a little chocolate. Nice texture on this beer and enjoyed sipping on this one. Overall a nice stout. Well done bells brewery.

12 oz bottle. Love java, love Bells. Pours a dark black color with a small brown head that dies quickly. Smells of rich roasted coffee, and a lot of it. Tastes similar, with a nice almost creamy finish. Could have a little more body to it, but very good.
Coffee, dark chocolate, and roasted malts with some more coffee, dark chocolate, and roasted malts.  Very good but a little too much for my taste.  I prefer a more toned down version.

Definitely looks like expected. Pours an almost black color. One-finger head of creamy espresso colored foam. Leaves a nice light swirl on top. Lacing is thin and somewhat slick.

Big dark roasted coffee beans, with that acidic tone of sumatra. Light hints of chocolate. A slight touch of smoke, and a very slight note of licorice. Predominantly, just huge coffee-ness. As youd expect from something called Java Stout.

The coffee is totally dominant here, also. But its not as overpowering as in the nose. Its a much nicer balance of flavor. Some nice chocolate notes can be found. A touch of smoke. A very light hint of vanilla. Some roasted malts.

This is a great full-bodied brew. Nice and thick. Very smooth, slightly sharp and a touch of creaminess.

This is one great coffee stout. I dont imagine that you could ask for more coffee flavor in a beer than this one. The smooth texture and balance of flavor make this easily drinkable, for me.
Bells needs to expand their distribution, and to please make Oklahoma one of their stops.

12oz bottle from Holiday Market in Royal Oak. Aroma is roasted coffee, dark chocolate, and roasted malts. Flavor is roasted coffee, dark chocolate, caramel, and roasted malts. While there is a fair amount coffee bitterness this beer has a very creamy and smooth palate for a coffee stout.  I am not a fan of coffee stouts in general, but this one is rather enjoyable.

12oz bottle.  black with a large frothy brown head.  strong, dry, roasted coffee aroma.  milky, creamy palate especially when warm.  the flavors is robust with a dry bitter coffee, lightly sweetened with chocolate to balance out the bitter coffee beans.  full body.  definitely one of the better coffee stouts.

Bottle from Crown#6, shared with Brother Eric. Pours pitch black with brown edge and quick fading tan head. Nose is strong pleasant coffee beans over roasted malt. Flavor is bitter smooth black coffee with some slight roasted malt and chocolate hints. If youre an avid black coffee drinker like myself, you will LOVE this beer. Slightly acidic and carbonated in mouthfeel. Excellent brew!

Batch 8375. A black beer with little to no head. The aroma was coffee as was the taste. The mouthfeel was slightly creamy & is a good coffee beer. Id rather not think about it since this is a good beer that we may never get in TX since Bells has no plans to come here.

12 oz. bottle from Macs on West Peachtree. Nice off-white chocolate head that fades away rather quickly. Nice black body, and opaque. Looks good to me. Pungent coffee bean and slight milk aroma as well; very pungent beer. Coffee roast flavor is awesome. This beer has a lovely coffee smell. The beer did not look as smooth as it is during the pour. It is actually very smooth. I am surprised by the texture. Coffee flavor is very much in your face. Very big roast flavor. Coffee flavor is great, but it doesnt allow for other flavors to come through, but when you call a beer "Java Stout", what do you expect? A great coffee beer. I am very pleased that this beer finally made it to Georgia.

12oz bottle. Pours a black body with a thin, brown head that dissipates immediately and leaves a light lacing. Aroma is packed with dryer coffees. Some dark chocolate and milk chocolate add a nice sweetness, but this is clearly all about the coffee. Flavor is more the same and very bold. Lots of coffee greets the palate along with a rich and milky, dark chocolate. A light nutty molasses comes in during the middle along with more coffee and chocolate. Finishes with a good amount of woody bitterness along with some roasts to dry this fairly quickly. Lots of bittersweet chocolate and coffee make up a lengthy aftertaste. Medium to full body, smooth, and slightly syrupy. Overall, this is a really nice coffee stout. The coffee is clearly the dominant flavor, but there is still a nice chocolate malt backing and a solid bitter finish. Really nice.

12 oz bottle.  Dark black opaque pour with an average tan colored head.  Obvious coffee dominated aroma, but I also get notes of tobacco, nuts, and cardboard.  Flavor is quite bitter, but not offputting by any means.  The cardboard luckily does not show itself in the flavor.  The flavor of this beer is much better than the odd aroma.  I do get more chocolate notes when tasting.  I can see some similarities to Founders Breakfast Stout, but overall its not nearly as well put together.

330 mL bottle.  Almost black with little head.  Aroma is almost all coffee, with a little roast and cola.  Flavour also - lotsa lotsa coffee.  Soft finish, perhaps due to the low carbonation.  Body actually thins as it warms!?  Good, but its no Peche Mortel.

22nd July 2008. This is not a subtle coffee beer but it is a good one. The sumatran coffee is slightly sweet but retains its character. There is also some repressed fruit in the finish. Not too bitter.

Charcoal nose. Black pour, headless. Licorice, coffee, and charcoal, very dark and sooty tasting. Thin to medium bodied, low viscosity. Some bitter dark chocolate notes in the end. Dry and unbalanced.
12oz bottle. Pours black with a dark brown head. Strong aroma of coffee beans and chocolate. Taste is similar with a creamy finish.

Poured oily black, with nice tan head.  Nose full of coffee and roasted malts, tasted of coffee up front with a nice dark roasted finish.  Overall an excellent and balanced blend of coffee and stout, as advertised!

12oz bottle.  Pours black with tiny tan head. Decent aroma.  Wow.  A much different taste from the "traditional" stout.  Heavy coffee flavor, almost too much.  But what do you expect from a JAVA stout. Hints of spice at the beginning drink also, but that might have been the heavy carbonation. Decent beer but not great.

First coffee infused beer for me. It pours pitch black with a nice, chocolaty head, though it dissipates quickly. Very strong and wonderful aroma of freshly roasted espresso beans, like a nice coffee house. Flavors are awesome. Full of chocolate, cream, and of course, strong brewed coffee (dark or espresso Id say). Finishes full, like syrup, and bites like a dryer stout. Wonderful to cozy up with when its cold out.

Very dark pour with a very dark tan head. WOW! COFFEE!  Strong bitter coffee at that.  The coffee dominates both the aroma and taste.  Strong carbonation, which I normally dont like but it worked and gave this a great mouthfeel.

Quite nice scent, fresh coffee, very strong.  Hints of chocolate and vanilla in the background.  Appearance is nice, if a bit thin looking as while it appears black, under light reveals brown highlights.  Flavor is extremely coffee and cream forward.  Very good, but the coffee for me anyway is not up to the gold standard of Speedway.  Still very good.  Mouth is surprisingly thick for a "regular" stout.  Enjoyed this one thoroughly.

12 oz bottle from Archer Liquors. Similar to Founders breakfast stout. Aroma has bitter chocolate with lots of over-roasted coffee, some creamyness. Dark black color with a big reddish brown head. Flavor is chocolately and bitter, nice thick mouthfeel.

Pous opaque black w/a creamy tan head from the 22oz. bottle: Aroma is stiff: fresh espresso, dry roast, and dark chocolate. Flavor is a creamy, delicate blend of dry coffee and roasted malt with faint gun powder. Medium bodied. The only negative is that I wish more "stout" would shine through into the finish. I wouldnt say the coffee flavor is overwhelming, though. Drinkability: Ahhmazing. Sweet. I can tell that it is what the brewers wanted it to be. Rebuy: Right away. #176 on 31102009 "BOO". DG.
Pours a dark, dark brown with a tan head and lacing.  Strong coffee aroma.  I repeat,  strong  coffee aroma.  Coffee flavor with a hint of creaminess.  A tad bitter, but good.
Love the label in a big way.  Coffee aroma is upfront and foremost and so it is in the flavor.  Nice dark brown color.  Thin enough to make it a session beer when its cold out.  Yum.

Bottle from the Beeryard - tasted last winter, rating just added now. Bottle. Black, medium tan head. Strong coffee aroma, raisins, currants. Not my favorite aroma, but not by any means bad. Bitter, like sweetened black coffee. Slightly thin, but generally good palate.

Bottle - Batch 9375 - Dark pour with a small tan head. A blast of light roast coffee, cinnamon, asphalt, wood, and some light milkiness. Flavor is really roasty and finishes with coffee and cream. Theres lots of roasty bitterness on the finish. It definitely smoothed out as it warmed, and lost some of the biting carbonation. Definitely not as much coffee flavor as, say, FBS, but still a good brew.

UPDATED: OCT 23, 2010 Extremely good but very expensive ($15.99 for a six pack) stout that is consistent with two things: coffee and chocolate aroma & flavors.  The description states "truly enlightening beer" and I couldnt agree more.  -----  Had this again in a single bottle purchase and its even better than I remember.  Perfect blend of dark roast coffee and chocolate, rich and creamy.
Bottle. I love stouts and this one did not disappoint.  Wonderful coffee aromas with a creamy finish.

Bottle.  Pours dark brown with an average light brown head.  Heavy coffee bean aroma with some oak and dark chocolate.  Roasted coffee is obviously the dominant flavor with plenty of it in the initial and finishing taste.  Also has a presence of smoke, black licorice and cocoa that contributes to a dry finish.  Surprisingly creamy texture with plenty of carbonation.  Very good and highly recommended for anyone that likes a heavy dose of coffee flavor.

Black with good, creamy brown head / Nose of cigar box and roast coffee / Medium body, chewy, with good balance and dry, rich finish / Flavors of cigar box, roast coffee, unsweetened chocolate, and vanilla / A big, dry, astringent stout.

Draft at South Park Tavern in Dayton, OH.  Not a huge stout, but flavorful as can be.  Big roast, big coffee dominates this beer.  The pour is dark, dark brown with the aromas of dark roasted coffee.  Very drinkable, very easy going.  I could drink these all night.

Bottle from sicilianos, batch 9363.  Opaque black with creamy tan head.  Aroma is fresh espresso, dry roast, chocolate, nice and stiff.  Flavor is dry coffee and roasted malt that is very well blended, coffee in the finish is a little astringent but not overwhelmingly so, sort of like gun powder, a little tobacco, very nice.  Creamy, well carbonated, full body.  Very nice, way too many positive things about this beer for any of the negatives to shine through too much.

12oz bottle batch #9363.  Pours a duller dark brown chocolate color with a sticky fizzy foamy tan head.  Aroma is lovely mellow coffee and cream, a touch woody, reminds me slightly of a blend between DFH Chicory and Tyranenas coffee porters, dryer slightly chalky, dry woody, toothpick/tongue depressor like, touch of dark chocolate.  Flavor starts out a bit harsh but very tasty, very bitter dark chocolate, dark chocolate becomes quite creamy and subtly rich, bright very strong roast coffee beans, espresso, nice balance but still quite aggressive, seems like a stronger version of DFHs Chicory, has that slight woody dry mellow quality, finishes a bit brighter with some acidity and slight unpleasant astringency.  Some bitter charcoal lingering aftertaste.  Very dark and bitter.  Creamy medium/full body, more towards full, nice finer somewhat sharp fizzy carbonation, finishes just a bit syrupy.  Very nice... but I think I prefer the drinkability of DFH Chicory or Founders Breakfast.

dark light imprenetable brown, tiny tan bubbles rim the glass, some lace.  nose of coffee, dried fruit, licorice.  flavor follows nose, coffee, dried fruit, licorice.  oily mouth feel, bitter hop finish.  an enjoyable stout, well worth repeating.
Pours a dark brown, tan head.  Sweet malt, milk chocolate, roasted coffee, smoke, and some nuts.  Creamy mouthfeel.  I had this side by side with special double cream, and I like this one better.

Bottle batch #9363.  Black pour with a small tan head.  The aroma is loaded with dark bitter coffee and dark chocolate with a hint of smoke and hazelnut.  The flavor is intense espresso with some lacto sugar creaminess, dark chocolate, and a smoky, toasty nuttiness on the finish.  The body is thick, oily, and chewy with plentiful carbonation that cleans the palate for the next tasty sip.

12 oz. bottle from Grape & Gourmet (Batch 9363 bottled September 22, 2009).  Black pour with a light tan head.  Big, bold coffee aroma with rich chocolate.  The taste doesnt disappoint; strong coffee flavor.  Sweet chocolate roasted malt balances the flavor.  I had this a few years ago and liked it but this is even better than I remembered.  This is quite good.

Big pop when opened. Smells of fresh brewed coffee, somewhat bitter smell also.Very smooth and flavorfull with roasted coffee almost sweet. Wow. Creamy and chewy, finishes very well, with just a bit of bitter. Will be picking up more in the future.

UPDATED: OCT 14, 2009 12oz bottle, batch #9363, from grape & gourmet. pours a deep, dark brown with a soft, quickly fading, tan head and great lacing. aroma is wonderful with big, dark, roasted coffee, ash, smoked nuts, and bitter chocolate. flavor is great as well with the aforementioned huge, dark, roasted coffee notes dominating but with smooth, subtle notes of chocolate, burnt malts, and cigar paper coming through on the swallow leaving a bitter, ashy finish. palate is medium bodied and very smooth making it extremely drinkable. overall, another well rounded, delicious beer from Bells.
Unexpectedly bitter, really strong and thick, delicious. good stuff dat. lots of coffee and malt, no noticeable chocolate flavor.  Sampled at the 2nd Annual Treasure Coast Beerfest in Ft. Pierce.

12 oz bottle courtesy of Dak.  Thanks again for the extensive Bells stout hookup!  Deep brown, almost black pour, with a 1 finger, nut brown, head.  Strong nose of roasted coffee, unsweetened chocolate, and wood.  Smooth mouthfeel with the definite dryness of coffee.  It is pretty dominating at first but the roasted malts and chocolaty notes come out as the beer warms a little.  Its almost a little too drinkable.  I could see putting a few of these down in one sitting.

Pours a very dark brown almost black color with mahogany edges and a huge frothy tan head. Roasted malty aroma with lots of coffee as well as some oatmeal, toffee, caramel and hazelnut. Very smooth and quaffable with lots of roasted coffee maltiness, creamy sweet dark chocolate, caramel, toffee, oattmeal and a bitter, hoppy dry finish.

Bottle from 2007.  Dark amber brown pour, little carbonation and nice aroma of chocolate, coffee and vanilla.  Flavor is pronounced coffee and chocolate right off the bat, then finished with vanilla, peat and somewhat dry.  Awesome brew that tastes great with some age.
very nice chocolate and coffee aroma. This beer has a full bodied flavor with a creamy mouth feel.
Overpowering with so much coffee!  Holy shit!  If you like coffee this is your beer, if not, well, its name is well-earned.

12oz bottle provided by josephselander poured into a snifter.

Pours black in the glass with hints of mahogany showing through the edges.  There is an impressive two-inch tan head that hangs around as a small cap and leaves good lacing.

The aroma is like a coffee milkshake with a shot of chocolate syrup.  The dominant aroma is that of spent coffee grounds but there is an underlying chocolate malt presence that keeps the coffee from being the only player.

The taste doesnt quite hit the excellence of the aroma but, as a coffee lover, I thoroughly enjoyed it.  Its got the dominant roasted espresso taste but its definitely got a more toasted character than the aroma, almost burnt.  There is a decent malty sweetness but the finish is very roasty and bitter.

They mouthfeel is on the fuller side of things and super creamy with soft carbonation.

This is an stellar stout that sits somewhere just short of an imperial stout, but is extremely tasty and a must-try for the coffee lovers out there...like me.  Another great beer from Bells.
Rich coffee and dark malt aroma. Black, nicely balanced flavor of coffee, bitterness, malt and mild chocolate.

Draught @ Bells Eccentric Cafe, Kalamazoo, MI: Pours deep, deep brown - almost black - with a bountiful foam tan head resting atop.  Aroma is all coffee off the top and throughout; I squinted and strained to find some chocolate and anise waiting for me, but this is coffees show.  That first sip again is a coffee bomb, but a great one.  Dark roast, earthy coffee with subtle notes of chocolate malt, cocoa powder, tobacco, and toffee.  Its complex, its super tasty, and it glides down your throat without effort. A commendable effort by a superb brewery.
Aroma of roasted coffee. Kind of woke me up. Taste was much of the same. Loads of coffee with a rich thick body. Hellava good coffee brew.

There are a few breweries that are veritable powerhouses when it comes to consistently good craft beer. One of them would be Bells Brewery.


My Java poured black as night with a billowing head of foam which rises from her dark depths to proudly dominate the top of my brew. Where light manages to peak through, glints of dark earthen brown can be glimpsed while her head collapses in a series of bubbly pockets, leaving a dark tan blanket to mark her territory. Just as her head billowed and burbled her way to the top, so does her nose; coffee, a smorgasbord of chocolate, and espresso with fresh caramel crema topping her estery bliss. Warm notes of vanilla and cream temper the delicate notes of caramel sweetness as dry, toasty and crusty burnt malts cause me to salivate in delight. Enough of this nose thing, I want to make sweet love to her dark java stout depths. Our first embrace is soft with milk chocolate and cream, reminding me of a gourmet latte with hints of chocolate and caramel while coffee permeates every pore. Dry burnt malts leave each kiss dry and arid, creating an immediate thirst which is sated almost immediately. Delicate lace teases, seducing my eyes and body as we grow closer. Her coffee presence dominates while a naughty nip of lemon creeps into her finish. Whoever said parting is such sweet sorrow was obviously a masochist because parting is nothing but sorrow. As I bid my Java Stout farewell with a tear in my eye, my senses revel in a beauteous blend of rich chocolates, fresh coffee and cream, gooey caramel, and a whisper of wood while my body melts in contented warmth.


I love this beer. I could drink her all day long, but then I wouldnt have time to enjoy other beers. Suffice to say, Bells Brewing knows their beers and they especially know their stouts. Java Stout is an absolute success and I am happy to say that this time I have more awaiting me in my fridge for further scandalous affairs.

This is batch 8256.

Appearance - Pours a dark brown with a 1 finger cappuccino head. Has wonderful head retention.

Smell - Smells like an over the hill coffee smell. Not the most pleasant of smells from a coffee beer that I have experienced. This scares me a little, wonder if this one has gone south...

Taste - Yup, this one might be heading south... The coffee is there, and is not very pleasant. A weird taste in there, cant put my finger on it; not a welcome taste. Tastes kind of stale. Maybe some rotting figs, I can almost taste branches too...

Mouthfeel - Great carbonation, wonderful mouthfeel. For the style, I would say this is damn near perfect. A nice and refreshing feeling.

Drinkability - I dont know, I wish I could have tried this when it was fresh. It is 2 years old now, and I just dont like it that much. I didnt finish the bottle.

smell: coffee all the way. Appearance: black as... well, coffee. Taste: well... coffee, strangely enough. Taste: erm, like a cup of really nice coffee! As it warms a malt sweetness emerges, softening the coffee bitterness. Very drinkable.

Bottle batch # 8315. A very dark brown color body with a medium sized light brown head. Aroma of ground coffee,malt ,and chocolate. Flavor is much the same  intense coffee, cream, sugar, dark chocolate,tobacco,and vanilla,smooth creamy mouthfeel,light to medium carbonation,bitter dry espresso finish, a very tasty stout.

 Thank you Bells

bottle poured a dark brown color with a frothy brown head that fell away quickly but looked nice. aroma has dark chocolate malt, coffee, licorice, and light roast. light mouth feel with light carbonation. flavor has a heavier coffee, dark bitter chocolate, and roast. finishes drying with black espresso and bitterness.
Pours a deep brown.  Cocoa, dark chocolate, coffee nose. Sweet, roast, cocoa, coffee flavor.

Pours a dark brown with very little head. Aroma of chocolate, malt and coffee.  Taste is initially a sweet blend of chocolate and malt finished off with a little burnt coffee. Another nice one from Bells.
poured dark with a small head that faded quickly smelled of cofee tasted of sweet coffee and chocolate very good beer

UPDATED: APR 18, 2011 Solid black with a creamy brown head. Coffee and chocolate aroma. The sweet chocolate is balanced well by the bitterness of the coffee. Medium chewy body, bitter finish...... Another bottle thanks to Savvy1982. This stuff is damn good. I wish I had an unlimited supply of this as it is a perfect breakfast beer. Sweet, chewy, some bitter coffee/roast. Perfect.

Shared with barrios et al. on the brew day.  Everything you expect a coffee stout to be. Extremely dark brown pour but just a hint of brown dark tan head. Roasty, coffee, bitter chocolate.  Nice example of the style.
