2008 Bottle - Thanks BrewCzar! - Pours a thin dk brown with a medium creme coloured head...aroma is dk malt, green peppers, coffee, cocoa and vanilla...flavour is dry and ashy, but evolves into a nicely balanced brew, capped off with a lingering coffee finish that rocks...very nice!...
12 oz bottle.  Dark brown pour with a medium light brown head.  Aroma of coffee, chocolate and malts.  Sweet but full taste of coffee, milk chocolate and roasted nuts.  Nice dry finish.

12oz Bottle  Trade - Daknole
Aroma: Huge dark coffee roast and dark roasty malt aroma. 
Appearance: Black in color, clear with a thin head.  
Flavor: Big coffee and dark malt flavoring this also had good hints of chocolate.  
Palate: Dry stout finish, with a great Mouthfeel.  
Overall: Super beer this was awesome in so many ways loved the flavoring this was very well brewed.  Thick and tasty.
Bottle. Thick black pour with espresso like crema on top. Heavy coffee aroma. Looks and tastes like espresso.
UPDATED: MAY 31, 2009 bottle from james. pours deep brown with a tan head.   coffee, roasty, bitter, not bad.  no expedition stout.
Bottle from Butters.  Pours a dark brown body with a light brown head.  Smells like coffee with a bit of chocolate.  Tastes like coffee, roasted, and nice bitterness.  Coffee finish.
Bottle shared with Steve.  Great coffee stout.  Excellent choc espresso flavor and has a beautiful caramel smokey finish.  Go try this one.
Pours Black with little or no Head. Tons of Coffee and Roasted Malt. Little bit bitter but thats dues to the coffee. Awesome night cap or after dinner beer.

12oz bottle from The Brass Tap in Wesley Chapel, FL. Pours dark brown, almost black with a thin tan head. Aroma is strong of toffee and caramel with some black coffee. Flavor is burnt espresso, toffee, caramel...very sweet. Medium mouthfeel, burnt/sweet aftertaste. This is good...but almost too sweet for me...and thats unheard of.
Im not sure what happened here, but this was not a great stout that I expect from Bells.  The coffee flavor was very mild and there was a strnge bitterness present in the after-taste.

Bottle received in a trade, thank you so much but Im at a loss who so kindly included this one in a trade. Pours black as pitch with a smallish tan head. Aroma is huge fresh roasted coffee, very rich and inviting. Flavor is roasted coffee, caramel, chocolate malt some slight dark fruit in the finish. Very creamy mouth feel and overall a very nice stout. An enjoyable second to the first stout of the evening, Peche Mortel.

UPDATED: MAY 21, 2009 I cant describe beer like everyone else here, but Ill sum up my feelings: delicious, dark brew with an extra caramelized head, with a wonderful dark taste leaving a hint of coffee. My kind of stout!

Bottle.  Poured black with thin dark brown head.  Nose is thick with coffee and sweet alcohol.  Delicious.  Medium bodied, very present coffee and some smokey chocolate notes.  As it warms the coffee flavor gets pretty intense.  Finish is dry.  Yum.

Batch 8315, packaged Feb 5, 2008. Dark not quite opaque brown. Dense rich mocha head eventually collapses to a thin layer. Unmistakeable coffee aroma, coffee and cream, rich, roasty, cohesive. Very soft and creamy texture. High quality latte, but not espresso based, if thats fair to say. Light/medium milky sweetness. Light/medium bitterness of part roasted coffee bean, part roasted barley. To compare/contrast this with some other coffee stouts Ive tried, far less astringent than Founders Breakfast Stout, like drinking heavily creamed coffee vs straight dark roast. Less roast than Peche Mortel and shorter finish. This is such an easy drinking beer, very recommendable, although to be fair, the first half of the bottle is better than the second half as the bitterness does build up.

pours a deep black with a thin and creamy mocha head.  outstanding aroma of dark roasted coffee with a subtle milk chocolate backing.  flavor has tons of coffee, some burnt toffee, and a hint of dark fruit.  i wish the chocolate wasnt lost in the flavor.  mouthfeel is thick and creamy with a roasted coffee finish.    very nice stout...the only thing it lacks is a bit more flavor complexity as it is a bit one dimensional and head retention was poor.

Found some old notes. (6/30/07). Bottle. Pours a rich coffee color. Nose is full of roasted malts a little coffee. Flavors are also very malty with a slight coffee. Wonder if this bottle is not as fresh as it should be or if that is just the beer. Still a good drink.
Bottle. Pours a black color with a decent head. Aroma is roasted malts and coffee. Taste is similar to the aroma. Very drinkable beer.

Bottle from California bottles. Has a moderate amount of roast black malt and scent of coffee bean but overall aroma is average and not substantial enough for satisfaction. Stout, however, pours a deep blackness with a thin layer of film. The flavor is a rich and robust blend of coffee bean and lives up to the title and description of the beer. Lovely aftertaste finish of dark black coffee and just the most minor reminder of half and half or sweet flavored creamer.

Pours motor oil black with a small dark brown head.  Aroma is deep, earthy coffee with some milkiness, and maybe a twinge of vanilla and spice.  Smells like a Starbucks.  Some small noticeable yellow lace upon swirling.  Flavor is some malt with black coffee and some sugar.  Finish lingers with earthy coffee.  No bitterness in finish.  Very gentle and unbitter for amount of coffeeness present.  Very nice stout: even gives coffee breath without the unpleasantness of so much coffee.

Bottle, batch 8315. Poured black with a tan head that settle to a ring and left light lace. Big aromas of coffee and chocolate. The flavor is much the same but the coffee is even more pronounced. Full body and very enjoyable.

12oz bottle brewed in January 2008 sampled at the Hopsnobbery Collective stout tasting on 1.16.09.  Pours darkest brown with a thin off-white head.  Aroma of coffee, coffee and coffee.  Heavy coffee flavor with a touch of creamy sweetness.  Not a lot different than when fresh, but I still love this one.

Bottle. Pours jet black with a small tan head. Aroma of coffee, chocolate, roasted malts, and has a hint of vanilla. Flavor is rich and sweet with dark chocolate, dark roasted coffee, molasses and some roasted goodness with a medium body and a lightly roasted bitter finish. Excellent stout.

Bottle:  Poured a black color with a tan head.  The aroma was roasted coffee malts and chocolate.  The flavor was creamy, sweet, coffee, chocolate, caramel, and toffee.  Overall, a smooth tasting beverage Id drink instead of coffee.

Bottle (note: bottled on Feb. 08, so almost a year old). Pours opaque black without a hint of light making it through, with a fluffy brown head that recedes quickly. Nose is interesting - there’s a clean dark fruity/cocoa sweetness, alongside light espresso. Taste is surprisingly sweet - sweet chocolate alongside a light espresso character. Chocolate covered espresso beans. Finish is light, delicate espresso with some notable dark chocolate, consistent with taste and aroma.  Mouthfeel is nice, lively but but light carbonation, slightly fluffy mouthfeel. Very drinkable and tasty cross between a milk stout and a coffee stout.

12oz bottle from Mr. Dunderbaks (Tampa, FL). Pours a pitch black color with a massive two finger tan, creamy head that settles slowly and heavily laces the glass. Aroma is malty and sweet with heavy notes of coffee and dark chocolate, dark ripe friut, raisins, roasted notes. Flavor is roasted and malty with notes of sweet chocolate, fresh coffee, prunes, molasses, and hints f caramel and toffee. Generally medium to full body with a slightly bitter chocolate and coffee finish.

Pours black with light brown head. Aromas of burnt malts and coffee. Slightly bitter roasted malt flavor with chocolate and coffee. Full body with moderate carbonation and a slick, oily mouthfeel. Another well done stout from Bells.

330 mL. Pours a deep brown almost black with a thin, yellowish head that sticks around for awhile. Good lacing. Aroma is saltwater with some capers and green olives overpowering the coffee and chocolate notes. Taste is very salty with lots of capers, motel coffee grounds, and bittersweet chocolate. As this beer warms it gets less salty and more like coffee. 7.5% is nicely hidden.

12oz bottle (batch 7706) given to me from a trade awhile back...pours close to black pour with a thin light brown head....
mostly assertive dark roasted coffee aroma, chocolate and little of much anything else...
flavors characteristically follow suit. strong chocolate, coffee, and roasted malts mostly that come off as primarily sweet.  slight bitter roast in the finish.  decent coffee stout with a sweeter finish...
8/3/7/4/15
Bottle.  Strong coffee and roasted malt/chocolate aroma.  Black body, small head.  Outstanding semi-sweet coffee/chocolate flavor, lightly bitter finish.  Wonderful.

From MrChopin via trade.  The pour was ultra dark brown with a short tan head and spotty lacing.  The aroma was mostly coffee in the initial rush.  As it opened up light chocolate and roasted malts were there too.  The flavor was slightly hoppy and slightly sweet with coffee bashing you over the head rather unsubtly.  Relatively thin mouthfeel, which made it easier to get through.  Good, just borderline one dimensional.

UPDATED: MAY 6, 2009 bottle thanks to dakine poured black with 1 inch tan head aromas abound of coffee taste of coffee and coffee and coffee and a hint of smooth chocolate medium body with a sweet slightly bitter finish one word fanfuckingtastic great beer

UPDATED: MAY 15, 2009 very good aroma with figs, prunes, and malt.and a hint of vanilla....has a nice creamy mouthfeel, with little to no head....finishing nicely with a medium roast coffee and just a hint of ash..
wonderful stout

Bottle.  inviting black color with tannish beige head.  Soda-like in consistency and appearance.  Coffee grounds, vanilla, decaf-black like my mother used to drink.  Smooth with lightly acidic finish.  Very drinkable.  I have a bias for Bells - I come in expecting a good pour every time.

Pours almost black with a thick chocolate milk colored head.  The smell is full of coffee.  More than a lot of other coffee stouts or porters out there.  Mouthfeel is thick and creamy with a subtle mocha flavor.  Reminds me of an Arby’s Jamocha shake.  (for more on Arby’s and beer, see my review of Newport Storm 08)  Very good coffee stout.  Sweet, smooth and creamy with a robust roasted coffee flavor.  Another great Bell’s offering.

UPDATED: MAR 9, 2009 Bitter, earthy coffee on the nose.  Pours black, thin brown head, spotty lace.  Flavor is coffee, toasted malts, bordering burnt, aniseed.  Finishes bittersweet.  A lot going on in the mouth, but not well harmonized to my tongue.  Dry, chalky, lively mouthfeel.

Pours deep black, with coffee/brownish head.
Aroma is loaded with torrefied coffee and roastiness.
Taste, coffee with nice chocolate malts and light mocha. Leaves a light bitter hoppy finish, mouthfeel is thick and malty.
This one is loaded with nice coffee. Definitely a great coffee stout beer.

Pours virtually black into the glass, with a nice deep brown soapy head.  This diminishes as the brew warms, leaving spotty lace.  The nose is of strong Sanka instant coffee, with some dark chocolate brewing in there as well.  The flavors follow much in tow, with a huge java effervescence backed with bittersweet chocolates and a mild bitter hop back that complements the pull.  The mouthfeel is nice, but a bit anemic for the huge roasted contingencies.  I like the brew, but will be a specialty occasion pour for me, as I’m not a coffee drinker... but this, for what it represents, is very, very nice.

Aroma - Dark, bitter coffee beans

Appearance - black coffee, tan head with no lacing

Flavor - coffee coffee coffee!  bitter, black roasted, Some malt comes through at the end

Palate - moderate, not thin, not thick

Overall - I really like the coffee in Dark Lord, but this overwhelmingly coffee, a good beer for sure.

Poured dark with a brown head. Aroma is huge on coffee, chocolate, and roasted malts. Taste was coffee, a big ass dose of coffee. Underneath the coffee was roasted malt, chocolate, some spice, and a hop bite underneath that lingered. Thank the lord I like coffee, otherwise I would hate this beer.

Bottle. Pours a deep brown/black with a hefty tan head that leaves some nice lacing on the side of the glass. Big balanced aroma of coffee, chocolate, some malty/wort aromas. Leads in with a roasted coffee front, chocolate and caramel, a little sweetness in the middle, some dark fruit notes, fades to slightly hop bitter and roast grain astringency. Smooth and incredibly drinkable, low carbonation, with a nice medium to heavy mouthfeel, a little acidic maybe from the coffee, tannic drying. Although this is coffee forward, they integrate it very well into the base stout.
12oz. from the bottle. Flavor is amazing with chocolate, strong coffee, and roasted malt. Wow, if you dont like coffee stay away.
user_location: back in NJ!, New Jersey, USA

text:
this beer is delicious.  Plain and simple.  Deep, dark, and rich.  I feel like I could drink this instead of coffee in the morning.

Another winner from Bells.

Pours black with tan head that slowly diminishes. Aroma is smoky and full of coffee with hints of chocolate. The body is medium to full. The taste is all about coffee. Really nice roasted flavors. with a lingering bitter finish. very nice.
Very good stout.  Small tan head.  Light on the palate which is good for this type of stout.  Nose is chocolate, caramel here and there, and strong coffee.  Really enjoyed this one.  Cheers!

Pours brown with a thin tan head.  Smells of coffee, chocolate, some spicy hints, roasted malt, vanilla.  Tastes sweet and semi bitter with a coffee flavor that is complimentary rather than the dominant feature.  Some dark fruity hints emerge on the finish.  The body on this one is slick.  Very enjoyable beer.
liquorloft tallahassee, strong aroma of fresh ground coffee beans and vanilla. taste is lots of malt and coffee, chalky but pleasant in the finish. lasting coffee roast taste. a great coffee stout.

Pours from the bottle a deep black/ebony color under a 1/2 " dense tan head. Attractive foam retention with creamy, paisley shaped swirls accumulated on the surface. No lacing noted. Aromas nicely show off a rich, dense freshly ground espresso bean presence supported by fainter smells of vanilla bean, dark chocolate and blackstrap molasses. Mouthfeel was great for this beer style being creamy and smooth, but not overtly heavy or thick. Initial flavor starts out bittersweet with notes of dark espresso, semi-sweet chocolate, roasted malts and vanilla cream. Finishes with some mild alcohol warmness and a touch of hop/fresh-brewed coffee bitterness and acidity.  If you’re looking to sample a coffee flavored stout I would say this would be one of the best to try.

Black with tan head, which lasts.  Obvious coffee aromas, which are the dominating force in the taste was well.  Creamier body reflects vanilla and caramel notes as well.  Pretty well organized, bittering hop finish and a nice eye opener of a beer.

Pours black with a light brown head. A very aesthetically pleasing beer. Smells of hot chocolate, caramel coffee and "java coffee".Wow coffee, malt, and that blended coffee drink i can’t think of the name of it oh wait...java. Very good yet slight chalky aftertaste.

Bottle. Pours a very dark brown/black, beautiful light brown head. Aroma is a very nice coffee/espresso. Flavor is in your face coffee, maybe a touch of vanilla hiding in the background. A little too bitter for me, but still a good stout.

Bottle.  Poured a deep black with a brown head.  Aroma of coffee and vanilla.  Flavor was strictly coffee.  I really enjoyed this beer.  Body could stand to be a little heavier.  Carbonation was mild.

Bottle.

I’m usually a big Bell’s fan and usually like the style, but one thing I guess I’m realily sensitive to is the cigarette-ashy flavors that come out in a lot of espresso stouts. This is sticky-sweet syrup poured over cigarette ash, and I simply can’t do it.
A shame.
Bottle. Pours near black with a brown head. Roasted aroma with coffee beans and vanilla. The flavor has roasted malt, espresso, coffee beans, and vanilla. Nice.

Pours a black color with a nice tan head with a little retention. Lots of roasted malts and coffee in the aroma with a creamy scent that blends in nicely. Not all that complex but a very good tasting beer with excellent drinkability. Roasted malty flavor with lots of coffee, as expected, and some milk chocolate, mostly towards the finish. I’d say it’s medium-bodied, creamy, perhaps a shade thin, with light dry bitterness. Nice beer

A black pour with a solid brown head.  Smells like a cup of espresso.  Tasted very roasty, malts and coffee with some mocha or bakers chocolate.  Coffee bitters linger at the finish, but not too bitter.  Alcohol is well hidden, a little warming effect after you get into the beer a bit.  Very pleasant, maybe even better than the Beer Geek in my opinion.
user_location: from Michigan now in Charlotte, North Carolina, USA

text: Pour is a black with a big thick tan head.  Aroma is nice with lots of roasted malts and a nice chocolate.  Flavor is also decent with some roasted nuts burnt malts and some wet hops. The coffee is there but it probably one of the lighter flavors to come out in the beer.  Still this is a decent beer worth looking for.

UPDATED: DEC 28, 2009 Bottle, batch 7706, courtesy of adrian910ss (thanks Adrian!).  Pours a dark inky black with a super pretty dark tan head.  Aroma of coffee, lots of roasted and burnt peanuts, roasted and burnt malts.  Taste is very similar with lots of peanuts, roasted/burnt malts, and coffee icecream.  Not AS coffee-rich as the fresher batch, a bit sweeter and mellower, but still so good.  Smooth drinking.  Not as rich as Expedition, obviously, but its quite good.  Alcohol is a bit strong for a 7.5%.  Otherwise, yumzo!  One of the better stouts Ive had in awhile.  8/5/8/4/16 [4.1/5] 
Update 12/26/2009: Bottle, batch 9363.  Wow, the most noticeable thing about this beer is its awesome aroma.   TONS of coffee, peanut butter, and chocolate, quite pungent (a good thing!).  It smells like a rich dessert ready to be attacked.  Flavor is not quite as in-your-face but it has the same decadent qualities with some charred/burnt malts as well.  This is just an exquisite beer!
10/4/9/4/17  [4.4/5]

Bottle, 8307, which may be the one I received courtesy of sprinkle, or his may be the one that my girlfriend is currently downing. Thanks either way. Now, of the coffee stouts I’ve had so far, this one defines coffee. Every possible aspect of coffee is encapsulated in this beer. Coffee beans, black coffee, roasted coffee, espresso, coffee ice cream, bitter coffee, sweet coffee, charred coffee, etc., etc. All well balanced, great base stout, all that necessary stuff too. Either way, this is a coffee treat. Fun one.

Simply stunning presentation. Pours pitch black and is topped with a deep fluffy chestnut brown head. The alcohol content is apparent in the way the liquid sticks to the sides of the glass. The aroma is full on coffee grounds. The beer is not shy, serving up loads of black coffee and bitter chocolate flavor, with a slick creamy mouthfeel. Sweet but tempered by ample bitterness. Very long aggressive finish.

Black pour with no red in sight.  A late forming dark brown head soon ends in a thn ring.  Very sweet coffee and chocolate defines the nose.  Flavor is coffee and milk chocolate.  It is quite sweet with a dry bitterness.  Very smooth and oily feel to it.  The beer seems to caress the mouth.  Its effervescence lights the tongue up late as the hops show up.  This is a straight forward beer and an excellent stout.

A nice java stout to something that doesn’t like coffee.  Pours very dark brown with dark brown / orange head.  The aroma has a mix of coffee, dark chocolate and roasted malt with coffee being up front, but not killing the other flavors.  Medium / full body that is quite smooth with some gentle carbonation.  The flavor starts with the aroma traits, but a bit richer with some dark caramel notes with a bit of spice and a hint of hops.  The finish has roasty coffee flavors.  Great for the style.
Really liked the Java Stout.  I love coffee and beer so it was right up my alley.  Really smooth and creamy.  Everyone should give this a go.

Bottled.  Pours black with dark brown highlights and a small tan.  Big aroma of coffee and dark chocolate.  More coffee in the flavour plus some bitter chocolate and roasted malt.  Very smooth and creamy mouthfeel.  Good stout and not overdone.

Bottle pour black with a medium tan head. Aroma is sweet with notes of coffee and chocolate. Tasste is semi sweet with aa definate coffee punch with hints of chocolate. Mouthfeel is thick with a good balance of sweet and bitter. Great coffee stout.

Thanks to Sammy for the Trade.  Simply phenomenal.  Medium roasted coffee beans scent.  Perfect black in colour with dark beige lacing head.  Tastes like roasted coffee, no surprise, not as strong as other coffee stouts I’ve tried.  Thick body, bitter finish, lingering lovely aftertaste.  Similar body to the Bell’s Kalamazoo Stout.  Bell’s really knows how to make a stout, and make it well.  Wish I could get some more of this in Toronto.

UPDATED: APR 29, 2010 Thick, tan head- three fingers- slowly fading to half a fingers width. The smell reminds me of a gas station. Subtle dark chocolate and gas station coffee dominate both aroma and taste. Nothing special.

Roasted coffee is the initial aroma.  Espresso to be exact, its very nice.  Also has notes of dark chocolate and malts with slightest hints of vanilla.  Appearance is an interesting one...dark black with a dark tan brown head.  It has carbonation bubbles on the sides, mostly on top and on the bottom.  Flavor is espresso, roasted coffee, and slight hints of chocolate and caramel (roasted).  Palate is extremely smooth and full bodied with aftertaste of a great espresso.  This is a great beer, a great example of why I love Bell’s.

Thick dark brown with rich tan head and lacing. Rich mocha java aromas, especially as it warms. Silky smooth, viscous mouthfeel. Not a lot of roastiness, but very coffee-forward. Packed with flavor without being dense or syrupy. Very nice, very drinkable.

Thanks to Crizay for my dessert coffee fix here.   Pours black with a medium sized tan-khaki head, dissipating somewhat quickly.  Aroma is straight up coffee beens, but more specifically, it’s like going to the bulk department and scooping a bunch of beans into a bag to take home.  That’s the smell.  It’s very earthy with a bit of toffee and dark chocolate, but it’s a strong earth smell more than roast.  Tastes really balanced with dark chocolate, chocolate milk, fresh earthy coffee, dirt, sticks, and toast.  Finishes with a slightly bitter roast, but mainly a smooth earthy taste lingering like buttered toast and lightly charred wood.  Medium bodied and medium carbonation, silky feeling.  Best thing about this is that it’s SO SMOOTH.  Amazingly smooth.  Usually coffee beers are the more abravise breeds of stouts, but this is really really good.  The coffee taste is smooth, earthy and as far from harsh as you can get.  Have I mentioned how smooth this is?  Just effortless.
Poured a jet black from the bottle with a trim head of tan foam.  Brimming with espresso in the aroma and flavor that is blanced with a mild creaminess.  Not ambitious, but highly drinkable.

Bottle @ The Brickskeller.
Black colored brew. Nice aroma of roasted coffee, very intense. Burned coffee in the flavor too. Kinda odd at first, but it’s a nice mixture of the roasted malts and coffee beans. Nice!
Tons of coffee smell & flavor and a creamy mouthfeel. Totally hit the spot on a Sunday morning. Good beer!

12 oz. Bottle.  Cellared for a year.  Pours an inky black with large bubbles and very little foam.  Aroma is intense with a blast of espresso and coffee beans.  Flavor mirrors the aroma to a certain extent and is definitely dominated by the roasted coffee flavors.  Some bittering hops and hints of vanilla behind all the coffee.  The beer feels strongly acidic on the tongue, but the body holds up nicely to mellow out the coffee.  Finishes quickly and leaves a slightly tart lingering sensation.  Having tried a number of "coffee" stouts, this one is about as potently coffee flavored as they get.  Bells has succeeded yet again in making another unique and memorable stout.

This poured black in color with a thin head and there was no hiding the coffee aromas and flavors.  It pretty much dominated the beer which made it rather simple but also well made and balanced.  Medium-bodied and smooth.

Bottle. No doubt about the strong coffee aroma in this, like espresso. Heavy notes of toasted and molasses for the the malt as well, with light dough and earth for the yeast, faint resin for the hops and vanilla in the background. Head is large, rocky, off-white with good lacing and is mostly lasting. Color is black. Flavor starts heavily sweet and finishes moderately sweet and lightly acidic and bitter. Palate is full bodied, between creamy and syrupy, and has a soft, bordering on flat carbonation. It finishes chewy and lightly drying. Im not usually a fan of coffee flavored stuff but the essence of the coffee married well with the other components of this Stout.
A smooth stout, with a great coffee flavor.  What a combination.  Perfect for those cold winter nights.  Too bad I can’t get this out in Colorado.
Smooth, with definate flavors of espresso. Worth trying, not a session beer.

Pous a dark rich creamy brown. Thick cream off white head. Laceing stick to the glass the whole way though the session.  Strong chocolate aroma, but I also get alot of alcohol and pine. Not to much coffee but there is some present. The flavor is alot more mellow then the aroma present. Smooth creamy chocolate and acidity. Toffee and maybe just a hint of coffee. The palate is big and thick. Smooth and well balanced. Not really sure why its called a Java Stout, but it was tasty.
Rich flavor.  Tastes very malty.  Definitely lives up to the name Java Stout.

Taste 7/8 Bottle (batch 8216). Looks: Black and tan. Aroma: Wow! Licorice, Toasted coffee beans,bitter nut. Taste: MMmmm...,acidic, coffee, chocolate. Medium body with a very creamy character. No alcohol in the aroma or the taste. Great brew. Think chocolate covered coffee beans.

Batch #8315  Pours dark.  Big creamy tan head.  Impressive lacing.  Sweet creamy chocolatey flavor.  Too me its more like capuchino then coffee.  Really liked this beer, but really thought of it more of a desset beer.  I’d call it a sweet stout.  Not the kind of beer that you buy of a case of, but definitely another quality Bells brew.
On tap at the Outer Banks Brewing Station. Wonderful aroma of chocolate and coffee. Almost black with a nice tan head that lingers throughout. Very creamy feel going down.

Very dark pour with a very dark tan head.  WOW!  COFFEE!!!!  very roasted character as well.  Good quality fresh coffee beans seemed to have been used for this.  Notices some earthy tones towards the finish with some hop bitterness and then more coffee.  Good brew.  Definitely a morning beer.

Pours out very dark, with a nice tan head leaving a good lacing and plenty of head stays on top. The name says it all, this one definately smells rich of coffee. If you don’t care for coffee, it might be too strong, but to me it smells awesome. Taste starts with a bit of coffee, and then some sort of green flavor comes in, not strong, but I can only seem to describe it as fresh vegetables straight from the garden, then the taste shifts back into a bitter chocolate flavor before joining back up with the coffee for a choco-coffee finish. Med-high carbonation, thin little bubbles bounce around on the tongue, light bodied and pretty dry. Mouthfeel doesn’t say Double Stout, says more Irish Dry Stout to me. I imagine this would be nice just about any time during the day, breakfast would fit in well with this, but it becomes a bit cloying by the end, one bottle would be enough. Definately worthy of a try and I could see myself having more, but probably wouldn’t break my regular lineup.
Poured a nice opaque black color with a tan head. Aroma was of coffee and spices. Flavor was of a little coffee and some strange spicey, almost a chile beer flavor, very strange.

12 oz bottle...Thank You Daknole!....Dark brown sugar head, dark dark brown body--almost mistook as black...Aroma is a fresh bag of whole bean coffee...bitter like Blue Mountain beans...after sitting less than 3 minutes, a sweetness enters the nostrils...so far a true coffee experience....fresh beans--then they are ground--cream is added--so far this is all before I have sipped it--ah the coffee is being created in my mind, now to taste-->Body is silky and smooth, rich and full, sweet, but not too sweet...coffee coffee and coffee...a bitterness in the finish--this beer defines coffee to me...dense and intense...lacing is dotted but sticks--overall balanced and easy to drink , yet it lingers on every taste bud...a wonderful caffeinated alcholated created beverage...palate nice, low carbonation--an alcohol infused coffee, but so much more,,,yum yum and yum I could drink this in the morning b4 the job...:)

Boooya! Pours black with a sexy brown head. Aroma is of coffee and a hint of chocolate. The taste is awesome because it reminds me of black coffee, not hazelnut or vanilla or what have you. Very delicious.

Bottle thanks to EithCubes. Pours a dark black with a nice frothy beige head. The aroma was mostly a rich and great cup of joe. The taste was quite full and very smooth; tons of slightly bitter coffee beans and some rich burnt coffee/malts. Also, their is a sweet plum and chocolate aspect that balances it out. Very nice. What I expect from Bells-quality.

can you say coffee?  scent is very coffeeee.  taste of coffee bean and burnt roast.  a slight hint of chocolate.  The coffee taste is a little overwelming, so I would probably not purchase this again.  it is still a well constructed beer with good complexity.

12 oz bought from the brewery in a mixed sixer.  Batch 8151.  Pours a delightful dark chocolate/coffee color with a short, creamy head that lasts throughout the brew with reasonable lacing.  For me, the taste is wonderful for I am a coffee lover in addition to my love for beer.  The dark, rich coffee flavor blends well with the light notes of chocolate and decent amount of malts, all hiding the alcohol taste quite well.  The malts actually gives me a hazelnut feel on the palate, which I truly dont mind.  I was pretty impressed with this one, though Bells rarely disappoints.

If you are a coffee lover then this the beer for you. The aroma is pure java and the rest the feel of the beer is soft yet yet has some carbonation where it counts.  taste is nice espresso and the malts take a back seat, but in this case it is worth it.

The aroma is burnt, but like coffee, malt, and a hint of smoke. The appearance is dark dark brown with a tan head. The flavor is nice if you like 7/11 coffee but I am not a fan. The palate is smooth. Overall its a disappointment.

Yum yum!  Tasted at Ezras tasting of Imp Stouts.  Poured a dark brown-black body with a rocky tan head.  All about the coffee in the nose.  A little vanilla and some chocolate on the palate, but just powering through with deep dark malts and coffee.  As usual, a great Bells brew.  Finished with a dry coffee bite.  Nice work.

12oz bottle and cask at R/R. This review is more the bottle than the cask. Pours a dark brown with a nice tan head. Huge aromas of coffee and dark chocolate. Really nice coffee nose on this beer. The flavor is a bit disappointing because its so one dimensional. There are some nice vanilla notes that come through. But mostly its black coffee with a hint of chocolate. On cask this is a much better beer, its very smooth. I cant believe I forgot to do this review back when I had it. Alot of the bitterness is replaced by a balanced smoothness and some hints of cardamom. Being cask I think it also benefits from the decreased carbonation.A very good stout.

12oz.  Yowsah.  What can I say, this was way more java than I had expected.  Pours black with a brown head that fades over time.  Nose is chocolate covered coffee bean.  Body is strikingly sweet.  I started drinking this slightly chilled and could barely stomach it, it was just so over powering coffee liqueur.  DRINK THIS AT ROOM TEMPERATURE.  By letting it warm up, the sweetness subsides a bit and more complexity in the roasted flavors comes through to balance out the sweetness.  Smooth mouthfeel and a semi-dry finish.  That was a close one, and first glance I thought I was going to have to give Bells a bad review.

12 oz bottle at the BA Speedway line tasting (provider unknown). Poured a dark black color with a big tan head. The aroma really blew me away, it was rich with pepper and spices layered over complex coffees. The taste did not quite live up to the nose, it was loaded with good coffee flavors but the spiciness of the nose never really materialized in the taste. Still this is a relatively small complaint, this was a superbly drinkable concoction. The mouthfeel was smooth and creamy. The flavor was long with lingering mocha. Overall: I loved it. One of the best stouts anywhere ever.

I hate to say it but Ive done so many trades lately I cant remember who sent this to me but thanks

Bottle poured into a tulip produced a good finger worth of tan head that goes to a nice ring of lace all on top of a black body 

Aromas of coffee filled my nose along with nice malt sweetness

The coffee flavor is great the malt keeps it from being to bitter nice smooth mouthfeel not much carbonation 

Great drinking coffee stout it be a great brunch brew

Bottle. Dark brown with a frothy head. Big java mocha espresso aroma with blackened malts. Medium body and smooth. Strong black coffee/espresso and bitter bakers chocolate flavors without much sweetness.  This beer was better on tap.
user_location: Same Trailer, Different Park, Louisiana, USA

text: Bottle; poured a dark brown/black with a small brown head.  Aroma was heavy on the coffee with some dark chocolate elements.  Flavor was heavy on the coffee.  Not big on coffee, but after a bit, it wasnt so dominating.  More roasted and chocolate notes began to show.  Overall it was a little one dimensional for my liking.  Would have liked something to help balance the coffee flavors.
Oh yeah.  Coffee big time but a sweet finish that balances wonderfully.  Bells = best brewery in America.

Nice mahogany body with quarter thin latte head.  Aroma does exhibit expected deep roasted kona coffee beans & dark chocolate.  Flavor is rich on the gulp with lingering coffee bitterness.  Good body in this one...thick enough to coat, thin enough to avoid coagulation.

Poured a dark brown almost black color with a thin, bubbly tan head that settled quickly. This had a huge roasted coffee smell wih a little bit of chocolate in there as well. The taste was much the same with a big roasted coffee flavor with a touch of dark chocolate and sweet cream. The roasty coffee flavors really stand out in this one. The mouthfeel is medium bodied with a roasted bitter finish from the coffee. This one is easy to drink, but maybe a touch too much coffee and not enough body to be a great stout. Another solid offering from Bells though.

Pours black with minor off-white/tan head. Nose is dominated by bitter coffee. Flavor is more balanced with sweet chocolate notes and bitter coffee still present. A sweet but slightly dry and bitter finish. Creamy beer with some nice flavors that I personally like, but overall, not very interesting and kind of plain.

yep another winner from the folks at Bells.  Delicious.  Coffee is the primary aroma and flavor.  The only downside is that the coffee flavor reminds me of instant coffee...but the beer is great, especially as it warms up.

Good Java Stout. Aroma is coffee - smells somewhat like burnt coffee as opposed to freshly brewed, but what do you expect? With a coffee nose this strong, you get the good and the bad. Has almost a tobacco-ish smokey flavor. Pours black with tan head, very little carbonation.

Bottle.  Pours a dark brown body with a tan head.  Aroma is burnt coffee, roasty coffee, chocolate, and some etoh.  Flavor over emphasizes the burnt coffee flavor.  A little creamier would have made for a more enjoyable experience.

Cask @ redlight redlight.  Rich coffee aromas, dark chocolate, strong roasty aromas.  Pours black with a thick dark brown head. Very smooth, with strong coffee flavors, rich espresso, dark chocolate, sweet vanilla finish.   Very smooth and delicious.
Very dark with a head thats not much lighter than the body itself! Very rich deep espresso flavor. Very unique beer and great for the coffee lover!

Pours a very dark brown, nearly black, with just a ring of light brown head. Delicious aroma of roasted black coffee, peat, and chocolate. Taste is true to the smell if a little sweeter at first with the chocolate. The body is then very smooth and the finish really drags out the coffee and heavily roasted malt flavor.
Bottle,  Lovely tasting beer.  Strong coffee tones.  Super dark color with an awsome smell.  Dark tan long lasting lacing head.  This is an extremely unique tasting beer.  One of my favorite.

UPDATED: MAY 12, 2008 Bottle thanks to Hellbilly.  Black with decent tan head.  Burnt roasted aroma of coffee and some molasses/chocolate goodness and a hint of black olive/licorice.  Sweet taste with really strong black coffee bitterness.  Medium bodied.  My type of coffee stout.

Courtesy of Quake1028. Pours dark dark brown with light brown head. The aroma is coffee, a hint of chocolate mixed with bosco, spicy mustard sauce and mild roasty malts. The taste is somewhat different than the aroma with rich malts, chocolate and coffee. Wow, this is rich and nearly decadent in its opulence. Into the finish mild burnt malts and malt astringency add some balance to the experience. It has a healthy dose of YUM.

On tap.  Dark thick black with no head to speak of.  Powerful flavor of roasted coffee nicely balanced with a bittersweet chocolate presence.  This was very good, but also very rich, no more than 1 at a time for me.
Only the second coffee stout Ive tried.  With that said, this beer is great.  Robust malts and it finishes pretty clean.  Think chocolate-covered espresso beans.  Great after dessert.

From bottle : Pours a totally black color, with a finger and a half of light brown mocha colored frothy head.  Sticky lacing around the glass.  Big time coffee aroma, and thats about all im getting.  Very thick, dark, rich chocolate and coffee taste.  Thick and smooth, with a big roasted coffee bean aftertaste.  Very different then other stouts, almost like a liquid chocolate candy bar with coffee beans in it.  Good stuff.

Pitch black poor with a bubbly yet foamy light brown head with good lacing.  Aromas of coffee, bitter dark chocolate and roasted malts.  Medium bodied with a good bitter mouthfeel... Sweet at first, bitter is longlasting.  Strong coffee flavors with chocolate hints and alcohol.  Not the best coffee stout ive tasted but still a great experience.

Dark reddish-brown with a brown head.  Aroma of chocolate and very strong coffee beans.  Strong mocha flavor with heavy coffee aftertaste that lingers for a long, long time.  Also some sweetness from sweet malts to balance it out.  Pretty solid stout yet again from Bells.

Pours jet black with small tan head. Aroma is ground coffee, bitter chocolate, some faint hops. Tastes of strong coffee, dark chocolate, smoke, Thick and creamy body: tastes just like youd imagine a coffee beer hybrid would taste.

Pours a murky black with a nice thick broan head and some lacing. Aroma is very, very coffee, slightly metallic, touch of hops. Tastes of strong ash, opening up into potent campfire coffee, roasty and smoky. Warm, hoppy finish. Carb is low, but body is thick and creamy. Very nice beer, many thanks to SoLan for the trade!

bottle courtesy of nick76.  pours an opaque black with a creamy tan head.  aroma is full of coffee and bitter chocolate.  the flavor is rich of roasted coffee, chocolate syrup, and hints of fruit.  such a fine brew... if only Bells were distributed in Oregon.

Bottle pours a pitch black color with a thin brown head.  Very nice lacing that clings to the side of the glass and just lingers there.  Robust aroma of roasted coffee beans and rich dark chocolate.  Flavor is cofffee, roasted malts,  and bittersweet dark chocolate.  Just the right amount of bitterness in the long lasting aftertaste.  Wouldnt have guessed it is 7.5% as it is extremely smooth.
Pours black with minimal brown head. Powerful roasted coffee aroma with just a bit of malty sweetness. Sweet and roasted coffee flavors. One dimensional but it is what its supposed to be.

Smells like coffee, but not exactly fresh coffee. Very dark brown color with a tan ring for head. Near medium in body with fizzy carbonation. Flavor is coffee, with a hint of some sort of liqeur. Toasted/burnt malt notes. Not sure I am tasting chocolate, but could be. Finshes something like coffee with a bit of sugar. Quite different, and very pleasant.

This would go great with my eggs and toast.  Aroma smells heavily of coffee.  Pours dark black with a thin tan head.  Taste leans towards coffee with a hint of beer/alcohol in the background.  Finish is bitter and crisp.
Dark pour;heavy coffee aroma, also a sharp, unidentified aroma. Flavor is dominated by coffee. A bit overwhelming in the bitterness/coffee aspect.

Pint from cask at Oldsmar Tap House.  Black with lasting light brown head and lace.  Espresso and chocolate aroma.  Espresso and espresso and espresso flavor with mild fruitiness and coffee bitterness in finish.  Full body and low carb (from cask) make for  excellent mouthfeel.  An excellent beer but should probably be served in a  coffee cup.

Like drinking the best cold coffee Ive ever had, with many pleasantries of beer (i.e. carbonation, mild sweetness, and a good creamy texture)
Ive had a few coffee stouts, and generally theyre pretty good beers, but this is exceptional.

wow. da bomb. extreme coffee stout. sitting at the bar sampling it and talking with another patron and we agree that while its such a bold coffee stout there are no bad parts; indeed only good. The finish is like espresso. They have acheived a perfect balance for such a beer. Poured opaque black with tan head and good lace. Huge volatile nose of malt and dark roast coffee. Looooong finish. Would go great with chocolate. Having a mug of this at Bodega brew Pub downtown La Crosse, Wis. Usa.
Six pack purchased at Bells.  Perfect mix of coffee to stout gives this a rich, chocolately, coffee flavor.  If I were able to drink one of these for breakfast each morning, I just might.  :-)

Bottle. Black color, opague, dark head. Coffee and cacao in the aroma. Malty sweet flavor with some citric tartness, coffee, milk chocolate and licorice. Creamy mouthfeel. Very tasty stout, but also an easy drinker. Not a sign of its alcohol noticeable.

Bottle from hopdog. Black beer with a thin tan head that went away quickly. Aroma is that of roasted malt with the ever so slightest sweetness. Nice dry roasted flavor, coffee beans, light chocolate too. Pretty damned good stuff here. Awesomely drinkable. I want more.

UPDATED: OCT 23, 2009 Dark pour with somewhat disappointing head.  Bittersweet chocolate is as dominant as coffee on the nose, and I got a ton of cinnamon and brown sugar as well.  This was much sweeter than I remember the first time, but every bit as bitter/roasty, and in a good way.  Great aftertaste.  A really good beer, and nice that its not too strong on the ABV.  A favorite.

sampled at the Cobblestones in York, PA: Poured black with brown around the edges.  Aroma was sweet brown sugar, with lots of coffee and chocholate, just smelled delicious.  Flavor was even better, tasted like a gourment coffee with just the right amount of sugar and cream.  unbelieable creaminess to this beer, that melds together so well with the roastiness of the stout and the bitterness of the coffee.  good full mouthfeel  this is an excellent beer.

12 oz bottle from Gregis. Batch 7768 - (packaged on December 21, 2006). Pour is deep brown with only faint ruby highlights, smallish tan head. Aroma of musty charred wood, smoke, perhaps a bit of milkiness. Taste of milky caramel sweetness, and the charred coffee taste behind.  There is some bitterness on the finish. Body is somewhat syrupy and mouth coating.  This reminded me of the Bells Double Cream Stout, though a bit flatter and a lot less soft.  If I see this a bit fresher, I may give it another try.  Thanks for giving me this beer, Greg.

(USA) Dark brown color with a med-tan head. There is a roasted espresso / chocolate aroma with a folgers or maxwell house taste. I think it has a slight bitter finish, but a well bodied brew !!!  This one is recommended. And another cool thing is the artwork on the bottle.

Pours out dark brown with a slight tan head. Aroma is of coffee, roasted malt and slight chocolate. Taste is complex coffee, roasted malt, slight hop. Coffee isnt overpowering and neither are the hops. Very well balanced.

12oz bottle at Nikos Restaurant, Lebanon, PA...pours very dark with minimal tan head...sweet malty aroma with coffee and chocolate...favor is like a cold glass of hopped up espresso, dry, slightly bitter with a hint of semi-sweet chocolate...I really enjoyed this one.

Opaque ruby body with a small tan head.  Aroma of bitter bakers chocolate and roasted malts.  Flavor is full but not overpowering, with rich roasted espresso, sweet chocolate, and a good dose of hoppiness.  The palate is dry and tangy with a dry, bitter finish.  Alcohol is barely evident.  Very well done!

This beer pours a very dark black, with basically no head.  The aroma is of chocolate and coffee.  It reminds me a little of tobacco.  The taste is really good.  It tastes very chocolatey, balanced with some roasted coffee astringency and no noticeable hop flavor or aroma.  It is full bodied.  I would like to try the beer without the coffee added to see exactly what it brings to the party other than novelty.  The only thing that could improve this beer would be a thick head!

Pours a deep dark brown with tannish mocha head. Aroma is coffee grounds and little else. Flavor is folgers medium sweet coffee, light grapefruit and roasted malt. Medium to body, creamy texture. Really expected more out of this one ala Southern Tier Coffee Stout.

Pours into a dark coffee with a light tan head.  No lacing.  Dark chocolate is the dominant flavor with hints of coffee.  Goes down rather smoothly.  Bitterness is not overwhelming and similar to that of coffee.  Tasty stuff.

This pours jet black with a dissipating brown tan head.  It just reeks of coffee, but I love my morning coffee and am okay with that.  The flavor though is all coffee, which I again am mostly okay with.  But it seems like its so much coffee that the beer is just completely unbalanced.  I almost think Im drinking a cold cup of coffee instead of a beer as a matter of fact.  But finishes with a nice coffee bitter, which I do enjoy.  Tasty beer, but there are better coffee beers out there.
A great balance of the stout and Coffee. Nither over powers the other. Another hit from Bells

if it were socially acceptable id have one of these in the morning everyday.  really bold with the amount of coffee.  pours pitch black with a great head.  aroma and taste stick together in this not too complicated just up-front coffee stout.  delicious.
Bells Java Stout is a pitch dark stout beer with a great mocha head. The aroma is coffee and the taste fully mimics the aroma. This is a fantastic coffee stout.

UPDATED: JUN 5, 2008 Bottle. Pours a dark brown with red highlights. Big, cottony, tan-like thick head. Constant lacing on the glass. Big roasted coffee in the nose. The malts are prevalent and very roasted. A bit of a smoky quality, too. Very rich. Flavor has coffee everywhere. Soft, creamy malts, with chocolate and caramel coalescing in unison. Some raisin, too. Nice vanilla finish. Medium-body. Very drinkable, and well-balanced. A very enjoyable brew.
Good solid stout. Bells doesnt dissapoint. Quality coffee + stout = mmmmmmmmm

bottle.  Aroma is nice roasted coffee malt with notes of licorice, dark fruit essence, and chocolate.  Dark ruby/black hue with a nice tan head that left good lace.  Flavor is roasted coffee, licorice, chocolate.  Nice finish with a good coffee linger.  Palate is smooth and medium bodied.  Fantastic brew, Ive impressed many a coffee lover with this stout.  A classic.

UPDATED: APR 25, 2008 Poured a nice deep black with a thin, light brown head. The aroma is of coffee, chocolate and licorice. The flavor is roasted malts paired with a slightly sour/abrasive coffee chocolate flavor. I must say that all the right flavors are there, they just arent executed as well as they could be. Overall the flavors, despite their individual shortcomings match up nicely to create a pretty round, mellow taste. The palate is good for the style, but not outstanding. Overall a good beer. Only my second coffee brew, and I have to say that I think I prefer Surlys Coffee Bender, but again, another great beer from Bells.

12oz bottle, batch 8216. Pours a dark black with a nice foamy, light brown head.  Nice lacing. Aroma is cocoa and coffee.  Palate is mainly coffee, but that weird instant folders coffee and/or coffee grounds flavor, with a bit chocolate malt.  Fairly thin mouth feel. Not my favorite Bells product. BUT IM AWAKE!!!
Pours black with a small brown head into a snifter. Aroma of roasted malts and coffee. Coffee is very dominate with hints of chocolate and hints of smoke. Bitter finish. Overall I enjoyed it.

12 oz. bottle courtesy of Secret Santa.  Pours black with a moderate tan head that lasted until about mid-glass.  The aroma is totally dominated by coffee.  Coffee is also the dominating component in the flavor, along with a fairly strong flavor of burnt toast.  Acidic coffee bitterness at the finish.  Very one dimensional and lacks depth.  Medium bodied. A disappointing coffee stout in my book.

Bottle.  Pours black with a brown head.  The aroma is roasted coffee.  The taste is dominated by roasted malt, bitter, strong, and burnt.  Its good, but I was looking for more from Bells on this one.

Cask at Redlight Redlight. Pours a deep brown with a thick dark tan head. Huge chocolate, cocoa aroma. Medium body. Taste is thick dry chocolate and cocoa and roasted malt. I think I would like this as a desert beer more than anything.

Pours a nice black color with a tan head. Coffee is definitely what this beer is all about. Dark chocolate comes through as well. The only thing I dont like is that the coffee flavor tastes a bit old and burnt... as if you accidentally left your coffee brewing for way too long and forgot about it. Not a bad offering by Bells, but far from their best.

Pours black with small brown head. Aroma is of coffee grounds after the water has gone through them. Taste is coffee hitting you up front with chocolate and bitterness in the middle, and more coffee and bitterness hitting up the aftertaste.
12 oz bottle. Black with a dark tan head. Big roasted malt aroma with a hint of coffee. Flavor is strongly coffee with some malt bitterness at the end.
black pour with a thin layer of froth.  huge roasted malts and coffee on the nose.  it tastes more like a black coffee with some alcohol.
Strong black color with a slight head once poured. Tastes of strong black coffee. Great brew for anyone that likes to explore java stouts.

UPDATED: MAR 5, 2008 Smells exactly like you expect. Very strong black coffee smell. Smells like you just walked into a coffee shop. Dark black with a small head that dissapates to a slight film of bubbles. Taste is like a strong dark coffee. Really good and interesting, just what you would expect from Bells.

Draft...more java than stout, really. Thick, chalky and bitter, it really tastes more like a mouthful of iced coffee, which if you like that youll like this. Alcohol slightly noticeable. I would much prefer an imperial stout over this.

I have decided that I realy dont enjoy coffee stouts.  At first they seemed unque and now the light has faded.  the coffe in this brew was less orusive than most but still the acrid bitterness of coffee turns the beer taste into a wash of mixed unbalance.  Thanks to slob for helping me decide this.
from vintagecellars.com  Black with a light brown foamy head.  Chocolate and chipotle pepper (Is that just my tumor acting up?) aroma.  Chocolate and coffee taste with pepper to the finish.

Bouteille 12oz, courtoisie de Hogtownharry. De couleur noire et opaque. Nez malté de chocolat noir, de café, moyen de malt rôti, léger de houblon herbeux et avec des petites notes de chocolat au lait (notes lactiques). Moyenne-ronde en bouche avec un pétillement moyen et une texture riche et crémeuse. Petites notes de chocolat au lait et de crème (notes lactiques) avec de faibles traces de tabac et de fruits (prunes et dates) lors de lentrée en bouche auquel se rajoute rapidement un goût moyennement amer de chocolat noir ainsi quun goût de malt rôti puis progressivement le goût de café vient se joindre au goût pour dominer en finale, accompagné dun léger goût de houblon assez herbeux (petites notes terreuses et boisées aussi perceptibles en toute fin). Post-goût très long aux notes sèches et moyennement amer de café espresso, de rôti, moyen de chocolat et léger de houblon herbeux avec des notes de chocolat au lait.

One of the best coffee stouts I have enjoyed.  Opaque brown in the glass with thin light brown head.  Strong aroma of chocolate, milk, and chocolate.  Very malty with a full every forward coffee taste.  A very robust, rich, and enjoyable coffee flavor.  Lingering roast bitterness and a medium body.

Pours a big, thick, dark brown head. Lots of roasted coffee aroma. Big taste, especially the coffee elements. Great body though. It doesnt stay in the mouth as long as youd expect. Nice suble alcohol flavor for the abv.

Dark chocolate covered espresso beans all the way!  Pours deep and dark with a tan head.  Thick and rich.  Flavor is strong, cold espresso, bitter chocolate, and roasted malt.  Wonderful collaboration of flavors...however, you have to have a strong affinity for coffee.  Aroma and flavor of espresso is overwhelming.  The chocolate is a great second fiddle.  The flavors meld harmoniously.  Smooth, silky feel with a light bite.

pours a dark, dark opaque brown with a light brown head.  aroma of green coffee beans, some bitter chocolate, some brown sugar spice notes.  taste is coffee city with some greenery, bitter chocolate, dark bitter fruit.  mid-full bodied with a heavy, creamy mouthfeel.  motor-oil look to this one.  very nice, im actually surprised its not an imperial.  this one might get better with age.  remniscent of southern tiers jah-va imperial stout.  very, very nice, will definitely try again!

UPDATED: FEB 24, 2008 This is quite an amazing beer and is extreme with the coffee.  Everything about this beer, the aroma, the taste, is about coffee.  Smells as if you have your nose in a bag of beans and it coats the palate in the same fashion.  The coffee lingers on your tongue long after the beer is gone.  If this beer was a little thicker and a tad bit smoother on the back end it could be the best beer ever.  Try the Barley Island for another good Java Stout (it is less strong with the coffee bean flavor).

Nice aroma of coffee, roasted malt, dark chocolate, touch of molasses, light milk chocolate.  Poured into the Pint very dark, with a large foamy dark tan head, that slowly became a thick creamy cap. Left thick lacing on glass.  Strong, but pleasant coffee flavor with a nice bitter dark chocolate flavor, light touch of milk chocolate and a slightly burnt roasted malt flavor.  While bitter, it wasnt overpowering, just a nice robust flavor. 
Nice full body that is very, very creamy, very enjoyable, very smooth.  Carbonation is slightly stronger than average.  A long pleasant bitter finish, that wasnt overpowering but nicely robust.  I enjoyed this beer quite a bit. I am not a big coffee stout fan, although I love stouts.  But, this is one I will definitely have again!  It is a very fine beer by Bells, which always seems to put out very good brews.  If you like coffee stouts definitely give this one a try. If you like strong coffee, strong dark chocolate, definitely give this atry. If you like stout also give it a try.  Very good job by Bells!
Well I fully understand why its called a Java stout!  Terrific aroma and flavor!  Dark with orange/brown head.  Goes does very smooth...another fantastic Bells beer!!

12 oz bottle thanks TikiE.  Poured a weird looking dark tan head, then went to a light tan head as it faded away.  Aroma of roast, coffee and bitter chocolate.  This beer is very well balanced, not to much of anything for a coffee stout.  Notes of roast, coffee and chocolate also in the taste.  Clean mouthfeel of a decent carbonation.  Its defenetly a Bells, this beer impressed me.  I expected less, I would drink this again.
Dank! Smells and tastes of beautiful coffee and chocolate. Got it at our local beer and wine shop, and it was definitly worth the purchase. Love it!

Perfect blend of chocolate and roasted malts, this excellent beer with the awful label art is one of the finest examples of a coffee stout Ive encountered.
Bells has got to be considered one of the best breweries in the country.

Pours black with a decent tan head.  Sweet, roasted aroma with huge notes of coffee.  Roasty flavor at first giving way to a sweeter taste on the tongue with bitter coffee and hops lingering on the way down.  Fairly smooth on the tongue, but I expect more from a Bells beer.  Still, very enjoyable if you like coffee.

Pours out a dark cola, with minimal head. Nose if a mix of sweet malt and an dark espresso. Taste- sweet milk chocolate, medium roasted coffee and slight bit of lactic sourness on the finish. Hops are also noticeable on the finish. Medium bodied and moderate carbonation. Drinkability is high and overall a very tasty stout.

Aug. 2006 - Maybe I need to have this again when my allergies arent killing me...but I was disappointed in this one. Pour was dark and beautiful...one finger head and decent lacing. Aroma was fairly faint...dark roast and coffee. The flavor was much of the same. Fairly smooth mouthfeel, but not thick. Flavor was pleasant, coffee and roasted malts, but kind of watery. Just not strong enough to make a great impression.

Cant believe I am just getting a chance to try this bellweather bells beer.  Exceptional roasted malt flavors.  Aroma of roasted coffee.  Flavors of bittersweet chocolate, and rich coffee bean. The finish is slighlty bitter and acidic with a medium body.  The taste is the corresponding sense you get when you walk into a coffee shop and they are grinding beans and brewing a fresh pot at the same time.  That aroma of roasted bean just floors you.  Translate that aroma to taste and thats what this beer is.  Oh yeah, thanks to eithcubes for the first in hopefully a number of trades.

Another winner from bells... pours black, with a mocha latte head that sticks around for most of the glass.  Aroma is delicious smelling... coffee with dark chocolate.  The coffee flavors really bring out the chocolate flavors of the stout.  This would be a great breakfast beer!  Or after dinner.  Im not sure this would be a session beer of any sort, but it is a winner all around.

pours a very opaque black with a tan head that lingers slightly... Aroma of bitter chocolate... Taste of dark roasted bitter coffee with a hint of sweet chocolate... If all coffee tasted like this.... This is waaaayyyyy too easy to drink for a 7.5% stout...

on tap at kellys.  poured opaque black with a thick tan head that faded slowly and left some lacing here and there.  huge bitter coffee aroma, maybe some dark berries hiding in the background, then some coffee came out some more, and i could smell a bit more coffee.  big roasty coffee flavor, with some cocoa, vanilla, and cherry notes.  a bit more coffee flavor, as well.  fairly bitter, as one might expect, some sweetness in there as well, good silky mouthfeel, lots of carbonation.  there certainly was a lot of coffee flavor.  as im not a coffee drinker, it was all a bit overdone for me.  i much prefer mikkeller beer geek breakfast, and founders breakfast.  not horrible, just not for me.

If you had a six pack of the Java youd be buzzed and hyper all at the same time.  The coffee taste though listed as Sumatra must have been roasted darker than a Sumatran coffee is usually roasted.  If youre looking for a stout with a coffee taste, BAM heres the Java Stout from good old Bells.
12oz bottle. Drank luke warm which may have affected the review. Sweet bold coffee taste paired with a strong solid malt backround. Color was black as can be. smokey

Cant decide on the after dinner drink: coffee or a rich stout...this one is both. Both tastes come out evenly making this an instant favorite. The color is dark opaque black and the bitterness of the coffee bean combined with the rich roasted stout comes across nice - not too strong

Poured a very dark, opaque brown into a snifter. 2 finger cocoa colored head leaves some decent lacing and reduces to a thin cap on top of the beer. 

Very chocolatey aroma, some notes of coffee and a biscuity oaty note. 

Mainly coffee in the taste, backed up by chocolate syrup flavors as well as that biscuity note from the smell. Similar to Terrapins Wake-n-Bake. 

The body here is kinda flimsy for a stout. Carbonation is fine, no alcohol taste. Easy to drink.
This relatively low rating is mostly based on the fact I just dont like coffee.  Smells like coffee beans.  Too much coffee for me though.
Bottle.  Good coffee stout.  nice amount of roasted malt and some chocolate.

Tap @ Barleys Taproom Asheville, NC. Pours balck with a one finger tan head that leaves good lacing. Aroma of coffee, roasted malt, chocolate, and caramel. Taste is the same as aroma. Medium full creamy mouthfeel with a mild to moderate amount of bitterness. Very good.

b;ack pour with a medium  bubbly brown head...head disapate quickly...aroma of coffee grounds and mocha....extreme bitter black coffee taste...roasted malts...thick mouthfeel....some charcole and nuts ..... barbeque and coffee....thick mouthfeel...some smoke...great stout

Dark black body and a very active tall froth of a head that leaves soap like lacing on the sides of the glass.  Naturally coffee aromas come through and perhaps a note of pepper as well.  Nice sweetness balances well with the roasted coffee flavors and overall is quite smooth.  Much like a mocha drink with the chocolate flavors coming through.

UPDATED: APR 30, 2009 BIG turnaround. Had this twice, didnt care for it either time. Tried it a couple months later and WOW. Dont know if the first bottles I had were bad or (more likely) I just have grown to like coffee in my beer more. If you like coffee, this one is the best thing going. Nice aroma, creamy texture, and tons of coffee flavor. Delicious!

Pours an inviting yet not-quite-robust brown and drinks smokey and sinful like your ex-girlfriends Dinty Moore Stew chute. Similar to Bells Expedition Stout yet its only 7.5% and, at $8.99 plus tax for a sixer, quite a bit cheaper. When I drink this I cant but help wish Id be having Bells Expedition Stout but still, if you cant get that, this is a nice substitute.
Really significant coffee aroma and flavor. Smokey and dark, with an earthy almost ashy palate.  Dark chocolate definitely present.  As usual, a good offering from Bells.

12 oz bottle.  Dark brown with a toasty tan head.  Nose is grape jelly and coffee.  Starts with a strong acid-carb bite; a bit lactic.  Body is a silky medium.  Holds up well to the opening tongue assault.  Plums, dates and some chocolate give way to a hoppy coffee that intensifies as it dries.  Different kind of stout; points for creativity.
Pours coffee black with thick creamy dark brown head.  Immense coffee aroma with hints of dark chocolate.  Flavor of strong black coffee with nice dark chocolate bitters.
Bottle at Eccentric Cafe.  Thought it was decent-- but not anywhere as smooth and tasty as Founders Breakfest Stout.  Coffee flavor is not overbearing.

07 Bottle:  Viscous black pour with a medium-sized creamy, tan head.  Massive coffee aroma...shocking!  Unsweetened bakers chocolate, dark malt and pipe  tobacco notes present as well.  Medium-full bodied, silky mouth feel.  Flavor follows suit, yet its sweeter than I expected.  This is a very satisfying stout and unlike any other that Ive tasted.  This would be a perfect brew to pair with a cigar.
A lot of coffee in this one. There is also caramel sweetness here to balance out the bitterness of the coffee/malt, but there is slightly too much for my bitterness loving tongue.

Bottle, batch 8151.  Pours a thick, black, opaque body with brown head.  Aroma consists of coffee and roasted malt.  Strong roasted coffee flavors with some earthiness, ash, and cocoa.  Finishes with a burnt malt and bitter coffee aftertaste.  Smooth, full-bodied mouthfeel.

UPDATED: FEB 7, 2008 batch 7768 bottle. viscous black pour topped with a frothy tan head. it fades slowly and leaves a bit of lace work. ashy aroma is full of spent wet coffee grounds and earth. a mild astringent flavor of highly roasted malts is combined with wood, chocolate and coffee sourness. theres something else in there as well... unfamiliar and indescribable. its not wood or roast but something vegetal almost stale. its not completely unpleasant... just distracting and strange. medium body with a creamy mouth feel from the carbonation.7/4/6/3/15=3.5

batch 8216. near black pour is almost opaque. its topped by a fluffy beige head which leaves some spotty lacing.  the aroma is whole coffee beans, lacto, grain roastiness and wood. the flavor is woody and chocolate along with so much coffee that it is almost sour. the roasted grains are smoky and almost ashy. dry finish and enduring coffee aftertaste. light to medium bodied with a creamy texture. 7/4/8/3/15=3.7

Appearance: Pours a black body with a lush, though brief, light khaki-colored head.

Smell: Lightly chocolatey aroma with a bit of molasses and the strong scent of stale coffee. Theres a vague fruitiness there as well which doesnt really carry over into the taste.

Taste: Sweet, rich chocolate flavor with some sugar laced coffee. Then a roastiness arises and begins to build alongside an earthy bitterness. Eventually, the taste goes to burnt malts and scorched coffee, long ago abandoned in a glass pot on the burner. Starts off good but goes downhill quick.

Mouthfeel: Medium-bodied. Medium carbonation. Silky mouthfeel.

Drinkability: Decent enough, but outshone by some of the other coffee stouts available.

Bottle. Oh thats some serious coffee. Complete darkness with a thin dark tan head. The nose is all coffee and in a good way. The flavor again has a lot of that coffee shining through, but its a bit too much sour bitterness...something like youd get from cheap coffee brewed too strongly. A good, very smooth beer, but that sourness felt out of place and kept it from being really great.
Bottle: Great aroma of coffee and roasted malt.  Not much chocolate.  Flavor same as aroma, but a touch too bitter.  Pretty good.  Will try again to see if better.
UPDATED: FEB 15, 2008 Bottle.  Thick black pour with espresso like crema on top.  Heavy coffee aroma.  Looks and tastes like espresso.

Tap at Blind Tiger.  Pitch black with a thick dark brown head.  Aroma is loaded with coffee aroma.  Lightly vegetal over a lot of chocolatey malts as well.  Aroma comes across as a little salty and leathery with heavy roastiness.  Flavour is intensely roasty and charry but it comes across as pretty leathery.  There is a light sourness in the back that suggests that this keg might be a bit old.  Fairly sweet with a rich malty base.  Heavy coffeeish flavour on the back.  Lightly oxidized with a long roasty finish.  A bit of a strange beast and one that Id like to enjoy a bit fresher.

pitch black with tan head.  chocolatey nose.  little carbonation.  flavor is very powerful with hints of roasted, chocolate, and caramel malts with a nice coffee finish.  the hop component isnt overly noticeable but definitely present and balances the beer almost perfectly.  the flavor is big and powerful, which i guess could potentially be overwelming, that could be the only complaint

Cant really add anything insightful to whats already been said.  This is loaded with coffee.  One jet black pour too although no head on mine.  It is a good stout.  Want to compare it with a Wake and Bake though.

Sampled white making beer bread for Cellars semi-annual beer bread bake off. Pours a dark brown brew with fast dissolving tan head that leaves behind some spotty lacing and a tan ring. Aroma of roasted dark malt, plenty of coffee grounds, some chocolate and molasses. Taste is medium to full bodied, light carbonation with flavors of roasted dark malt, coffee and a touch of pear. Finish has an over-powering coffee/espresso character that covers up most other flavors.
Bottle.  Coffee ground and malt aroma - like smelling a new bag/can of coffee.  Midnight black with giant tan head.  Strong espresso malt flavor with a light bitter finish.  Delicious.

Bottle shared with GregClow, his bottle.  Black, nice small chocolaty head.  Sweet aroma, with tons of coffee roast as well.  Nice taste - lots and lots of coffee, solid sweet stout base.  Nice roast linger and hops at the end.  Another stout winner from Bells!

COFFEE!  This was all coffee.  Deep dark brown pour with a small tan head.  Roasted malts and a huge coffee aroma.  The taste is very similar and tastes strongly of ground coffee with a bit of hops on the back end.  If you like coffee you will love this.

Bottle shared with tupalev. My bottle, obtained from HogTownHarry. Deep ruby-brown with a dark tan head. Aroma of freshly brewed sweet coffee and strong, roasty malt. Medium bodied. Dark malt flavour, with strong notes of coffee and chocolate, and a good amount of hops poking through in the finish. Really well done.

[742-20071006] Bottle (w/ jerc). Super coffee bean and chocolate aroma with lots of dark bean and beer and some brewery. Dark dark brown body with a quick light tan head. Beery coffee flavour. Medium-full body is a little barnyard bitter. Interesting.

Dark as can be, with a nice little wispy tan colored head. Fresh coffee and warm malt aromas. Flavor is a fresh pot of black coffee, dark chocolate covered fruit, roasted malts, and um.....coffee. Has a delicious softness that makes it stand out. Flavor is well balanced. Body is medium thick, which makes for a wonderful sensation on the palate. This may be perfect for a stout - not molasses thick, but not watery.  Once again, Bells comes through with yet another well made brew.

Cofffee. Chocolate. Coffee. Coffee. Coffee. Hint of chocolate. Thats about all that needs to be said about this sucker. I like coffee but I love beer that tastes like coffee and this is one of them. There is a thickness in the mouthfeel that reminds one of an impy stout without the added alcohol burn in the flavor. Super awesome.

I thought this was quite yummy.  Great coffee flavor mixed with good malts.  What I really loved about this one was the body and the mouthfeel.  It was creamy, rich and viscous.  I would actually lean this closer to a imperial because of the richness and body.  Good one to sip and enjoy.

UPDATED: JUN 14, 2008 bottle.  the best coffee infused stout Ive had to date... absolutely wonderful.  Thick and creamy.  Full of coffee, espresso, etc... flavor.  Pours a deep dark black with a thick soft tan head.  Smells of chocolate and coffee.  Nice full body that flows over the palate evenly leaving a nice bitter coffee taste on the finish.  Incredible.  Glad I got a six pack.

dark black bitter ice-coffee, half pump of chocolate, light in my mouth, still all up in my face, a frothy brown head witha thin slice of butter spread coating my tizongue.... this is a tall, but I like it more grande, ya heard?

Pours a very dark, opaque brown with a nice rich tan head that is very thick. the aroma is not as strong as expected but has definite aromas of freshly ground coffee. Taste is similar to coffee with hints of chocolate, which seem to be often present in these styles of beer. I like that there is not much for hops. Neither is their a ton of carbonation, which I like for these brews. The beer is good and a nice light creaminess. A very good stout that has definite coffee flavor.

A: This was a bottle from batch 7768 poured into a Chimay goblet. It pours jet black with a thick mocha colored head that fell over the period of several minutes. A couple of drops that fell on the bottle were a good red color.

S: Im pretty sure a stick of chocolate dynamite went off in this beer because it exudes pure chocolate aroma.

T: This is one hell of a good beer. The flavor is insanely creamy and filled with TONS of chocolate and coffee. Sometimes I think about changing my favorite style to something else and then I have another double stout and that fleeting thought is immediately erased. It is perhaps a bit lacking in the aftertaste department. The flavor doesnt last long enough as it quickly fades.

M: This beer is good and heavy and as I said before, ridiculously smooth.

D: Damn. I might have to move to a state where they sell Bells. Enough said.

Good coffee stout.  Pour was a dark brown with a dark head.  Aroma of coffee and malt.  Taste is similar with some chocolate present as well.  Finish is dry.  Not much in the way of hops.  Mouthfeel is good and creamy.  Moderate carbonation.  An excellent stout.

Pours out black with a chocolate milk head that laces sheets as it dies. Big roasted coffer beans in the nose with a little sweet malt. Taste is very big coffee roasted beans and grounds, also chocolate makes itself knows with a smooth as silk finish with the slightest dry finish. Its not even funny how smooth this is, and its not crazy thick. A delicious coffee stout with a drinkability that rivals all stouts. Try this

Pours a dark brown with with dark tan head that fades quickly.  Aroma is very upfront with the coffee.  Notes of a strong, dark roasted coffee are the first thing I’m picking up followed with some light charred wood.  Some light notes of chocolate are able to waft into my nose as well.   Taste is of dark roasted coffee, semi-sweet chocolate, and light floral hops to prevent this beer from being lop-sided.  Palate is amazing on this bad boy.  It comes on fairly strong with it’s flavor and then glides very lightly over the tongue.  An almost creaminess ensues leaving you to think the finish is going to be watery, but uh no, this beer doesn’t finish weak.  Instead, this beer comes back with a strong finish reminding you of what you just drank.  Carbonation is moderate and the alcohol is well hidden.  Solid.

12 0z bottle thanks to limesmut.  Pours a dark brown/black with a thin tan head which dissipated.  Aroma was burnt coffee grounds and cigarette butt ash.  Taste is very strong, burnt coffee.  It is true to the label, just not very complex.  Medium mouthfeel with dry aftetrtaste.  Decent stout.

Fresh batch 8216.  This one pours a dense, opaque black body with a thick, spongy, khaki colored head.  The foam shows excellent retention, and leaves patches of craggy lacing etched onto the glass.  Aromas include freshly crushed coffee beans, bakers chocolate, scorched caramel and roasted barley.  The flavor is built on the same theme, though it takes a turn for the more complex.  The caramel component is much more mellow and sweet than the nose indicates, as is the chocolate.  Earthy hops add bitterness, while a touch of anise lends depth.  Well balanced, with a medium-full, slightly viscous mouthfeel.  Finishes long and roasty, with an ever so slightly sticky remainder on the tongue.  This one reminds me alot of Mikkeller Beer Geek Breakfast, though it falls just short of its far more expensive Danish counterpart.  Still an excellent beer, and a better value.

12oz bottle, batch 8151. Pours black in color with thin brown head which does not last long. Aroma of strong coffee and dark chocolate. Taste is the same as the aroma with bitter dark chocolate finish.

Pours a dark chocolate brown color with a dark mocho head that has red lacing and turns to creame colored quickly. Nose is of stale / sour coffee and roasted malt. Mouth feel is soft and a bit prickly with a long lasting finish. Tastes like dominican coffee and a bit of natural cocoa. Great brew but a bit heavy. Thanks Kryptic.

UPDATED: OCT 7, 2008 Pours pitch black with a quickly diminishing tan head and loads of lacing.  Aroma is heavily coffee, a mix between french roast and a vanilla cappucino, along with roasted malts and chocolate.  Taste is sweet chocolate up front, very smooth, with a strong dry coffee roast taste in the back.  Its quite striking how the palate is similar to a roasted coffee.  A VERY easy drinking stout.  Rocks hard!
wow!  coffee great pouring dark beer, not much head actually looks like coffee.  great buy for the price
Great coffee scent right away, with an obvious thick black pour.  Nice thick creamy palate thats very enjoyable.  A touch of alcohol noticeable.  Another great Bells brew.

12oz bottle(courtesy of mreusch-Pitch balck body with a small ring for a head and an aroma of coffee and a little chocolate. Taste of a full bodied stout with the taste of coffee, chocolate, roasted malts, and cocoa. Nice tasting stout with the coffee not being overpowering.

Big beefy black stout.  Swirl this stuff around to unsettle the gunk on the bottom and its the best pour ever for a tremendous visual presentation!  Rolling top half of brew. Coffee aroma, what else? Big black cold coffee impact. Once you go black youll never come back is what my dad used to say!  Strong like too much coffe was used to brew it. If you heat this up I think you can repair the cracks in the asphlt driveway with it.  Quite strong and suppressive. On par with Founders breakfast stout.  Finish is, well, what else, youwser youwser big black coffe and bitter need not be said. Probably should be rated as an imperial stout, not just plain stout!
user_location: Beaver Valley, Beaver County, Pennsylvania, USA

text: Looked beautiful poured out of the bottle. Nice, tan, long-lasting head with dark brown color. Coffee aroma (as expected), and terrific coffee taste. I had this as an after-dinner drink (in place of the typical hot coffee) and it really hit the spot. For me, this neared perfection. I wish I would have bought more than one, so Ill go back for more on Monday.
