Cant recall if I bought this or traded for it, so if I traded...THANKS! Gorgeous dark black with wonderful head. Nose of coffee, dark chocolate and toffee. Taste is a bit chalky, but has a great chocolate, coffee bean flavor that leaves a nice bittering on the end. Nice beer.

The aroma was strong espresso coffee roast with an acidic coffee note and a strong backbone of dark chocolate. Some caramel was notable in the aroma and a bit of a grassy nature. The beer poured into the glass pitch black with a brown frothy and moderate head which fell ultra slowly to lace the glass. The flavor was very nice with coffee, espresso and any other coffee drink that comes to mind melded with dark bitter chocolate and roasted malt. The flavor was quite bitter from coffee, grains and more grassy and resinous hops in the background. Any sweetness was quickly mitigated by the bitterness. The finish was dry and nice with lasting coffee into the aftertaste and beyond. The body was just above medium-full and the carbonation was moderate. On the palate the beer was nice and creamy. A great stout!
12 ounce bottle. Batch 8158.
user_location: North of Raleigh, North Carolina, USA

text: Bottle thanks to artusory.  Poureded a deep brown color with a tan head.  Aroma of freshly ground coffee beans.  Fresh coffee dominates the flavor, slight hints of chocolate and a somewhat dry, tart finish.  Very easy to drink.  Thanks to Ryan for hooking me up.

Bottle courtesy after4ever. Pours opaque blackish brown with a thin tan head. Aroma of brewed Folgers coffee. Medium body and carbonation. Creamy chocolate and dry coffee taste. Vanilla espresso finish.

Bottle thanks to NachlamSie. Poured at room temperature outside, 30 degree fahrenheit. The brew poured black with an abundant tan head that gave some amazing lacing. The aroma is of a mild, earthy coffee with some molasses and vanilla. The carbonation is light, creating a nice, smooth mouthfeel. The coffee flavour, as expected, is pretty dominant, though, it seems a little weaker than I like my coffee to be. Cocoa mixes in with the coffee very nicely. Brown sugar and molasses become evident as the brew sits on the tongue a little longer. As it passes, it becomes much sweeter. A coffee-like bitterness lingers in the background. As this brew starts to cool down, the coffee flavour becomes slightly weaker. The sweetness in the finish subdues a little as the bitterness becomes a little more dominant. Now at optimal serving temperature, the initial coffee flavour has become a little stronger again and has leveled out nicely with the flavours of the molasses, brown sugar, vanilla, and cocoa. I really enjoy this brew, and I especially enjoy doing these tastings in the frigid weather with the beer starting at room temperature cooling to optimal serving temperature. Its unique. (Ill have to give NachlamSie some props for introducing me to this kind of tasting.)

Pours deep, dark, black from 12 oz bottle.  Aroma of roasted malts, coffees with a hint of chocolates.  Flavour is full bodied, as you would expect, coffee and chocolate dominates well, balanced with malt and a hint of hop character.  A wonderful work of brew mastery.  As a lover of IPA and IIPA beers, this is truly a nice change in terms of flavour.  I lost hope for some stout beers, except for a few, but this beer gives me hope for deep, dark, flavourful ales and beers.  Excellent job Bells.
user_location: The Crystal Coast, North Carolina, USA

text: TAp at brewery. Poured a very dark black color. Aoma is coffe all the way. Taste is coffe and chocolate.

No doubt about the Java in this one. Pours out a very dark brown with a nice fluffy tan head. Aroma of,,,you guessed it coffee, malt and a little chocolate.  Tastes very strongly of coffee and roasted nuts with a nice little hop. The alcohol blends in quite seemlessly with the perfect carbonation. The mouth feel is thinner than Bells regular stout but still good. Very well done.
Sweet aftertaste that  gets more pleasant as it sits in my mouth. At first, I wish I had the regular stout but after about half way thru I really began to enjoy this one.

Bottle. Pretty jet black with brown head. Harsh aromas of burnt coffee, burnt dark chocolate, and ash, with some faint sweet roasted notes in the background along with a touch of spruce. Flavor is not as harsh as the nose implies-- fairly well balanced chocolatey dark malt and bitter black coffee, with a lingering aftertaste of dark chocolate. Incredibly smooth and creamy on the palate. Just too harsh all around for my tastes-- the burnt coffee flavor/aroma got in the way of an otherwise _delightful_ stout.

Bottle. Aroma of spiced coffee. Lots of coffee but balanced by enough rich, sweet, roasted malt. Pours damn near pitch black with deep brown highlights. Thick khaki head with sticky lacing. Flavor has a good balance of dark, rich coffee and sweet, rich roasted malt with hints of dark chocolate. Rich and creamy on the palate. Finishes with a nice bittersweet chocolate kick. One of the better coffee beers out there.

Java is right. Tastes like chewing on burnt fresh coffee grounds. Very thick beer. Alcohol is very well received on the swallow with slight warming but much tartness. Very hoppy stout with much much much roasted notes.

12-oz. Thanks, FranksnBeans! Black. Slight mahogany highlights. Nearly headless. Laceless. Huge chocolate and coffee nose. Nice medium body with just a hint of creamy thickness to the mouthfeel. Ripping chocolate flavors tear across the tongue; great big coffee notes are on their backs. Nice creamy sticky chocolate finish. I dont ordinarily go for the coffee bombs but this one was dandy.

The nose is more chocolate mocha then coffee, but it pours the proper opaque black with a coffee froth head.  Slightly sweet beginning finishing with a nice long coffee finish.  Doesnt have the wine like qualities of Sumatran coffee, just a standard dark roast with a touch of chocolate to balance.  Nice creamy mouthfeel to go along with it, alcohol not noticeable.

Purchased this beer in a bottle, not very strange as beer of this sort usually come in a bottle.  Poured dark brown, wouldnt say black, with a minimal head.  Strong aroma of coffee, taste of coffee and chocolate.  Quite thin palate, in keeping with the coffee qualities.  Very good overall!

UPDATED: NOV 15, 2007 [Bottle] Pours dark brown with a fairly dark tan head.  Aroma is, big surprise, a blast of coffee.  A little chocolate is also present.  Taste is sweet up front, then another huge dose of coffee and chocolate with just a hint of alcohol on the tongue.  Quite thick, long finish. Like many coffee beers this was fairly one-dimensional, but it was definitely enjoyable nonetheless.

(bottle) Poured into my mega snifter.  Pours dark brown with cream colored head. Upon sniffing I was greeted with a huge aroma of roasted coffee, with some slight undertones of chocolate and toasted walnuts.  This was basically all I was looking for, and then some on the aroma.  Taste was a strong blast of roasted coffee with a lingering bitterness and roasty finish, along with some chocolate.  Medium bodied, perfectly carbonated (like all Bells stouts).  This one pretty much was all I was looking for in a coffee beer.

Pours a very dark brown, with a chocolate frosting colored thick creamy head.  Aroma of coffee and light chocolate, with some charred oak.  First sip was unable to detect the coffee or the chocolate.  Waited a few minutes to let it warm a bit more and bamo, there they were, very enjoyable.  The coffee, chocolate and wood flavors come through.  Finish was a bit tainted by a flowery hop that peeked through a bit too much.  The feeling is smooth and light, but still feels creamy on the palate.  A decent beer, but definately not my favorite coffee.
Solid black with dark brown head.  Aroma of coffee and light roast.  Flavor is of a heavy roast coffee.  Finish is smooth and surprisingly light and creamy.  Very enjoyable.

UPDATED: MAY 22, 2008 355 ml, batch 8158. Jet black with a large head that lasts. Aroma is fresh coffee grounds, cocoa, and charred wood. Flavor is dark roast coffee, charred wood, slight metallic herb and chocolate.  Medium-large body with a creamy smooth palate.

Pours opaque with a massive tan head. Nose is a roasted bean kind of thing with an odd perfume edge to it. Flavor is thick with a nice robust character. On the end I get a roasted edge and that odd perfume thing comes out. It is almost like liquid flowers, with leaves and stems along for the ride. At first this seemed nice. Then that weird flowery perfume edge was kicking in way too hard and it just detracted from an otherwise interesting beer. Ncie to try for the first half at least.

Bottle. Pitch black with puffy brown head. Big time, long lasting frothy lacing. Aroma of roasted coffee, gigarette smoke. A bitter, burnt chocolate flavor, with a roasty coffee background. Could have been slightly sweeter/maltier. Some hop flavor squeaks through in finish. Surprised to see this is 7.5%. Didnt taste it. Good.

Bottle (batch 8158): pours dark black with a big tan frothy head, aroma of coffee is very strong, in fact, that is all I smell, taste is coffee and malt, fairly dry finish but a bit thin of a mouthfeel for a stout.  Probably has too much coffee for me but it certainly is another quality Bells product.

Pours a rich dark brown with almost not head.  It smells of chocolate, malts, and coffee.  It is much thicker in the mouth than it looked when poured.  The flavor is a little bit bitter with strong coffee flavors and some chocolate somewhere in the backgroud.  The aftertaste is very stongly of coffee.  I think this beer may have a little too much coffee flavor for me without much else to offset it.  Its a strong flavored stout.

Every restuarant should have this, what a great beer to have with spice cake, carrot cake, coffee cake, coffee & doughnuts ice cream, etc.... This is the real deal for Starbucks addicts, rich and smooth, super tasty...the aroma of Bold Sumatra coffee beans hit your nose like a sledgehammer, reminds me of Old Rasputin with coffee, truly excellent

Pours a dark brown with a thin lasting brown head. Has hints of burnt malts, coffee, cocoa. Finishes boozy and thick. Has a nice warming of alcohol. Carbonation is fantastic. Sticks to the palate well.

12 oz bottle coutesy of HopHeadinAZ. Sweet roasted nut, caramel and chocolate aroma. Black body with decent dark tan head. Carbination doesnt give that thick stout texture but the rich chocolate and roasted malt flavor is good. Java part comes in as it leaves a some what dry coffee aftertaste but a smooth and ejoyable beer refreshment. Turbo said to have a beer and I had one of his favorite style.

Pours opaque dark brown (coffee colored) with a chunky tan head with nice retention and lacing.  Smells like coffee grounds and a little dishwater.  Wow - very full flavored; bitter coffee, very bitter finish.  Full-bodied, astringent, moderate carbonation.  I love stouts and I love coffee, but this didnt work too well for me.
Bottle.  Powerful coffee flavor.  Some alcohol hints in smell and flavor.  Heavy and quite smooth.  Cant drink too much of it.  Strong hot chocolate aftertaste.

bottle.  small tan head (quickly dissapating) into black body.  aromas of strong coffee (shocking!), chocolate, and some hops.  flavor is light bitterness into moderate sweetness.  texture is dry.  very long duration on finish.  fine stout...if fact I may start having two of these in the morning instead of coffee.

bottle. coffee coffee coffee. and burnt coffee at that. aroma was nice and inviting but the flavor was a bit too burnt for me. came off more like used or old burnt coffee grounds rather than roasted or burnt fresh beans. will definately have another and see if it grows on me or not.

Bottle Black pour with small head and great lacing. Coffee aroma with a burnt coffee flavor. A bit astringent. Not the greatest coffee brew Ive had, but not bad. Honestly, its the same astringency Ive had in homebrew, think its from aging the coffee.

Bottle thanks to gregis
Black pour with a tan head.  Smell was of strong roast coffee, wet burnt gritty coffee grounds, and a twinge of metal.  Taste was strongly of coffee, but smooth, and very creamy.  Again maybe a hint of metal, but not enough to really detract much.  Wet charred coffee bean flavor in a good way.  Very drinkable, perfectly bitter, and spot on body and carbonation.  I loved this beer!

I had to give this one high overall marks simply because of the Sumatran roast that they used.  Unlike the Terrapin coffee brew, this one had a richer taste.  The finish tasted like actual roasted coffee, complete with a nice, bitter kick.  If you like coffee brews, pick one of these up.  If you dont, stay away from it.  The Terrapin brew tasted more like instant coffee than this one.  Good stuff.

12 oz. bottle.   black pour, head of brown froth with good lacing. Aroma of fresh brewed roast coffee, burnt malt, earthy, heavy chocolate.  hop bitterness up front with with a full bodied texture.   Sweet at first then turns bitter.  Overall tastes of...  well, coffee...  lots of coffee.  A little much for my liking -- though good beer no doubt.

Bottle. Its a Bells stout taste fest! Pours opaque black with a dark, medium sizes head. The aroma is, what else? More coffee ice cream than coffee. 
Taste is a little bitter for my taste, but Im not a coffee drinker.

UPDATED: OCT 19, 2007 Dark pour, dark head, what did you think?  Big coffee nose.  Flavor profile had lots of coffee again, but there is a nice chocolate element in there as well.  Problem is that the coffee is not so well incorporated into the beer.  Tastes like wet, used coffee grounds.  Not completely disgusting, not my favorite Bells offering.
The score is all of the effort here:  Great thick black body and definitely a quality beer but it turns out I hate coffee stouts
Pours dark dark with a small tan head.  Smells like sweet chocolatey roasted coffee.  The flavor is bittersweet chocolate and lots of coffee.  A nice slight bitterness on the finish.

Pours black with tan head that slowly diminishes. Aroma is smoky and full of coffee with hints of chocolate. The body is medium to full. The taste is all about coffee. Realy nice roated flavors. with a lingering bitter finish. very nice.

Starbucks/Caribou/Barnies in a beer; plain and simple. This is the strongest coffee stout I can remember. Strong smell and taste. This is a dark roast for sure. :) I dont taste one ounce of alcohol. Pitch black color. Long lingering coffee roast finish.
user_location: Heart of the Rockies, Colorado, USA

text: 12 oz bottle from Sams, Durham. Man, yet another killer - and highly distinct - stout from Bells. Its got a very full body, with a really abundant mouthfeel that distinguishes it happily from some fairly thin coffee stouts out there. But the aroma is killer, and the flavor even better, with rich bitter chocolates blending seamlessly with potent malts and extremely strong roast coffee (tastes more like Italian than Sumatran if you ask me, but what the hell). Kudos again, Bells!

12 oz bottle.  Pours dark brown with a bubbly tan head and minimal lacing.  Aroma of cold coffee/used coffee grounds... probably the intended effect, but strange because used coffee grounds generally smell like something you wouldnt want to put in your mouth.  Tastes really nice though... strong coffee taste backed by dark chocolate.  Definitely good stuff.

12oz bottle, batch 8151.  Pours pretty dark black with a nice foamy, light brown head.  Aroma is really nice, fresh, roasty coffee.  Mmm.  Not much else in the aroma but Im not complaining.  One of the better coffee aromas Ive encountered, right on par with Founders Breakfast.  Taste is strong coffee with a chocolate finish.  Palate is about average - medium bodied.  Could be thicker but not bad.  Certainly satisfies my craving for a coffee stout, which Ive had lately.  Another very well done beer from Bells.
pours dark with thick tan head.  Thick lacing. Coffee aroma. Thick velvety mouthfeel.  Malts, chocolate, and coffee!  Very nice!

Black body with a small chocolate brown head. Smells like coffee grounds and egg shells. Odd coffee grounds carries over to the flavour, dominating over sweet malt. Smooth medium palate. I dont know if this bottle was old or if I just really did not care for this one, but it did not do much for me at all.
UPDATED: FEB 13, 2008 Not quite as smooth as some other coffee brews, but still awesome. Very strong coffee aroma and flavor, good breakfast brew. You best like coffee to drink this one. good stuff
Draft from Capones.  I like coffee and I love beer so how can you go wrong.  Thinner then the expedition stout, but still I thought it was well done.

12 oz bottle-trade w/Acknud-Batch #7768. Jet black pour w/absolutely no head; strong coffee aroma, like an espresso. This one is pretty intense, overwelming coffee flavor w/traces of roasted malt. Its called Java Stout, & that name rings true. Dont bother w/this one if you arent a coffee drinker/fan (which I am) cause thats what it tastes like. I enjoyed it, but some folks may not. Thanks Bill!!!

UPDATED: APR 16, 2011 
Date: May 07, 2005
Mode: Bottle
Source: Party Pic, Indiapolis, IN
Appearance: pours thick jet black, big tan head
Aroma: rich roasted coffee aroma
Body: velvet smooth body
Flavor: rich thick coffee flavor, lots of roasted character, long bitter finish

Date: February 25, 2006
Source: blind coffee stout tasting
Score: iiii to ii
Appearance: black, nice tan head
Aroma: big coffee aroma with touches of roasted and chocolate
Flavor: strong roasted and chocolate flavor, coffee bitterness

Date: June 03, 2006
rich coffee aroma and flavor, all coffee with a hint of beer

Date: August 08, 2008
Mode: draft
Source: maduro
rich chocolate and coffee flavor, butterscotch sweetness, 

Date: January 10, 2010
Mode: draft
Source: taco mac kennesaw
Score: 2.8 to 3.0
Appearance: black, fine tan head, solid lace
Aroma: roasted coffee and dark chocolate aroma
Flavor: big coffee and roasted malt flavor, bitter dark chocolate
Overall: dark and bitter

Date: February 18, 2011
Mode: bottle
Source: hop city
Score: 3.0 to 3.3
Aroma: huge coffee aroma bordering on ashy, rich roasted, dark chocolate
Body: creamy body
Flavor: rich coffee and chocolate flavor, lots of roasted, bitter dark chocolate
Overall: a big ole cup o joe

Aroma: 6/10; Appearance: 6/10; Flavor: 7/10; Palate: 6/10; Overall: 14/20
Rating: 3.3/5.0Drinkability: 7/10
Score: *** /4

Bottle #7768 (December 21, 2006) from john_adam2002. 9 months old. Aroma as if straight from a cup of coffee.  The liquid is much darker than coffee.  No head.  Medium bubble lacing on the glass edge that fades immediately.  Smell reminds me of Meantime Coffee Porter, which I disliked.  It is this memory that makes me wary of this beer, plus I am not the biggest fan of over-roasted flavors, especially if they are combined with acidity.  Let me write down the aroma and appearance score before they are possibly corrupted with taste.  Taste:  ahh, not as bad as I thought, much better than meantime.  Still very coffee flavor.  I think I dont like black coffee.  I like it with cream, and I like it with sugar, and I love it with cream and sugar.  Add a LOT of sweetness to a coffee, and I would like it much better.  Add a creamy texture, possibly from Nitrogen or some maltose late in the boil, and I think your in business.  Some excellent beers use coffee, such as Speedway, but the coffee flavor is more subtle, and after aging the coffee is even more subtle.  Chalk my low score up to my taste preferences.

12 oz bottle courtesy of Acknud. Pours as dark a brown as you can get w/o being black. Tan head w/ minimal lacing. Aroma is of coffee. Were talking expresso here, not wimp coffee. The taste is of coffee bean and some chocolate, but mostly coffee. It is called Java stout. Pretty good although not one I would go out of my way for.

wow.......LOADS of coffee in here!
nice flavour of roasted malt, and chocolate also. very nice stout, very much like drinking cold coffee.
A GOOD stout.  Heavy aroma of coffee, heavy body that looks like espresso, and a strong taste of cocoa and coffee.  WYSIWYG with this one, and what you get is very good.
Pours dark with a small amber head.  Beautiful aroma of chocolate and coffee.  The taste is similar to the aroma.

2004 bottle  Pours black with a small, khaki head. Aroma is lots and lots of coffee and roastiness, maybe a touch of cream? The aroma is powerful. Taste is espresso, milk chocolate, and roasted malt. It almost tastes like a small bit of lactose was added, if so, not much. The finish is mildly sweet. I would have thought the coffee flavor would have lessened over the years, if it has, there was too much to begin with because it is seemingly a pretty large part of the flavor. There is a subtle fruitiness that you get with some the better coffees, maybe this is from the coffee, hops, or chocolate, I dont know. Thick mouthfeel.
Pours very dark with a raosted head.  Aroma is of coffee bean and chocolate.  Lots of coffee and chocolate on the palate.  Definately some roastiness.  Not bad if you like coffee.

(Bottle via trade with <A HREF=http://www.ratebeer.com/ViewUser.asp?UserID=3 target=blank>shigadeyo, thanks Craig!) Add some cream and sugar to one of these and youre good to go for the morning...Pours very dark brown with some ruby highlights. Four fingers of creamy, slightly rocky tan head. Rather unpleasant aroma is of old burnt coffee, little bit of chocolate in there as well as hints of something vegetal. Mouthfeel is nice, smooth, sort of creamy and lightly oily. Flavor is whoa, look out!...very strong black coffee, roasty and slightly burnt - not for the faint of heart. There is some chocolate in there as well I suppose but pretty well hidden by the coffee. Vegetal taste emerges a little as it warms. Lingering bitter coffee aftertaste.

Pours a thick, viscous black with a dense thin mocha-colored head.  Aromas of coffee, roasted malt, dark fruits, and chocolate are densly packed in this opulent nose.  The flavor is thick and rich with dark roasted malts, coffee, chocolate and toffee.  The body is thick and sweet--almost bordering on a lactic quality--without much carbonation and abounds with roasted malt bitterness that coats the mouth and lasts well into the finish.  An excellent, serious coffee beer.
bottle.  opaque, little carbonation.  smells and tastes of unbrewed beans.  Dark roasted flavors.  loose lacing on the glass.  probably wont try this again.

I, like Gregis, really dont see how this beer can be so highly rated or popular. When I think of a good coffee or java stout, I think of Beer Geek Breakfast or Speedway Stout. For me, this was really like drinking day old Folgers on the rocks. Very bitter, burt coffee aroma with a very metallic presence. Flavor is of burnt coffee, tobacco, and finishes with a "the caffeine in this drink isnt worth the effort to finish it" that I often experience when drinking my coffee after it has gotten cold and bitter. Oh well, Im not a fan, but it appears than many are...
Poured a pitch black color from a 12 oz bottle. Aroma was really strong and same as the taste, which was of coffee and roasted malt. This is a really good stout.

Its pitch black with a creamy, light brown head. The aroma has clear notes of roasted coffee and roasted malt, and its slightly burnt and yet smooth. The flavour has notes of roasted malt, dark roasted coffee, light sweetness, a hint of dried fruits and even if there are slightly burnt notes in the entire flavour, it also has a smoothness. The balance is has it weight in unusual parts of the flavour - but the balance clearly is there. Thank you Linus_Stick for this coffee-ish beer! 2340

Bottle courtesy of Plucier: Poured a deep pitch-black color stout with a nice big foamy head with great retention and great lacing. Aroma of medium dry coffee is well balance with roasted malt and light subtle dark chocolate. Taste of nice coffee without being too overpowering and some nice medium bitter roasted malt. Texture is quite creamy which is appreciated with a quite full body and some adequate carbonation. I thought this was a very well done and well balance example of a coffee stout.

12 oz bottle. Wow is this stuff good, way better then the Expedition in my eyes. Poured a viscous dark black with an inch of creamy light brown head, from a rather vigorous pour, into my Lucifer snifter. The head settled down to a small lacing that remained on the edges of my snifter the entire time. Aroma was awesome, Hersheys chocolate syrup, not straight from the bottle but the stuff that would remain on the bottom of your glass if you put to much in, coffee and upon warming some vanilla and even a sligh essence of wood. Flavor was fantastic lots of chocolate with hints of coffee. Mouthfeel was full but a little to astringent on the back of my throat where I wouldof liked it to be a little creamier for being only 7.5%. This is one fantastic beer however and I will grab some more of this next time I see some.

12oz bottle poured in a shaker.  This beer is like a Rottweiler in a glass.  It has a black body and a tan head.  The head has small bubbles and leaves a nice lacing.  It smells like coffee and vanilla.  Its a nice coffee stout with an agreeable flavor, chewy body and pleasant lingering finish.  All in all Id say this is a very nice beer.  Why does this sound so weak?  ..pleasant ..nice ..agreeable..  Because its a good solid beer that would make a great flagship beer or local favorite but not a beer that would stand up to the "big boys" that you can find with a little work.  Its the "girl next door" of beers.  Like Nicole Kidman, it pretty for your home town but not anything to get excited about.

Wow. I dont get the popularity of this beer. I love good coffee and I love good beer. Unfortunately, in my opinion, this beverage doesnt possess the qualities of either. It pours a dark brown with a sizable, frothy, mocha head; pretty enough. The smell, however, is less pleasant. While roasted dark malts and tobacco sit in the background, the dominant aroma in this brew is wet, old coffee grounds. The mouthfeel is medium-bodied, creamy, slick and soft with a bitter coffee finish. Sweet roasted malts along with faint chocolate and cream front a god-awful coffee finish. The finish makes me think of what it must be like to suck on twice-used burnt coffee grounds. Dump the coffee portion of the brew and youd have a very creamy and satisfying stout. With it, you have my least-favorite Bells offering.

Rated 12/31/06:  Talk about deja-vu, I tweaked an oatmeal stout recipe last year and brewed up a coffe stout that was extremely similar to this one. Choked down about half the batch and ended up dumping the rest, just too many coffee beans used. This one is much smoother and tastier, but still not to my expected liking. Aroma is intriguing, lots of ground coffee bean to the nose but with a decent amount of dark malt to make it enjoyable. Dark pour, head soon diminishes, and no lacing very sub-par for a stout. Thin mouthfeel even a touch watery, happens more often than I allow myself to admit w/ Bells beers. Flavor is a solid blend of dark and roated malt with a ton of coffee, again just too much focus on the bean it really detracts from the decency of a good stout. I applaud the effort but not something Id spend my cash on again.

Courtesy bdigi66.  Pours a very dark brown, with a small white head.  Big coffee roasty smell as expected.  Some chocolate as well.  Very creamy.  The taste has big coffee roast, some dark chocolate, and dark malts as well.  The taste seems to be a little too much coffee, and not much else going on.  A little bit bitter in the finish and the aftertaste because of this.  Maybe needs a little more body.

This beer exhibited a very nice dry-roasted aroma, like nice coffee.  Flavor is also very pleasantly coffee-ish with a bit of sweetness and a dry mouthfeel.  I thought this beer was very drinkable and delicious.  This beer is a beer that is highly sessionable, yet offers up a serious amount of dry roasted coffee-ness.  Highly recommended.
Quality stout in all respects---but I dont smell or taste anything but coffee! It overshadows everything else. Really black color.
Pours an opaque black with a brown head.  Aroma is dominated by coffee, and roasted malts.  Flavor is roasted malts, coffee, slight ash flavor.  Pretty good coffee stout.

Overall good stout.  For a strong coffee stout, I would not prefer this over others, such as the Red Hook Double Black Stout.  Very strong coffee flavor and a bit bitter.  Lots of flavor and worth trying.

Strong coffee aroma with lots of toffee and candy. Pours deep reddish brown, almost black with a small amount of head. Strong coffee flavor with nuts, candy. Some sour notes and tannin. Thin body (for a stout) with a pleasent bittery aftertaste and a slight alcohol warming sensation.

Bottle.  Pours a very deep brown/black with a good sized tan head that slightly lasts.  Leaves a nice lacing.  Aroma is of dark roast coffe with hints of chocolate and toffee.  Undertones of sweet malts.  Taste is all coffee with just a hint of chocolate.  Medium bodied with a surprisingly thin mouthfeel.  Finish is slightly bitter leaving hints of chocolate and coffee.  Coffee is just a bit overpowering and makes me feel like I should be drinking this beer in the AM hours.

had this a couple of times so its time to rate it.  pours black with thin tan head.  aroma is a wonderful earthy and spicy coffee blended with some sweet malt and choco lining.  taste is a wonderful smooth coffee with great sweet malt supporting.  finish is a cold coffee ground.  this beer showcases coffee beautifully.  the best non imperial coffee beer ive ever had.
Smells of roasted coffee and malts. Kind of woke me up. Taste was much of the same. Loads of coffee with a rich medium body. Very filling.

I did not get to enjoy this as much as I would have liked, thanks to a crabby girlfriend.  However, what I did enjoy of it was very good.  
Taste is of deeply roasted coffee, bordering on coffee ground infusion, a medium body, which I thought was a bit lacking, but not by much, and a fantastic coffee aroma.  A very good beer.  Earthy, coffee, citric... nice.

Bottle. If you like coffee alot and you enjoy the stout variety alot - chances are youll find this stout favorable.  A nice stout that I feel is perhaps overdone in the coffee department.  Tasty but hard to define other notable characteristics when the coffee prescence is so strong.  Kind of a novelty beer - good, but not something I would turn to on a regular basis.

poured from a 12 oz. bottle into a tulip pint glass, from Batch 7706 (bottled 10/26/2006)

A: Pours a gorgeous deep, rich brown with ample tan head. Looks creamy. Leaves moderate lacing throughout as minor head sticks around til the end.

S: Delicious! Mildly sweet roasted coffee beans with a slight tanginess on the back end.

T/M: Very rich, matches the smell quite well. Possibly a bit too overpowering at times. Very roasted, almost to the point of burnt coffee dominates the body. As creamy as it looks, with the proper amount of carbonation.

D: A bit "much" to drink too much of at a time, but a well-made beer. Id drink again.

Bottle:  Pours black with a large, creamy tan head.  Good lacing.  Nose is coffee dominated with heavy roasted malt tones.  Taste is a better marriage of the coffee with the roasted malt and notes of bittersweet chocolate.  Very tasty and thanks to EithCubes & dirty_martini for sending this gem.
Poured a dark black with a small tan head.  Had a coffee aroma as you would expect with a name like java stout.  had a great bitter chocolate and malt palate and flavor and a very smooth finish

If you call your stout a Java stout, then youd better deliver in the java department. The boys over at Bells managed to do exactly that. A deep, jet black appearance with a small tannish head. Aroma is fresh coffee grounds, some black licorice, dark chocolate and toffee. Mouthfeel is a little sticky. Flavor is an excellent combonation of fresh coffee, dark malts and a clean finish. I couldnt detect any astringency. Just an outstanding beer. Kudos to Bells for this one.

The more coffee stouts I try, the more Im skeptical of the style. This one features a pleasant, deep coffee aroma with a sweeter molasses component as well. Milder roasted notes are there. Flavor starts off with  coffee, and not a whole lot else. Mouthfeel is on the thin side, as alot of coffee stouts are. This one is a touch heavier than most. Theres a roasty chocolate compnent that tries to assert itself. Very low hops, it seems as if the coffee is used as a substitute. Pretty dark, nearly black, with a 1 finger tan head.

Bottle, batch 7706 bottled on 10-26-06.  Pulled it out of the celler to give it a try.  6 months ago I tryed one, the coffee flavor took this beer over.  6 months later...  Pours pitch black with a average fizzy light brown head.  The head is mostly lasting, with fair spotty lacing.  The aroma is still of a cup of coffee, with no hop nose.  The initial flavor is very sweet with no bitterness, the finishing flavor is still sweet and a very mild bitterness.  The duration of the finish is a long coffee aftertaste.  The body is medium to full with creamy texture and soft carbonation.  This is a good stout, I have 4 more in the celler I will pull another one out in 6 months to see how it is holding up and see if the coffee is starting to mellow out.

Pours black with a big fluffy dark brown head. Aroma is a big beefy roast with earth and chocolate to compliment. The three of these aromas although seperate combine to form an overall similarity to good coffee. Flavor is largely coffee with some rich chocolate, and tons of roasted notes. Very smooth and creamy mouthfeel. There is somewhat of a burnt /charred characteristic to it throughout, but overall the roasted notes and its ever loving smoothness stick out.
Pours mahogany into a snifter.  Offwhite head recedes to skim rim.  Sour chocolate and espresso aromas.  Slightly thin and sour with a lasting espresso finish.

Had a sip of this stuff when jarspag drank it, not really something I would want a whole bottle of. Chances are it had gone bad, aroma of espresso with cleaning fluid or something chemical of that nature. Nice mouthfeel and palate however.

UPDATED: APR 22, 2007 the aroma on this one seemed a bit off to me - mostly coffee - but also had some weird funk to it - like something had gone bad.  hard to put a description on it.  flavor was dominated too much by the coffee - but hey, i guess thats what they were going for.  overall, not something i would seek out again, especially when theres expedition.
Wow, this beer is fairly one dimensional.  Taste is straight cold coffee.  Black coffee with no creamer.  Quite strong.  Not quite what I was expecting.
Tastes like burnt coffee beans.  Im not down with this.  Some adjuncts were not meant to be.
Very dark in color. A wonderful coffe aroma. Taste is a very roasty stout with dark coffee and some chocolate on the back end. Very good overall.

(Bottle, Akkurat, Stockholm, 13 april 2007) Pitch black colour with a short brown head. Roasted nose with distinct notes of coffee, heavily roasted and freshly ground. Same goes for the taste: roasted with freshly ground, black coffee, notes of blueberries as well. Some sweetish notes balance the dry, roasted coffee character very nicely. I wouldnt call this very complex, its actually rather one dimensional. But still, this is lovely coffee ... sorry, beer (if you love youre coffee black and strong)
Dark black body with a small creamy light brown head. Sweet rich coffee aroma with some light chocolate hints. Strong creamy coffee flavor with a gentle chocolate background.

Pours out a black color with a thin beige head.  aroma smells like coffee grounds.  Flavor is very much the same.  i really thought this was an impy stout and was a bit suprised when  read the reviews.

This isnt for the weak hearted. There is an extremely strong burnt coffee taste. That being said, I love it!
Pours dark, with a nice tan laced head. You can smell the roasted coffee from the first pour. The first taste is an immediate blast of strong java, then smooths out with the alcohol and co-mingled chocolate. There is a strong roasted java taste left on the palate after every drink. Although the coffee taste kind of kicks you in the mouth, its quite drinkable. Ive had a whole growler of this beer. A nice stout to occasionally drink, but not something I would put in the weekly rotation. If you like coffee stouts this is a must try.
Bottle.  Poured black with dark caramel head.  Smells of lots of chocolate, malt and coffee.  Tastes like more of the same with coffee beans in the aftertaste.  Mouthfeel was pleasant.  Delicious.
This beer got me started brewing java stout for myself. The coffee flavor is a bit too strong; I usually brew with half the recommended coffee and get a great stout. A good reference point.

Black in color with small medium brown head and nice lacing. Aroma was as expected, filled with roasty coffee notes and a little fruity. Flavor was very nice, coffee wasnt overwhelming. Good balance of roasted flavors, coffee, chocolate, and still a little sweet. Aftertaste reminded me of nachos for some reason- corn flavor maybe? Still really good.

Sampled with stegosaurus at Issac newtons. Black pour with a coffee//roasted aroma with hints of mild fruit. Heavy coffee taste with a roast finish. I dont like a heavy coffee taste but this was damn good.

Very thick and black with a small tan head.  Very strong aroma of cappucino.  Tastes just like it smells.  If you ever had starbucks cappucino, imagine that mixed with a good stout.  I think the taste is a little too strong and bitter, but its a very unique beer that everyone should try.

12 oz bottle. Poured a thick, opaque black color. Head was thick and khaki in color with good retention and lacing. Smelled of chocolate and coffee. Flavor was similar with the addition of toasted bread. Light roasty bitterness on the tongue. The only detractor was an occasional whiff of dry dog food. Otherwise pretty good.

Bottle.  Pours black with a microscopic tan head.  Aroma is strong roast coffee and perhaps some chocolate, but mainly coffee.  Im not the biggest fan of the initial taste of this beer (strong burnt coffee), but I think more flavor presents itself in the finish (chocolate, roasted malt).  This is not a bad offering, just not the best Bells has to offer.
Great coffee/chocolate aroma with nice dark color.  Strong taste of burnt coffee and chocolate.  I expected to like this beer, but came away very disappointed with the coffee flavor.

bottle: pours dark oily black with small tan head. first aroma is of fresh coffee grounds and bitter dark chocolate. the flavour is of a burnt triple shot iced mocha. finishes with alot of burnt chocolate also. really like the palate though oily but creamy.

Bottle.  Strong burnt coffee, dark chocolate, roasted malt and boiled vegetable aroma.  Dark dark brown with a brown creamy thick head.  Very rich flavor.  Strong bitter coffee bite, dark milky chocolate, thick and chewy, slight salt and pepperiness.  Palate is creamy with a bitter duration.  Tastes a lot better than the aroma would lead you to believe.  Tastes like it should be heavily caffinated. Perhaps the beer drinkers answer to Red Bull and Vodka.

You know the smell and the taste you get from a cup of Starbucks coffee? That horrible burnt coffee taste and smell... That is exactly the sensation I got when I poured this beer into a glass and took a sip.

The beer pours a really rich, dark black color with a tan head that settles to an ever present ring.  Just looking at the beer, you get lost in its depth.  

That is where it stopped being a great beer and started the Starbucks experience.

The smell was that of burnt coffee and a malt undertone. I could detect a scent of another note, but could not place it. 

The taste was exactly what I dislike about Starbucks coffee. The beer tasted like cold, burnt and over roasted coffee.  The alcohol was easy to detect and the beer leaves a pronounced aftertaste that lingers in your mouth. As another reviewer stated, the aftertaste is like someone put their cigarettes out in a mug of cold coffee then handed it to you to drink. Not a pleasant experience.

As the beer is in your mouth, it actually feels a bit heavy, bitter and oily on your tounge. It leaves a coating in your mouth that adds to the negative experience of the taste and aftertaste.

I was a bit hesitant to buy this at first because I feared it would be a dark, heavy and bitter beer.  However, after my great experience with Bells Special Double Cream Stout, I thought I might enjoy the Java Stout.  Sadly, I dont think I will purchase the Java Stout again. I just could not get past the taste.

Im sure that it may be a really great brew for some and Bells does put out a quality product. I just dont think this complex beer is for me.
Very nice chocolate aroma.Pours dark with a medium tan head.Got some chocolate but then the coffee really came through in the flavor.Full mouthfeel with a smooth creamy coffee/chocolate finish.

not bells best offering. the coffee flavor is definitely present, but the combination of bitter coffee with the roasted bitterness is almost too much to handle. not a drain pour by any means, but a little sweetness to balance the bitterness would make this much better.

A very good dessert brew.  New to this whole reviewing thing...  I am a big coffee fan and to me, this beer is extra special for that reason.  It is the perfect marriage of my favorite drinks, beer and coffee.

UPDATED: AUG 12, 2008 Pours black with small brown head. Aroma is of coffe grounds after the water has gone through them.  Taste is coffee hitting you up front with chocolate and bitterness in the middle, and more coffee and bitterness hitting up the aftertaste.  Good stuff maynard.

12oz bottle (7221) poured pitch black color with a nice lasting light brown head. The aromas were chocolate, roast, coffee and caramel malts. The flavor had a coffee bitterness along with chocolate and roast. The finish was medium dry with a good full mouthfeel. Overall a really nice stout that was thrown off by the coffee.

Pours dark and oily with very little head, really got me to pour it hard. Head is a nice dark brown, and sits just about a centimeter tall. Head leaves hardly any lacing. Aroma is strong coffee; this is probably the strongest, most authentic aroma of coffee Ive ever gotten from a beer. Taste is sweet chocolate, cold and smooth. The hops sparkle lightly and give bitterness and roastedness. A little bit of copper pennies and metal in the taste and aftertaste, dries with peppery notes. Overall, good beer though and alcohol is definitely there. Picked this 12 oz bottle up at Chevy Chase wine and liquors in Washington, DC.

Bottle.  Pours a light-blocking dark brown.  Very thick.  Nice tan head.  Aroma is full of roasted coffeee and malts.  Flavor is also full of the roasted coofee and malts.  A bit on the bitter side.  Rather creamy.  Thick & rich.
black with thin brown foan, it has a very nutty aroma.  chocolate aroma, this full bodied brew is nicely chewy.

Bottle, poured black with dark ruby outlines and a thin brown head.  Aromas of roasted malts and lots of coffee.  Flavors of raisins dried, fruits, molasses, smoke all mingled with bitter coffee.  A well balanced complexity of flavors.  Thick mouthfeel and a bitter coffee-esque finish.  Another fine Bells brew.
user_location: The Land of Milk and Honey, Ohio, USA

text: Bottle, pours thick and dark black with a thin tan head that dissipates.  Strong aroma of roasted coffee and espresso.  Taste is more of the same, thinner mouthfeel that finishes with a lingering coffee flavor that unfortunately starts to taste more like brew from Dennys thats been on the burner too long rather than a quality bean blend.  Not sure if its the overall concept or blend of coffee, but I think Bells should partner with someone more in the know on the beans side for their next batch.  Just like in beer, theres big and generic coffee (robusta) that can ruin the taste and it seems like thats the route this went.  A great concept, but needs a higher quality coffee in the mix.  This ones a rare miss from Bells in my book.

In many ways, and ideal desert brew. Thick, rich, aromatic, silky--just the right melange of espresso bitterness and roasted malt sweetness. The few bottles Ive had, though, have been somewhat marred by a fairly strong dry, metallic/mineralish lingering topnote. I prefer the Expedition Stout. But thats just me.

UPDATED: MAR 9, 2007 A dark black pour with faint tan head.  Lots of bitter coffee in the nose with a faint hint of a veggie crisper that you forgot for a week (best part of the nose).  Light coffe taste with a solid stout base, but still that vegetable taste.  I loathe coffee so I am not fond of this beer, however I can see where this would be an excellent brew for someone who enjoys coffee.

Pours a dark roast black/brown with a nice dark tan head.  Nice chocolate, meadium roast coffee, as well as a slight vegital character.  Nice medium coffee, but not overpowering.  A weird almost watery mouthfeel that makes it taste like a medium roast as opposed to a a dark roast like many coffee beers.
user_location: Farewell Minny; Hello Puyallup, Washington, USA

text: Java.......oh yeah. Very strong coffee note with this one. Tried in 12oz bottle. Personally, coffee note so strong got tied of beer after 8oz, but very good.
Bottle. Poured a dark black body with huge head. Aroma is of coffee, malt, chocolate. Flavor is roasted malt, bitter sweet chocolate. Slight bitterness with a smooth creamy blend of malt and hops.

Bottled - Thanks to Kevin for this one - A black coloured stout with a short-lived but very attractive tan coloured head.  The aroma has tons of coffee, although its not too roasty or over-powering.  The taste is also dominated by coffee but its very sweet and there is a worrying fruitiness also.  I dont like coffee but I can appreciate coffee enhanced beers.  This though has no balance and is not relly very tasty.  Compare this to Darwin Java Jolt from England and this is pretty much non-league.

12oz bottle, Batch 7706, bottled October 26, 2006. Pours a dark brown caramel--black in the glass--with a 1 1/2 finger fading brown head to a ring.  Aroma of fresh coffee and roasted malts, bakers chocolate, a hint of earthy hops and dirt.  Flavor has a lot of bitter bakers chocolate and coffee with some light acidity.  Roasty dry bitter finish.  Medium to full body, low carbonation with a silky mouthfeel.  A solid coffee stout.
user_location: Ocean Beach, San Diego, California, USA

text: Bottle.  Aroma of ground coffee beans.  Strong roasted coffee flavor, some bitterness, faint alcohol, and slight sweetness in the aftertaste.  Too much coffee flavor for me.

12oz, pours very dark with fluffy tan head, very milkshake looking. a dull coffee grounds aroma with floral hops. taste is very roasted, swiss milk chocolate, undertones of rich dark coffee. leathery hops are subtle. the coffee and hops result in a nice bitterness.mouthfeel is rich, creamy, full, but feels a little fizzy on the way down. carbination is low to medium. no alcohol in finish. overall a solid coffee stout and perhaps the best one ive had.

Thanks to richlikebeer!  Pours a deep dark brown-almost black.  Soapy cream-colored head.  Aroma of coffee, roasted malts, and chocolate.  Taste is strong on coffee, but carefuallt crafted with chocolate and roasted malts.
i am not a fan of coffee anything but this was pretty good.  slight chocolate flavor

Chocolate, obviously coffee, with a great aftertaste that follows through with a bitter finish. Really tasty stuff. 

I wouldnt advise this for your last beer of the night as Im pretty sure the coffee is enough to keep you up for at least a bit.

Bottle. Dark brown pour.  Aroma is coffee, and flavor is deffinately coffee with some chocolate tones. Much more coffee flavor than I expected, but once I realized that "Java" was coffee java (I suppose looking at the bottle after it was brought to me could have helped), I enjoyed it.

Bottle. Pours black with a nice tan head on top. Aroma is chock full of coffee, a very bold coffee aroma. Hints of chocolate and roasted malts are in the aroma also. Flavor is very much like espresso with the backbone of a stout. Chocolate flavors sneak in too. This would be a nice morning substitute for coffee. The beer finishes with a very dry feeling in the mouth just begging for the next sip.  A very good beer from Bells!

12 oz bottle via trade, and for the life of me I cant figure out from who.  Nice to rate this in proximity to my pal Bartzilla.  Pours black with a  tan head that has faded to a film that covers the top of the brew.  The aroam is really intense it is pure coffee, rich and strong coffee.  The taste is a great melding between coffee flavors and stout.  Even though I dont drink coffee I can say I really enjoy this brew.  Another stellar brew from the artisans at Bells.

It is what it says. Great stout by a great brewer. The pour was thick and full with a nice tan head with good lacing. The taste was (suprise!) chocolate/malt/coffee with a nice bitterness in the end. I would substitute this for coffee every morning if I were not married and didnt have a job. Delicious!
user_location: Moon Twp, suburb of Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, USA

text: 6 pack via Galtscat, devourer of souls.  Do you like coffee?  Do  you like stout?  Then why are you reading this and not slugging down a few of these?  Nice mix of espresso flavors and delicious stout.  Bells can sure do solid to their stouts.  Very good stuff!
Bottle. Black, small brown head. Lots of chocolates and coffee in the nose. Flavor is the same: bakers chocolate, coffee, malts. Too much for more than one at a time.

12 oz bottle:  Zowie, they arent kidding, there is some coffee in this beer.  I like coffee, and the marriage of beer and coffee is always a welcome venture for me.  This was very good, but dare I say, the coffee may have been a little overwhelming in this one.  As with all the Bells products, this is a quality ale, just a little off, in my opinion.

Dominant coffee aromas. Bitter and rich, but has the smell of spent coffee grounds on a bleached paper filter. Beyond that is a lot of nice coffee undertones. Dark and roasted with a bit of chocolate maltiness. Light bitter hoppiness and smoky presence. Black and impenetrable body with creamy rich tan lacing head. Medium heavy body, sikly but not quite chewy. Medium carbonation. Starts malty with big hit of chocolate and roasted coffee. Mild sweetness tempered by tangy sour-bitter coffee flavor. Nutty roasted bitter finish with coffee tang. Bittersweet dry after. A nice coffee stout.

(Bottle) Pours a inky black with a brown head. Very roasted aroma. Lots of coffee in the initial flavor, with a slightly hoppy finish. Its a good stout, but a little more balance would have made it even better.

Nearly black in the glass.  Lots of clinging head.  Aromas of coffee, black and smoky.  Flavors are spot-on coffee, with a deep chocolate in the background.  Where this beer is lacking is in the palate, which suffers from some graininess and roughness due to the intensity of the coffee.

UPDATED: NOV 17, 2007 Draft at KClingers.  Nice!  Perfect coffee aroma and the beer is like sweet coffee from Starbucks.  My non-beer drinking friend loved it.  Lightly bittered, cold coffee in a glass.  Excellent stout. (#2654, 1/14/07) <<UPDATE: Tried again from bottle, and had a similiar experience.  Very, very good beer.>>

Dark color - looks like espresso with a medium head.  Rich aroma of dark chocolate combined with strong coffee.  Taste is a quality mix of dark coffee with finely roasted malts.  Nice coffee taste with a smooth finish.  Very good!
The coffee has a espresso presence  starting from the aroma to the favor and finish. Not a well balanced stout, but a great coffee lovers beverage.

Pours a deep dark brown, topped with a thick head of brown foam. Betcha this head could float a golf ball. Nice lace clings to the glass.

Smells of sweetened coffee, and a very pronounced roasted scent. Taste is coffee up front, followed by a bit of chocolate and heavily roasted malt. Hop bitterness is there, but not distracting. I like coffee beer, but wasnt wild about the coffee flavor in this one. Tasted like a week coffee to me. Hmmm, I also detect a faint sweet jalapeno flavor in there. Ever try a jalepeno Jelly Belly candy? Thats what I taste. The rest of the beer was pretty good.

UPDATED: MAY 2, 2007 12 oz bottle pours a dark black with a tall brown soapy head.   The coffee immediately wafts up, this is better coffee aroma than i remember.  Rich roasted coffee, chocolate, and bready aromas, wonderful.  Sweet chcolate and bitter coffee flavors are blended very well, thick flavors complemented with the milky creaminess of the head that laces all the way down.  Chocolate coffee finish.  Overall not that complex but what it is is strong big rich flavors, much better than when ive had it before.  This ones for you grampa.

UPDATED: JUL 18, 2007 Dark brown pour with mahogany hues, diminishing beige head. Aroma is very fresh Colombian coffee, dried tobacco, evenly roasted malt and some hops, thankfully no citric aroma. Flavor is a bit of a letdown, just because the hoppiness present makes the coffee component seem bitter. Also tastes of slight tobacco, artificial sugar, more roasted malts. Flavor profile mellow overall. Palate is medium bodied, interesting because it quickly shifts at times from light to full bodied, like a rolling water or oil mixed in. Finishes soft with roasted coffee, off-dry. I didnt enjoy this as much as other Bells stouts but a good effort anyway. The slight bitterness kept this from scoring higher with me due to excessive hops for the gentle coffee and malt.

Bottle.   Pours a dark brown almost black color with a thinnish tan colored head.   Aroma is roasted malt, coffee, chocolate.   Flavor is much the same.   Palate is medium, mildly carbonated, bitter finish.   One of the better coffee stouts Ive tried.

UPDATED: MAR 14, 2008 Re-rate, on cask at redlight.  Aroma has much more chocolate and coffee tones on the aroma.  I definitely enjoyed it more on cask than from the bottle.  

Courtesy SoLan.  Dark brown/black in color, looks thin at the edge of the snifter.  Thin light brown head.  The palate was a bit thin for a stout. Aroma is of roast coffee and roast malt, a hint of a tobacco smell also.  The coffee aroma is a little stronger than the malt aroma, but the coffee aroma isnt very strong overall.  The taste isnt very complex - its dominated by a thinnish coffee taste and finishes with a mild, slightly acidic bittersweetness that lingers a bit.

Black. Modest, frothy tan cap. Big roasty coffee with some malt in the backseat. Coffee changes between quality and vending machine. Medium, balanced body. Perfect breakfast brew. Very good, not as good as their other stouts.

Bells Java Stout
12 oz bottle
Moderate pour in an English pint
Packaged 12/06, percolated 01/07.
Served at room temperature.

Poured black, with clear mahogany highlights, with a large mostly lasting light brown frothy head with good lacing.

Smelt of strong rich coffee roast, with anise, vanilla cream and dark chocolate accents.

Taste was upfront strong creamy rich bitter and moderately sweet coffee followed by more strong coffee bitterness, soy sauce, black earth, and a moderate amount of dark chocolate sweetness on a long bittersweet finish.  Palate was medium bodied, creamy, lively carbonated and lightly astringent and alcoholic.

Overall, first off coffee stouts are my thing.  This version has monster coffee taste with a chocolate finish, but the strength of the coffee overshadows other tastes.  Tasty and drinkable overall.

The color was an extremely deep black.  The head was fizzy and a medium brown.  The aroma had a very dark roasted coffee smell.  It has a bite to it.  It was slightly bitter.  It had a strong roasted coffee taste.  The palate is somewhat thin and carbonated.  The finish is warm and bitter.  I am a coffee person so i can appreciate the mix offcoffee and beer.The flavor of the coffee, however, kindof has a day-old coffee taste to it.  It is good, but i have had better coffee stouts.

Obtained in trade with brewblackhole. Pours a dark black and allows no light through. The head is medium, brown, and creamy. The aroma smells of a very bitter dark roasted coffee. Also has some sweet malt character. The flavor is dominated by what tastes like brewed coffee mixed with stout rather than coffee beans brewed with stout. The palate is rough and roasted with a medium harsh finish.

Draught.  Pours dark brown with tan head and moderate lacing.  Although the coffee is evident, the chocolate and roasted malt are apparent.  I question the choice of Sumatran coffee.  Could also use some more fruit in the background.

Pours near black with a thin, mostly receding mocha head. Aroma of stale coffee and roasted malt. Taste is roasted malt, peppery, vinous, and ashtray. Mouthfeel is full to heavy bodied with moderate carbonation. I love coffee, but this beer is no good.
On tap. Dark brown, tan head. Aroma is coffee, caramel, molasses, chocolate. Flavor is very chocolatey and creamy. I feel like Im drinking a mocha milk shake.

I like coffee.  I dont like instant coffee, folgers, maxwell, or even most burnt starbucks flavors.  I like good strong coffee, so its not coffee taste i dont like.  I drink mine black.  This tastes like coffee that has been left out for a day to oxidize.  glad I tried it, but not one I enjoyed.

Light aroma, dark dark color, dark tan sparkly head, tastes like a thick, overly malted stout as usual from Bells, not bad though....  The coffee flavor comes in mostly in the bitter feeling on the tongue that is only otherwise felt with a cup of coffee...I like it.  light coffee flavor.  Finishes nicely...thats all.

Java Stout tastes very near to Bells Expedition Stout, except with heavy coffee aroma and flavor.  The palate and finish is the same as Expedition Stout.  Thus, Java Stout is absolutely delicious as long as you enjoy very strong coffee flavors in your stout.  A warning however, it tastes so good that you might drink many of these, you might also be transformed into an energized, drunk who believes to possess super moxie powers, then makes a complete ass of yourself because such powers were all a delusion born from Java Stout.  Please, drink Java Stout in moderation.

Aroma of deep roasted malt and coffee a touch perhaps of smoke.  Poured a dark black with a chocolately head.  Flavor is an wake up and drink some more coffee but I didnt find it bitter just strong.   Palate is full and the alcohol is really hidden well.  A fine job done by the folks at Bells. They are fast becoming one of my favorite brewers.
Aroma is like emptying a spent coffee filter.  Taste is dominated bt coffee.  Bitter, not for all but special.

Nice black pour with a big ruby hued beige head.  The aroma is big malt with a nice fresh ground coffee highlight.  This is full bodied stout with strong coffee and molasses flavors coming through the malt.  This has a bitter The finish is long and creamy with a sour character.  Very good stout.

UPDATED: APR 2, 2008 Bottle.  Huuuge coffee aroma with lightly hoppy dark chocolate.  Motor oil pitch pour with a large creamy lacy dark brown head.  The alcohol is virtually non-existent in the nose - this could easily be confused with espresso in a blind sniff.  Medium body, thick, creamy mf.  Dry and bitter, as expected, but not cumbersomely so.  Light bg note of stouty sourness.  Creamy malt takes over a bit for the chocolate and coffee, though those remain the principle flavors.  The effect on the mouth here is remarkable - aftertaste is nearly exactly like that of fine coffee.  A wonderful, unique drinking experience! [4.1]I buy six packs of this every time I see it and drink it throughout the year - its clearly one of my favorites, and easily one of the most interesting beers Ive come across (of 1500+).  Theres no harsh alcohol, no extreme bitterness, no overdone hops; just lush, lasting, rich flavor, with complexity and memorable character.  After a few years of drinking this stuff, I have become an ardent supporter, and, more than that, a true believer. [4.5]

Pours a black color with a dark brown head.  Huge coffee nose on this one with roasted malts, chocolate, and molasses.  Flavor is also big on coffee flavor as expected with the chocolate and molasses.  Decent bitter finish that lasts.  Very nicely blended brew.

Bottle from Santa. If you like coffee then this is the beer for you. Not the faint coffee flavor you taste in other stouts, this really taste like strong, darkly roasted coffee. Black in color with no head. Smooth with bitter coffee grind finish.

Poured opaque black with nice sudsy head which faded all too quickly with moderate lace.  First aroma impression was hot peppers, then the chocolate, coffee and roasted malt start to sort out.  The flavor starts out all strong coffee then fills out with dark toasted malt and bitter chocolate following.  Some hops and yeast in the background.  Full viscuous body, nice and chewy.  An eye-opener.

Dark color. Smell of coffe, coffee, hops, malt, coffee, syrup, chocolate, hint of caramel and roasted coffee.  Did I mention that I smell coffee?  Taste of malt, roasted coffee, hops, caramel and milk chocolate.  Nice bitterness at the end.  It was like drinking a cold/room temperature coffee.  Great stout!

Very dark, almost black, with a strong sweet malt coffee aroma.
I love this beer , I love the robust coffee flavor with a little dark chocolate sweetness added. This is one of my new favorites, if tit wasnt so damn expensive Id buy more often. Definitely another impressive brew from Bells.

UPDATED: JAN 17, 2008 COULD I PLEASE.......GET SUM BEER WITH MY COFFEE. WOW i dont drink coffee..but this is amazing. a great brew at about 7 am with some eggs and sausage! just potent all around a hell of a coffee stout unreal flavor the aroma is pure black coffee in a blind smell test 99 in 100 would say black coffee but so much more in the taste phenominal VERY highly recommended
If you like a little stout with your java, then look no further.  A pure palate buster.  Drink this and youll be tasting coffee for weeks.

UPDATED: JUL 27, 2009 Batch 7221
11/22/2006:  Color is as close to black as one can get without actually being black.  No lasting head.  Aroma is like freshly ground coffee beans.  Flavor is like drinking rich and robust black coffee while eating roasted coffee beans and a piece dark chocolate.  Needless to say, the finish is espresso like with some roasted malt, bitterness, and a touch of sweeter chocolate at the very end.  The mouthfeel is slightly thicker than average and smooth.  -- 

Im not sure whether to call this to call this beer with some coffee added to the brew or coffee with some beer added to the brew!  It takes so much like cold coffee that Im really leaning toward the latter!  This one is not for people who dont like coffee!  Overall this was an interesting and pleasing brew, but would have liked something a bit more complex in flavor besides just black coffee.  Maybe there is too much roast in this one to the point that it almost tastes burnt...

12 fl. oz. bottle from Party Town (if I remember correctly).
. . . . . . . . . .
2003 Vintage
12/06/2007:  There is lots of MOCHA in the aroma as well as dirt and still lots of espresso.  When warmer, it smellls a bit stale.  The flavor is quite earthy and progresses from chocolate and coffee beans to caramelized malts, to a roasty finish.  When warmer, the oxidation really shows as the flavor turns to be more like dry cardboard and burnt coffee.  The beer is very dark brown in color with a tan head.  Overall this beer hasnt aged all that well and is definitely much better when consumed cold.  Its probably best just to enjoy this beer fresh or within a year or so...
12 fl. oz. bottle.  NOTE:  The posted score is for the previous rating from 11/22/2006...
Bottle: Black with a big dark tan head. Aroma, tons of coffee. some roasted malts, and a bit of chocolate. Flavor, rich coffee, some bitterness. Good thickness to it as well.

[Bottled. Thanks Kramer.]
I suppose this was almost black in colour. Aroma from old thermos coffee. How I hate thermos coffee. Luckily parsley and notes of cigar was traced, so no need to weep. Thick body, bit oily with light notes of chocolate and suggestions of oranges. Flowery hops in the background. On the surface, there is a wall of dark flavours.

UPDATED: SEP 8, 2007 Tap at the Happy Gnome.  The pour is opaque black with a head similar to the froth on a fresh espresso shot.  The aromas are of old coffee on dirty clothes (like my roommate getting home from work), burnt hair and the smell of espresso machines being emptied and cleaned.  Tastes somewhat like milk with cocoa but is drowned by the soapy texture of old coffee grounds.  An exemplar of this poorly conceived idea.

Mmm coffee... most true coffee flavor in a coffee stout Ive tasted so far.  Smells and tastes just like a nice creamy cup of iced coffee.  Slight roastiness and a little chocolate, but mostly coffee and lots of it.

12 oz bottle. Black with a film of a brown head. Strong coffee and charcoal nose. Smells like Starbucks Sumatra coffee, which, after reading the commercial description, makes sense. Strong black coffee flavor, light charcoal, a touch of bitter chocolate. Finish has a bit more chocolate, but this thing is all about coffee.

UPDATED: JUN 5, 2011 (Bottle) Pours black. Aroma of roasted coffee beans with some wet stone, cigar and hints of parsley. A bit salty smell. Bitter flavour with black roasted coffee beans. Nice balance between dry and sweet. Medium to big body.Not to complex but good. Second try: (Bottle) Pours black with brown head. The aroma is super coffee-driven with notes of green bell pepper, gravel, parsley and tar. Bit earthy and light resinous background. Clean and dry on the nose. The flavor is light sweet to dry, near medium bitter and tiny acidic. Coffee, light hoppy and medium roasted. Super yummy but not complex. The mouthfeel is sticky yet fat with a soft carbonation. Coffee and hops lingers. Medium bodied.

12oz bottle courtesy of kramer17801.  Thanks, Jason!  Pours a dark black center, thin brown edges; medium tan head (poured headless the first time) with ok retention.  Hugely aromatic nose: showing coffee and coffee.  Sharp carbonation, slightly acidic; medium-to-full mouthfeel showing plenty of smoke, fresh coffee beans (unroasted), slightly vegetal, and some dark chocolate; medium finish showing coffee and a slight dry hoppiness.  A coffee lovers stout, but pretty one-dimensional otherwise.  I feel awake.

Aroma of coffee, ash, dust.  Appears an opaque black color with a small deep mahogany head that dissipates.  Flavor is complex - sweet chocolate elements combine with a mocha tang, all finishing with an excellent fresh brewed coffee flavor.  Palate is medium-thick and creamy, and it certainly helps enhance the coffee aftertaste.  Overall, an interesting brew.  My thanks to joeybgood for this fine sample.

UPDATED: NOV 5, 2006 Bottle via trade withe Dickinsonbeer. Thanks Paul!  Intense aroma of roasted, almost burned,  coffee grounds and not much else. Flavor is a bit more complex with coffee flavors still dominating but slight hints of bittersweet  chocolate are evident. Medium to thin body for style.  Not as thick and creamy as I expected. Alchol hidden well, but frankly the burnt coffee grounds just overpower this beer for me.

Bottle: Pours completely black with little to no head. Smell is intense in coffee aroma. If I didnt see the bottle sitting right in front of me, I would think I was possibly smelling cold coffee, with just a hint of chocolate. The taste is not quite as strong as the smell. It still has that coffee flavor with a bit of chocolate.
Rich in coffee taste like many said below a little bitter on the finish but still a complex flavor smells of coffee definitely better ones out there but pick one of these up come january

Pours pretty black, but not real black. Aroma is really burnt astringent smelling coffee. Flavor follows with some roast and chocolate up front, which is pleasant. But then comes the onslaught of coffee bitterness that was a bit unpleasing. Decent but Ive had better coffee stouts.

Bottle sampled. Pours black with a large cola colored brown head. Aroma of roast, coffee, and chocolate malt. The flavor is sweet upfront, lots of roast and coffee, chocolate and bir=tter hops in the finish. Good body and mouth feel, good brew.

UPDATED: DEC 9, 2012 First ratingInitial Rating Date: 10/9/2006355 ml bottleDry old parchment scent, burnt a bit coffee. The "driest" beer Ive ever smelled. Black color, brown head. Full mouthfeel, sweet taste with a burnt coffee note. Medium bitterness. Not well balanced.6/4/6/3/12=3.1RerateBottle thanks to (non-ratebeer) Matt/Nekrobarr! Sampled on December 2, 2012.Black color, big light brown head. Sweet malty scent. Malty, roasted, sweet taste. Warming alcohol. Medium to smooth mouthfeel, medium high bitterness.6/4/6/4/13=3.3

12 0z. bottle courtesy Hellomynameis -thanks Zac. Dark brown/black, just a hint of light coming through the edges,. Big brown, durable, frothy head. The coffee aroma in this is profound, like sticking your nose in a cup of espresso. Theres also a noticeable burnt, woody aroma. Medium/full body with some astringency, but overall a pleasant mouthfeel. Rich malty backbone is opposed by the bitterness of the coffee and some peppery spice notes. Dry finish that leaves you wanting more. If you dont like coffee, this isnt for you. Fortunately I like coffee, strong and black, so this suits me just fine.

Bottle shared with HogTownHarry & mds -- my bottle. Pours a very dark brown, almost black, with an average size light-brown head. Aroma: no surprises here, a really nice, big coffee ground smell along with dark roasted malt and some chocolate. Flavour is predominently coffee along with roasted malt, chocolate and a nice bitter finish. No sign of the alcohol, its incredibly well hidden. Great full body. I really enjoyed this, if youre looking for a top-notch coffee Stout then this is your beer.

UPDATED: SEP 27, 2006 Bottle (12oz).  Shared with blankboy and mds, blankboys bottle.  Opaque black, small tan head.  Very bitter aroma, strong coffee grounds aroma, bitter and acidic - these guys make good shit.  Taste - strong coffee, hints of chocolates and hops, very bitter and rich - yummy.  Thick body, not much carbonation, acidic mouthfeel, long balanced finish- good stout.

Dark brown poor.  When you order this beer you know what you want.  Rich coffee flavor that you would not wqant unless you really enjoy coffeee and beer.  I woul recommend it to a select few people that Iknow would appreciate it for how great it is.
A dark almost black pour with a dark tan head. Sweet chocolate aroma. A semi sweet harder more bitter flavor than I expected. Just a tad on hte fizzy side for my taste. A beer I liked very much

355ml bottle obtained in a trade with <a
href=http://www.ratebeer.com/ViewUser.asp?U target=blank>OhioDad, thanks Scott.  Deep black in colour, very long lasting rich tan head, great lacing.  The aroma has an incredible fresh coffee roastness, bitter dark chocolate, some vanilla.  The flavour is of intense coffee, cream, sugar, dark chocolate, vanilla, some espresso.  Very bitter mouthfeel, medium body, medium carbonation.  Finishes long with a moderate bitterness.  An outstanding coffee beer. Batch #7221.
Very nice if you are in the mood for the dominant coffee note. Look and mouth feel are great. Not as nice as the fine gritty texture of the coffee in flying dog gonzo impy porter
One of my favorite stouts (Double Cream is good too) and one of my favorite Bells beers. Chocolate. Coffee. What more do you want from a stout?

Bottle. pours dark black, with a nice thick dark tan/brown head. Aroma is strong on coffee beans, roasty malts, and a bit of vanilla. Flavor is just like drinking chocolate covered espresso beans. Very nice.

UPDATED: DEC 7, 2006 12 oz bottle via trade (thanks Ross) Small bubbly tan head that quickly dissappears.Beer is midnight black. Aroma is malty caramel, plums, espresso, vanilla licorice. Alot of aroma happening here! Wow, it actually DOES taste just like it smells.
Creamy, full bodied. Wonderful espresso/licorice finish. Bittersweet cocoa aftertaste that lingers.mmm this is good! I need more of these....

Nice stout!  The coffee flavors do dominate , but dont over power. It would be killer even without the coffee flavors. Color is black as pitch, with a camel brown head. Smalls like coffee as you would expect, but some toffee, caramel and wet dirt notes are also percent. Really good mouth feel, and not to carbonated. Another reviewer commented on the bitterness, but I deducted almost none. Nice one! Also recommended for use none bitter loving guys is, Oscars Chocolate Oatmeal Stout.

I love coffee stouts and this was a great example of one. Exactly what I am looking for chocolate and coffee. I think the coffee actually added a little bitterness to this one. I was expecting the body to be lighter in this one but it was still pretty solid. It is nice to have a great stout sometimes that isnt over 10%.

On tap @ Bells!  Very dark.  has a sweet coffee flavor.  fine bubbles give it a tangy - tart flavor.  coffee is STONG -- like espresso and mocha.  Chocolate aftertaste lingers for a while after each mouthful.

UPDATED: AUG 11, 2007 Pours jet black with a thick light brown head. Intense, earthy coffee aroma with a touch of mocha. Flavor is dominated by full-bodied, deep-roasted coffee (which is fine by me). Next comes notes of chocolate, mocha and then a ton of sweet caramel. Very earthy and dirty tasting in a good way. Plenty of bitterness provided by the tons of roasted malt and roasted coffee in here - they probably didnt even need to use hops. Medium bodied (a little thinner than anticipated) with moderate carbonation. I would have preferred it a tad less sweet but really good stuff regardless. If you dont like coffee, stay far away from this beer.
@ brewery.  Only one word can be said about this beer, as it decribes the nose, flavour, and body: Coffee.

via trade with OhioDad - Pours a deep dark brown with a nice tan head which quickly fades to a film.  Aroma is only coffee.  Flavor is mostly coffee with a little chocolate flavor in there.  Finish is smooth and dry.  Medium body.  I like this a little better than Founders Breakfast stout.  Good beer.  Thanks Scott.

Bottle from my secret santa!! Chocolate and coffee aroma is heavenly. I love coffee stouts, and this is a great example. Lots of espresso and chocolate in the taste with a bit of cinnamon. The coffee outshines everything else..and thats what I love about it. I could drink one of these every morning. 
Thanks Santa!

bottle.  Aroma:  The slightly sour aroma of fresh roasted coffee beans.  Also getting notes of chocolate and orange.  Appearance:  Dark, dark brown in color with no highlights.  Medium tan head was full and creamy.  Good lacing.  Flavor:  No surprise...It tastes like coffee.  A full, rich coffee flavor, but also a lot of burnt malt flavors.  Getting some tastes of chocolate and caramel, as well.  Slight resinous taste from the hops.  Palate:  Full bodied and creamy.  High carbonation.  Finish was nice, but could have been a little dryer.  Slight alcohol warming on palate.  Overall:  If you like coffee, this ones for you.  Coffee flavors somewhat overwhelm the other flavors here.  Still, a very nice beer.

Bottle a trade with kramer17801 Stouts are great in any season! I drink hot coffee every morning even when its 85 at dawn! Nose of coffee, dark chocolate,  with a smoked malt note in the background, kinda faint, but there. Totally opaque black with hints of crimson showing at the surface edges and a thick red-tinged tan head that hangs in there while you sip. Flavor shows COFFEE!, bitter chocolate, and a nice bitter hop finish!

Ah, its been a while since Ive had a good stout!  Its summer you say?  Who cares!  Crank up the ac, and drink some winter beer!  This ones loaded with fresh ground strong coffee bean aroma.  Also smells like fertile soil.  Deep dark brown with a light brown fading head.  Hooo leee sheet.  boy thats some delicious dark chocolate bitterness.  Its perfect for drinkin anytime of year.  so, its bitter, cause thats what dark chocolate and coffee are like, but they friggen nailed this one.  Dad would like it too.

The Sumatra flavored coffee has a nice bittery grassy feel and the stout kind of floats around it, adding an extra boost of roasted malty flavors. In the aroma there is a whiff of toasted cherries which is carried over in the flavor. It is medium-dry and well suited for coffee lovers like myself. However, it does not make we want a cup of water like some of my favorite coffees do.

This baby is like drinking a cup of Folgers mixed with alcohol! Very heavy coffee everything--aroma, appearance, and taste. The coffee flavor has a bitterness to it, but not much else to make this really interesting. The mouthfeel is a little off, not sure why, but it isnt as smooth as the other Bells stouts Ive sampled. Not a bad stout, but definitely not one you would probably want to drink all day. (what, you dont drink stouts all day?)."

Bottle at Delilas in Chicago. Poured dark with a rich and creamy head.Incredible coffee and mocha notes. Nice thick mouthfeel which went down smoothly leaving an unmistakable coffee aroma in on the palate. Great brew. NOT just a clever name!

Coffee, coffee and more coffee! Did I just order a double espresso, or is this beer? Deep brownish/black with a tan pillowy head. Robust coffee aroma and flavor with a slight chocolate aftertaste. Very good.

From 12oz Bottle, #7221.  Pours a deep chocolatey black color with a nice even layer of medium bubbled toasty head.  Lots of roasted coffee present in the aroma, and it brushes my nose with a whiff of dark chocolate as well.  Plenty of roasted malt gives it a rich blackened toast quality.  Full bodied, slightly creamy texture that boils out in an initially roiling sensation on the tongue before receding to its peaceful creaminess.  Tons of heavily roasted sumatran coffee washes over my palate, accompanied by an earthy oaky hoppiness.  Not overly complicated but it delivers exactly what it says on the label - hordes of delicious coffee combined with an oaky woody dryness make this a delicious example of a stout.

12 oz. brown longneck bottle. No freshness date, but a 6624 seen on back label. Poured out a deep chocolate brown color, with a thin mocha colored head. Leaves a decent lacing down the sides of the glass.
Aromas are of sweet cherries, dark roast coffee, earthy hops. Bready flavors mix with birnt sugars & coffee.
Earthy hops round out the mixture. Thick, rich mouthfeel. Almost chewy.
